author: BatMeckley
content: I’m going to get absolutely hammered for this, but, you can’t be afraid to suck. It’s ok to suck. Stop spending all your time analyzing how not to suck and just go out and suck. And then suck again. And then suck again, but a little bit less. And just bake into the equation that you’ll suck for probably 50-100 songs. Because every success is built on a ton of previous sucking. Even Michael Jordan got cut from his highschool basketball team cause he sucked. But no one got worse at something the more they did it. You’re not supposed to be good at something right away. You’re supposed to suck, until you finally don’t. But you get to the suck less phase by actually sucking lots.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
📖 story time:

Arguably one of the most important things I did in my career was a last minute instrumental version of "I Love Rock N Roll" for an A&R at Syco in the US for some random contestant on the short-lived US version of the X Factor. I crushed it on a deadline, then that same A&R hired me a year later to work on a band called Emblem 3 who was on X Factor US as well. I crushed that and then six months after that he recommended me to a UK A&R who was having trouble finishing a song for One Direction. I did a spec production on the song Best Song Ever and they liked it and used it and all of a sudden I become a big pop producer. Stemming from doing an great job on some instrumental cover for a dumb singing tv show.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Without going too therapist couch on the details, I was the only kid that had to lie to my parents in highschool and tell them I was going to parties (which were ok) and then went to work playing shows on the sunset strip (which was banned). Moving to Australia to join a band in my early 20s got me excommunicated from half of my family, some of whom I didn’t get to talk to for nearly a decade. Some had credible experience in the industry, others just in life, but truthfully, if you care about someone’s quality of life and ability to provide for themselves and hopefully a family, you don’t steer them towards a career in music. 

But, I wouldn’t be told no, and every time I was pushed away from something I wanted to do (I couldn’t go to school in LA because it was too close to the industry) I ended up somewhere that actually furthered my career (I ended up in San Diego, where I became friends with the Switchfoot guys which really helped launch me). It’s why I have such little patience for the “oh the studio manager was short with me while I was an assistant” crowd… if you want it bad enough, you figure out a way to make it work. And if you don’t want it bad enough, there’s a hundred more guys like me that do, that are willing to sacrifice their time/health/money/etc to the cause. I don’t say that to frame it as admirable or healthy or anything positive, it’s just the truth of how things are. 

So, that person that’s going to quit because a studio manager was challenging, or a teacher didn’t like their song? They’re going to get devoured by the people that really dedicate their lives to this, and it feels cruel to tell them otherwise.

author: NoahNeedleman
content: “Nobody tells this to people who are beginners, I wish someone told me. All of us who do creative work, we get into it because we have good taste. But there is this gap. For the first couple years you make stuff, it’s just not that good. It’s trying to be good, it has potential, but it’s not. But your taste, the thing that got you into the game, is still killer. And your taste is why your work disappoints you. A lot of people never get past this phase, they quit. Most people I know who do interesting, creative work went through years of this. We know our work doesn’t have this special thing that we want it to have. We all go through this. And if you are just starting out or you are still in this phase, you gotta know its normal and the most important thing you can do is do a lot of work. Put yourself on a deadline so that every week you will finish one story. It is only by going through a volume of work that you will close that gap, and your work will be as good as your ambitions. And I took longer to figure out how to do this than anyone I’ve ever met. It’s gonna take awhile. It’s normal to take awhile. You’ve just gotta fight your way through.” - Ira Glass

author: thegreatcarsoni
content:
Re; Brauer workshop

-First 2 days were nothing technical, the 1st conversation he brought up was about TM and how meditation in general has helped him.
-Everything is feel-based, most technical Q's for the first 2 and a half days got the same reply: "It doesn't matter to me, i don't care what the thing is long as it feels good". 
-MHB actually seems to leave the planet while he's mixing, it's wild how immediate he gets into that space. Seemed to go way past "i love mixing and here's all the reasons i'm the shit" and it was inspiring to see the ego leave the equation. His decades of experience are playing directly into his ability to access the story of the song and present it in a compelling, live-feeling way. He mixes from inside the song and performs. Well, he does discovery, then shapes the sounds, then performs just about everything on faders.
-The biggest wake up call to me is that a lot of moves i've made on mixes did not have a good reason behind them. So continuing to ask "why" as I work is gonna be important, because I have to start catching myself and adjusting when the answer to "why" is "because someone said this preset is cool" or "because this is what I do to a vocal/guitar/drums". I feel music very deeply, it's why i got into this, but I feel like i've been poisoned against trusting that instinct and convinced that what we do is a technical job. I'm done being an observer of the art, i want to be bold.
-It's critical to build trust with clients right away, you can't assume anything in what they understand about how you feel. Telling them you love the song and you're excited to mix it is important, and never blaming production/artist/anything else for the mix being less than what it should be. never okay to say "i did my best", because that gives you an out and implies somebody else could do it better
-Therefore, you must believe when you sit down to mix that nobody is gonna interpret this song better than you.
-Generally i'm skeptical to just take on someone else's "method" and start operating in that space just becuase of the success they've had with it. Putting this week into practice is going to mean using his template to get reps in, listening and feeling and interacting in a new way and letting my brain "level up", if you will, then zooming out and making it my own.


I can distill this more and want to share about a couple other specifics, but I just realized I grabbed someone else's notebook by mistake when I left on the last day so I'll need to have them mail mine back to me.

author: BatMeckley
content: But to come full circle, and in line with our talk at Cian’s the other night, my Lol’s on here are more for the 980 people on here that are registered but don’t contribute, or aren’t as active. There are GUARANTEED aspiring engineers, mixers and producers on here that are taking what we say far too seriously, and I feel a genuine responsibility to not entirely dash their dreams because they just spent every dime they had on PMCs or their beats suck. It’s a tricky to path to navigate between taking what we do seriously, without taking ourselves too seriously. It’s a people business, and I do my best to embody on this forum that I’ve found the best way to work consistently in this industry is to be able to take a joke, make a joke, and keep putting out good work. Which I think is FAR more important than if you picked PMCs or ATCs.

author: kieronmenzies
content: On the topic of communication, I know it goes without saying (pretty sure we're all guilty of this) but it's always worth mentioning in case there are any younger impressionable minds reading this. Older unimpressionable minds may as well read it too. Don't forget to communicate with yourself. Week in and week out, I don't know how many times I plug my ears and go "lalala I'm not listening" when my body starts throwing terms at me like fatigue, exhaustion, dehydrated, hungry, getting sick, underslept, stressed, depressed, fully sick, too much coffee, etc. At this point, maybe it's time to listen and do yourself a favor because in the long run, every favor done for you is also a favor to your family, your community and your clients.

author: LAPhill
content:
It's really hard to make decisions when you feel like our back is up against the wall. We've all experienced some degree of this, one way or another, and a lot of it comes down to personal tolerance for risk and resilience to weather dry spells, as well as our individual life circumstances.

There's no medal for going months without income. If you need to find a day job or side hustle to stay afloat, that's not failure. That's responsible. If the feeling of your wife's support is making you feel guilty, then it might be a signal to take some action to address that feeling. Music will always be there, and it's not an all-or-nothing proposition. 

I'm not trying to prescribe the way out of this, but give yourself some grace and permission to navigate it. You're not less-than because you take time to address your personal life and finances in the midst of building your career, you're human.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Loving your job 80% of the time is a phenomenal, compared to the general public. 

One thing I’m amazed by working with Cian & Rollmottle is their endless capacity for positivity during a project. No matter how shitty my delivery or communication, they approach things with a smile and a sense of humor. I’ve literally never heard either of them complain. I thought commiserating about shitty aspects of a gig was a part of professionalism, but they have me rethinking things. 

In my own projects, when I approach clients with patience and curiosity, I find that not only are they happier faster, I’m happier the whole time. It’s SO MUCH EASIER to say “let’s try it” than to say “here’s why that’s not a good idea.” I find I learn a lot that way too. 

In any case, going back in to fix or add only bugs me when I think I’m supposed to be done. If I can stay open, then opening a session feels a lot easier. 

So I guess my advice is: you might have fewer problem clients if you try to remember they’re not problems to solve, they’re people to serve.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Fun little chat with my old mic tech in LA. He and his wife sing together and are getting back into it. 

He’s got a vintage 67 and 269 in pristine condition, is mostly doing audio for movies now so he’s stepped out of tech work and will only send his mics to Germany to get worked on. 

That’s all preamble for this part of the story. 

He recently did a shootout on pres & compressors for his home setup. Ended up selling his vintage Neve & La2a in favor of the ORIGINAL MBOX. The first iteration that had Focusrite pres I guess? Had to buy old laptops to run ProTools 8. Has 3 rigs at his place and got ‘em all for under a $100. 

Boys & Girls, Vintage Digital is officially en vogue.

author: LAPhill
content: Don't want this to feel like a cop-out answer, but when something goes wrong, priority number one is fixing it. Regardless of why it happened. Let's assume you're not saying someone else in the room fucked up, but that a freak act of nature caused something bad to happen. The electricity went out in the middle of the session. A tree fell on your studio. The question is.. what can you do to better bolster yourself against that in the uture? It wasn't your fault, but if the electric company has a history with random outages, maybe it's time for a change. Or at least some badass generators. I know it's a random example.. but if it really wasn't your fault in any way, all you can really do is try to prevent it from happening again.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
On the food analogy:

Making food that is nutritious is not hard. A pile of kale, a bowl of plain beans, an avocado, maybe a fish, and a glass of water and you've got nutrition.

Making the first bite taste amazing isn't hard either. Add a ton of salt sugar and oil, maybe fry it. That'll hit 98% of people's taste buds hard immediately.

The challenge is not doing either, but doing both. 

Same is true for music.

First listen great, 1000th listen great, and have that effect on the most number of people. That's my favorite kind of music.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Hey @everyone. A quick PSA about form on this server: 

As this server becomes more populated the quantity of daily/hourly posts are increasing. This is a great development and we love to see lively, thoughtful conversations. 

With this increase in posting comes a lot of information that can sometimes be overwhelming to manage and parse. Especially when a channel has two different conversations happening on top of each other. I think we've all casually opened the app at one point and seen "40+ unread messages" and been taken aback by the sheer amount of convo that we now have to catch up on.

Moving forward I ask the following from everyone:

*1. If you see a conversation starting to ramp up use Discord’s **Create Thread** feature to fork off the conversation into a self-contained thread. (see attached pic)
2. Give the thread a descriptive name.
3. Continue all follow-up posts within the new thread.*

author: Barbara
content:
Feeling like shite, scheduled an in person mix review, in order to finish this project - communication wasn't being effective, so I though it would be easier this way to get something that would make us both proud.
Got the dry files from the producer 1h before meeting with the band.

The project is finished on my side. On to mastering now. Today feels like the first day of my life 😆

All of this to say what I think is really important and some things I learned that I wish I knew when I was in the middle of those project blues:
1) you WILL get through it.
2) it might be possible to turn it down or pass it to another person
3) trust yourself and your skills to make the best you can
4) set boundaries and expectations. From the start. With the artist and yourself.
5) try to find something you can enjoy during the process - to me, it was on the very last day of mixing that I changed something on my workflow that got me excited, helped me get to the sound of the album we were looking for and will probably be something I will do for every project from now on
6) surround yourself from colleagues/friends who can help you - I know this needs a strike of luck too, but I'm sure if you don't have a reliable in-person "work friend" who can be there for you (with kindness, while keeping it real), this discord might be a good place to ask for that kind of help.

author: cian riordan
content:
The take-way from all this blibber blabber is that I went in expecting to be trusted immediately. I wanted to show off… to establish ‘status’ as Ruairi put it. But it took years of patiently learning the ropes at the highest level to be trusted by the folks in the highest circles. I look back upon that now and I’m still amazed that I was paid to do that. It was essentially like a paid college degree in making records.

So now when I go into studios with a big client, I see the assistant through those eyes. I’m kind but communicative. If they can hang in the back and figure out how I work, anticipate breaks — get the menu book ready — know that we’re going to change gears — start setting up for that — then they get looped in. They get my running commentary on what techniques I’m doing. They get the inside baseball… “I wish they fired this fucking drummer”. 

I agree with Ruairi that this type of coming up through the ranks is a loss for up and comers. It was tried and true way to make people understand the ins and outs of studio technique, etiquette, professionalism. I’m glad I got to ride one of the last waves of it. I wouldn’t be here making records at this level if it weren’t for the opportunities I had at the bottom levels of the industry.

author: LAPhill
content:
To piggyback on @cian riordan 's point, there are real, tangible benefits to being quiet in the back of the room. I would love to be a fly on the wall while @BatMeckley is producing a chart-topping vocalist, or see how Cian works through a first pass of a mix for his next Grammy-winning client. I guarantee they've learned a thing or two about how to talk to sensitive, demanding, highly respected artists. And they've learned how to interpret vague feedback ("make the vocal less green")  and working with people who can't articulate what they want. These are things you can't learn by watching Youtube videos or going to school.

When I was an assistant at Remote Control, getting to sit in and see how Hans handles a note from Jerry Bruckheimer taught me more than years of music education. Watching my boss struggle for 6 months on a 10-minute cue and then sit in a meeting with grace and calm while he's being told to change everything he just spent many long nights working on. 

That's not to mention things like learning how the real pros handle file management, deliveries, deadlines, tech problems, etc.. There is so much beyond learning the gear that comes from being a good assistant. If Matt knows you're going to shut up AND have his back with lackluster cookies, he's going to let you hang in the room longer. Which means you can absorb and learn more. It's a win-win.

author: BatMeckley
content: When I was a kid I was super into magic, and had the good fortune of getting to spend a week with Penn and Teller in Atlantic City. The things that stuck out to me most was not just how continuously dedicated to their craft they were (Teller would routinely walk around with stacks of coins in his hand so he’d know exactly how it was supposed to look and feel when he was only pretending they were there) but how fiercely pragmatic they were. They’d stay on the 13th floor, walk under ladders, whistle at night… they were ferociously unsuperstitious. They weren’t counting on fate or luck, they were counting on work and the talent that stems from that. That always stuck with me.

author: BatMeckley
content: I feel like virtually all of us are dealing with mental health issues in one way or the other. For me, getting out of my own way is not over analyzing every step I take and re-litigating every mix decision to the point where I end up only releasing a handful of songs every few years.  At some point, no matter what our individual issues are, we have to log off the internet and actually make music instead of constantly talking about all of the individual reasons why we can’t. Sometimes, at least in my case, we get analysis paralysis because it’s easier than actually hitting record and just doing the damn thing. There was this meme going around last week that was something along the line of “oh hey task that only took me 15 minutes but I’ve been putting off for 5 months”. I think we can all get caught up in bathing in the 58 reasons why we can’t do something instead of just locking on to the few reasons we can, because it’s safer to live in our potential than our actual.

author: Rollmottle
content: Really tough and big question. Some broad thoughts: Expectations are unrealistic. Definition of success is probably flawed. If what you're doing is not having the desired outcome, then it demands a reexamination of what you're doing or what outcome you're aiming for. For some, that can be catastrophic because the worldview they've built, all hinges on everything lining up perfectly. In reality, that is a moonshot mostly out of their control and they need to reset expectations about timing and outcomes. If this person hasn't shored up the fundamental needs of their family or relationship or finances, then it stands to reason they aren't grounded in their reality and for me, would call into question whether they actually have put in their best efforts (best efforts to me would include integrating these factors into my equation and making sure my pursuits aren't the source of added strife for myself or others).

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Ok I'm gonna go in depth about this because I think it's FASCINATING.

The top three songs have an overlapping core fanbase that is largely unrepresented (or maligned) in popular culture: the white working class.

But none of them are really straightforward "country." 

The first song is a viral hit that seemingly comes from an authentic Appalachian kid talking about class. Despite his very explicit statements about hating political division, it has of course been wildly politicized because everything on the internet is these days.

The second song is a white male country singer covering a black lesbian female's iconic song ALSO about class. Talk about intersectionality...

The third song is the longest running solo male #1 song on the Hot 100 from the biggest star in country music (and really one of the biggest stars in the world... just, again, not covered by the current fashion of mainstream culture). It's a kinda-country-but-kinda-just-pop song co-written by the biggest country writer in history (Ashley Gorley) as well as once-rapper-and-Dr-luke-protege J Kash.

The rest of the chart is interesting too. #4 is a four year old taylor swift song that has gained traction online from her current tour so the label started pushing it as a single. 

There are two Olivia Rodrigo songs, signaling a true new superstar.

There are two songs from the Barbie soundtrack. In a "dying" movie industry currently on strike, when is the last time two songs from a movie soundtrack have been in the top 10? I dunno.

And lastly, there's only 1 trap song. The majority of these songs are people playing real instruments and writing more "classic" singer-songwriter songs. Rap music is really having a lull after a decade of dominance.

author: cian riordan
content:
"Sorry about the late night duplicate file, I did this track after six other people because I'm rushing as a team player.   I delivered as promised up front as we are all in overtime now to make it great.  *CLIENT* is happy with your work and with mine and we are all working overtime together.   Apologies also, I know there were some annoying ticks in there with some of the revised files. Still not sure why this one session did that. 

Of course I don't listen to every single file, post rendering.   We render and send 500-1000 files a month with the revisions on the 200-300 monthly songs that I do.  Team players don't ask such things on CC.  I work usually 7 days a week for 40-50 people a month, and making them happy with great masters is job #1.  Perfectionism is not a part of that process.    Software makes mistake, and that's ok.    People make mistakes and that's ok.   Mixes and masters should never aim for perfect, they should aim to connect, aim for humanity.  

Perfection is not the goal here, it's musicality and teamwork.  I'm sorry your ears suffered that horrible popping, but please, be cool. "

author: popaganda.
content: Several years ago I was on the hunt for the perfect guitar synth and landed on the VG8 from the late 90s. It was a weird box but had some amazingly responsive presets in it, nestled between random shred tones. It was awesome but I never made much music on it, and it ended up in my closet bc it was too bulky to live on my studio floor. I have to admit I felt jealous when this mk.gee wave hit and I saw 2 vg8s on the stage. I was sitting on a goldmine but I didn’t use it enough and they got there first! Been playing baritones for a long time too, fingerstyle. The lesson for me in this is that no matter what sounds are available to me, I need to be constantly re-connecting to my Why. Why do I make music? Remembering with a sense of urgency my need to express the deepest parts of myself and not just getting tossed around in a land of “shoulds,” chasing fads, second-guessing authentic ideas.

author: Zach Hughes
content: Story time. Last night me and my gf saw Janelle Monáe on her age of pleasure tour at the Ryman here in Nashville. While she was making her entrance on stage something weird happened to the sound. Loud pop, clicking, and then no signal, but seemed like the in-ears / on stage monitoring were still working. Her and the band played through the entire first song while everyone in the audience was just looking around confused. Many heads turning to the sound board. Eventually the crowd started a 'we can't hear you' chant and Janelle and the band realized what was going on. They all calmly walked off stage. Took maybe ten minutes for it all to get sorted with the sound. Then Janelle and her band proceeded to come back out redo the entire intro / first song and give maybe the greatest live performance I've ever witnessed. The show ended with a double encore. It felt like such an amazing example of class and professionalism. I got the sense that she decided, after walking off the stage the first time, that not a single person in the audience will remember this show being anything but amazing and it was. Truly undeniable. If anyone here has a chance to catch any of the remaining shows on her tour, I could not recommend it enough. 🤘

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
Ok gang, here’s something I’ve been pondering

Imagine 3 sliders that go from 0 to 10. Your goal is to set the sliders to maximize your wellbeing (in the broadest sense) and the wellbeing of those close to  you. The sliders are in effect zero sum, in that the closer you are to one end then less you have of the attribute on the other end. Let’s set the time horizon to 25 years and acknowledge the seemingly increasing pace of change in the world

Ok, the sliders …

**#1 Classics vs Cutting Edge**
On this slider 0 represents maximum knowledge in a classical sense - literature, math, mythology, fundamental accepted basics in Biology/Chemistry/Physics etc etc. 10 represents complete literacy in the cutting edge of culture, science and technology - from memes and Reddit culture to AI to synthetic biology and Blockchain etc etc 

**#2 Specialist vs Generalist**
Here 0 represents a very deep and specific knowledge of a chosen field (could be a doctor or a producer) vs 10 representing a modern Jack of all trades who knows a little bit about a lot of things 

**#3 Short Term vs Long Term**
On the slider 0 represents a disposition all about short term wins, fast plays that close out over a year vs 10 representing long investments in a given idea/field/belief system

It goes without saying that the zero sum aspect here is artificial, you can of course have some long term plays happening alongside some short term, but it’s just to get the juices flowing

author: Edward Rivera
content:
In meditative practice, there are exercises one does to mentally inhabit some bleak scenarios in order to invoke gratitude. 

Like, imagine you died yesterday…vividly…the last thing you’ll have said to your partner is the last thing you’ll have ever said, the last interaction with your dog is set in stone, as is the last thing you ate, or the last emotion you had…Yesterday was your last day on earth. 

Now imagine that you’ve been given a second chance at this life, you’ve been brought back to existence and can once again see your partner, your dog, eat food, and embody new emotions. How would that experience be / feel different ? 

And can you invoke that feeling today, right now ?

author: cian riordan
content: Eventually I caught the hang of things. I started to study the rhythms of the sessions, what order people would file in every morning. I knew the singer liked coffee one way, another guy did something else… I’d start to have that stuff ready. Instead of chumming it up with the band trying to fend off boredom while Eric was mid task, I stuck around on the couch… watching patiently. Those were the moments where he would start looping me into what he was doing, explaining his techniques. Before I knew it, I could start anticipating what he would need next. Someone mentions trying some vocals on a thing? I immediately got going on setting up a mic, getting headphones, even starting to dial in a mix on the headphone box. Percussion? Grab the trunk of junk and start laying out potential options. Once I started actually being useful, I’d be given real tasks. “Hey, do you think you could try doing a preliminary comp of this vocal?” I had been in the room for all the vocal takes, heard the discussion about approach and vibe, even made the singers coffee the right way… why not? That evolved into being trusted with recording stuff in the second studio… we were always running behind, and having me chip away at guitar tracking or re-amping was really useful. Years of this and we were a well oiled machine. I’d get looped into pre-production phone calls and meetings, he would start asking my opinion on things.. drum sounds, microphone choices.

author: LAPhill
content:
This feels like a good time to remind everyone to be careful about how much they share of their personal life on social media. I had a stalker that was a fan of a game I scored (surprisingly, the least-known thing I've ever done) start wishing my now-wife happy birthday on IG (she doesn't publicize her birthday and I would very rarely have her in posts). Then he made characters of us on his Wii. I eventually thought I had the situation cooled down, until he tagged us both, congratulating us on our engagement and knew when and where our wedding was, suggesting he might crash it.

I make a point of keeping my family out of any posts now, and don't show pictures of the area where I live, etc. etc..

author: thegreatcarsoni
content:
Awesome. I'm seeing this right now with a friend's band, so ima jump on the bandwagon here. I just took over mixing the album, which has been in progress for years. Everybody tells me the producer/band leader is this prolific asshole, constantly blowing up at people and impossible to please. The previous mixer had been mixing this thing for months/over a year and everyone was worn out/not getting results. I was really reluctant to take on the project for fear of being intimidated/failing to deliver.

I've made a point of greeting the producer at every step with clear communication, enthusiasm, and an open mind. I genuinely love the music and have made a point of letting him know how much fun it's been to work on the stuff. And, similar to your story, we were basically approved on the first track within 4 mixes and the guy seemed really really happy.

Everyone just said this guy was a hopeless asshole, but what I saw was a guy who was working so hard to bring a vision to life and just struggling to get there; self-financing, overseeing everything, etc... and it's fairly complex, hip hop and soul vibes with practically a full orchestra and 3 vocalists, so it's a lot to manage. Not trying to excuse the asshole behavior, but I see the frustration and I really wanted to highlight how much cool work he had done and that, without any fuss or needless back and forth, we would just get it where it needed to go. i tried to just think about how exciting it could be to finally hear these songs that've been bouncing around in his head actually come out of the speaker the way he imagined. We've got 7 songs almost done now and I've grown so much just from these attitude alignments i've picked up from spending time here.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Ironically, my career always seems to go best when my back is up against the wall. There’s that extra gear that panic gives me that helps me lift the car off my leg or put up with Cian or do whatever else seemed impossible  at first glance. 

Once I got out of college I spent my days selling clothes to the rich and thin before I got enough music work to leave that gig. We all go through the 40 hour week of day job and 60 hour week  of music making grind at one point of our career or another. And even when you get to quit the day job, almost everyone I know in our business has gone through what i call the “Cell service rack”, where you get a couple of gigs and your rack gets filled with cool gear and then all of the sudden it’s quiet for a few months and there gets to be less gear in those racks as you sell things to make rent. It looks like the changing meter of how much cell signal you have. There’s no shame in that game. 

For better or worse, it never ends either. I know 9 figure millionaires that are like “maybe I need to get rid of the fifth house in Aspen and free up some capital”. There’s nothing wrong with proactively taking stock of your life every once in a while and re evaluating which particular juice is worth the squeeze.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Over in the meme channel @Jeremy Klein said something about his grandpa saying “why don’t you play something that’s people actually like”. I’ve been thinking about it a lot lately, and whether or not people should work on developing their, let’s say “musical taste” as much as they develop their technical skill. 

It always breaks my heart to see music school grads know a million chords but not have any idea on how to put them together in a away that other people would enjoy. Also, who the hell is to say what qualifies as “taste”. But I’ve heard too many people argue without a sense of irony about the 5k on a song that is just at its heart completely unlistenable. 

Can taste be developed? Should it be?

author: Slow Hand
content:
---

At the end of the day I suppose I'm motivated to make music because what I want is not being represented anywhere else or I feel that I have something worth saying. I'm not aiming to be contrarian, but I want to follow the song and see where it leads me. I want to be surprised. Very often that runs counter to conventional wisdom around writing songs in "a way that people actually like."

Sometimes I feel as if I'm out here in the woods building a tiny little cathedral just for myself and a small group of people who stumbled upon it. If they wander in I'll serve them a nice meal and then send them on their way.

That said, I also don't have any expectation that I deserve to find success. I'm not going to get grumpy when my art doesn't pay off for me. I've got no illusions there. If somebody wants to make money in music they shouldn't be surprised when their Appalachian EDM doo-wop opera fails to find an audience. But if they make it I'd sure love to hear it.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
So I’m with Beckley on this. I get hired because of my taste, and I go into projects with full communication re: what is intended. 

I don’t say “this sucks I’m gonna fix it.” I say “I have some ideas about how to pull this into a really kickass place.” 

Very rarely as a mixer am I *only* mixing. Bass comes in and has no booty? Chances are I’m gonna be doing more than bx-subsynth to make it thump. Only tracked one guitar and it’s supposed to be huge? I’m gonna add some to really make that sell. 

I don’t always assume I know more than the artist, but the truth is, with the level of artists I usually work with, MOST of the time I do. 

That’s not an ego trip, it’s an understanding of the gig. It’s why people hire me. Why they ask for my help. And I treat that with deep respect. 

Last night Rauirí basically bullied me into buying RX standard for a project I was doing as a favor to a friend. I SPENT MONEY to do this thing. Because as Rauirí says: “Art matters.” 

And as Beckley ranted yesterday, I don’t think we should let something suck because we were only hired for a job. We’re not house painters who decided to fix a furnace. We’re general contractors who know how a house is built, and we fix shit that’s broken. (Bad example, but you get it.)

author: Slow Hand
content:
Fun question! I hate to complicate an already nuanced premise at the outset, but when I observe my own choices and think of each category I see myself living both sides of all three spectrums, but in different domains:

**For example:** I could be short-term in career objectives and overt achievement and long-term oriented in relationships and satisfaction. Cutting edge in creative pursuits, but classics in my personal taste. Specialist in my mode of expression, and generalist in my interests.

The more I subdivide and examine the question the more I find exceptions to everything. I am steeped in knowledge, but I seek wisdom above most things, which some philosophies would consider contradictory.

This Anais Nin quote comes to mind:

> "We do not grow absolutely, chronologically. We grow sometimes in one dimension, and not in another, unevenly. We grow partially. We are relative. We are mature in one realm, childish in another. The past, present, and future mingle and pull us backward, forward, or fix us in the present. We are made of layers, cells, constellations."

I think people are extremely lopsided and unbalanced when you start to drill down into their psyches, and that's wonderful! 

For the sake of refining this question and narrowing the scope, should we confine these three axis to only record making? Or do we want to approach it in a holistic sense?

author: cian riordan
content: I remember the first day I flew down to interview with Eric V. We were gonna just spend the weekend in the studio together and make sure the vibe was right... turns out I got roped into one of his rounds of speaker moving fuckery. The speakers were his giant UREI 813c's on top of these custom subs... very heavy... and only sitting on cinder blocks. He was deep down a Fuzzmeasure rabbit hole and we were just moving, shooting, moving, shooting, moving back, shooting, etc, etc. When we'd finally make a change to the speaker position that seemed listenable, that was always the first song he would play to hear the speakers, followed by Back in Black. It's one of those few songs that's just cemented in my brain from hearing it so much -- like when you leave an image on a TV screen and it burns in -- that's that song in my ears.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Man… this is something I wrestle with a LOT in todays climate of “send the artist home with a track! Send to the label halfway through the session!”, and honestly I just don’t do it anymore. Demo-itis such a real thing that everyone is convinced they don’t suffer from, and sending out something wrong but fast has ALWAYS fucked me in the end. I just do my best to gas light everyone into thinking it’s ok to give it a day and that perspective is one of our most powerful tools in making great music. Otherwise everyone gets hyped, listens to a song 38 times that night (to a track that won’t come out for 7 months) and convinces themselves that’s how it should sound and now comping etc become an uphill battle. I really really really hate the “this immediate comp sucks but its quick” mentality.

(This is not to be confused with tracking things quick and dirty to catch a vibe, which I’m very much for. Write drunk, edit sober)

author: Andy Lawson
content: just taking a break from a mix.. i missed a lot.. the only thing i know is the harder i have worked, the better the industry has been to me.. i started with nothing,  zero $$$$ in my bank account (i did have a photocopied version of the pro tools manual),zero skills, zero training (apart from listening to every song i could)living in a tiny share house room with no windows. but i've slogged and slogged. i've always wanted to be the best at what i do and i carry that with me daily. am i the best, absolutely not. but everyday i go into battle and try to believe i am or want to kick someone else's ass.. it's got me to the point where i bought a house and support my family. i think without that mindset i would have given up on this job years ago. Workhard, Think big, Enjoy! that's all we've got

author: Rob Domos
content:
Also think about turnaround times. You work on 15+ songs a day as an ME, you hear aberrant clicks and pops in *nearly every single one of them* 

With asking the person who sent you the files to do it, you spend your whole day emailing and managing files. It takes longer to open gmail than it does to zap the click. 

And think of the logical conclusion of asking the mixing engineer to fix the edit. They don’t have the edit, they have the comp. So then if you extend the logic they have to hit up the producer, and MAYBE the producer has to hit up the recording engineer if you really wanna “get to the source”. It’s like the meme of the producer who didn’t want to use splice because it was cheating and ended up farming sheep to get skin to make his own drumheads. Just do the fucking work. There’s no time to email back and forth about things that can be fixed immediately

I also see other people having the same experience, whether they consciously know it or not. Both watching people fail in the ways I've experienced and seeing what seems to give people a deep sense of meaning.

Feeling useful and productive and competent while connecting with other people is the current best way I can describe what is important to me. But that's pretty meta and I'm sure will evolve and refine.

author: Chad Rodgers
content:
This is a great conversation and it’s super interesting to see how culture and geography influences it.

As a Brit, the class system very much underpins life, even now (but in much different, more complex ways), so I share some of @Deleted User’s sentiments as the game is often rigged against a large portion of the populace despite their best efforts to turn things around for themselves. If only we had pure meritocracy here. Sam Fender put it really well this week with regards to the music industry so I won’t go over stony ground, you can google his thoughts which I largely relate to.

As an individual I’m horribly determined and annoyingly persistent when I have a goal in mind, as well as always balancing that with being the kindest person I can be towards others (sometimes to my detriment) and pretty much always in a headspace of bettering myself personally and professionally. This has generally been the key to many of the opportunities I’ve been given. There’s an English word for it, “nous”, which I think is similar to agency but also encompasses the notion of having “good sense”. I quite like that as it’s less about intelligence, and more about personal character. Just my two cents. As always firing off quick thoughts in a session break so I’m sorry if my take is a bit disconnected.

author: Brian Reynolds
content: So I climbed into my 2010 Volvo S80 today. And for the first time in 2025. I was going to listen to my music on the speakers. I plugged in my usb c adapter. Into the coaxial cable that runs into the center console, for that true old analog gold plated warmth. Turned the windows and volume all the way up, then as I prepared to hit play. I was blanketed with the all to familar tension. That very same feeling from when I was going to have to sit next to one of the two dudes on the middle school basketball team. Who took as their daily task, to pay homage to ancestral animal social structures, by drowning any nearby male counter part with sack taps, donkey punches, and nail whip flicks. You just preemptively flinch at the inevitable pain from their onslaught. I hit play on a mix that is -5.8 lufs at peak. No proverbial donkey punch to my thighs this time. The song didn't overload the speakers at any point. As I heard the mix in my studio. I heard it here. The things I loved about it. I loved it here. The things I was unsure about. I was equally unsure about them here. My eyes welled up a bit with fulfillment and gratitude. It took me longer and cost more than I could of ever imagined, when I started this journey. But I got here. No longer do I have to worry about translation of the mix. I can focus all my worry on the feeling and vibe of the performace. I'm willing to let my ego have this one, this mix punches with any modern mix on earth. On any system. (Sounds killer on the Meta Ray Bans. And those speakers are rutheless honest. Ive heard alot of overloaded low end mixes on em) And back to the gratitude. I wanted to thank this place. I couldn't have done it without yall. I'd still be in a pitch black room looking for a switch that felt like it was hidden on the ceiling. Now back to work! Have a great day yall!!

author: spectrummasters
content:
This completely resonates with me. The business of music doesn’t sit as well with me as the business of construction. There’s a camaraderie and kinship in physical labour on construction projects, and an embodied intelligence in that world that offsets the subjective and (for me) atomised work of hours alone mixing.

When I’m doing construction work, I’m also free to think objectively and from a distance about my audio engineering work.

Most of all, something changes for me when I’m being paid for musical “work” that I’m not entirely happy with. I’ve discussed this privately with a few folks here, and it seems the relationship between music and its commodification is problematic for more than a few of us. Simply put, it’s sometimes less enjoyable — though equally amazing — being paid for a passion.

I couldn’t recommend a construction or skilled trade career enough. It’s incredibly flexible and offers a tonic to music careers: you know you can walk onto a site tomorrow and get paid quickly and well. It’s always going to be around, and in my case, the certifications allow me to consider migrating to most economies globally as a skilled worker.

Construction allows me to be my own patron for my musical endeavours, and that feels really good.

I’d love to see a bigger debate here about how working in the upper echelons of the music industry feels long term — challenges, payoffs, economics, job security, retirement, healthcare, family life versus work life, and a world where socialising is networking.

Construction is a simpler engagement: competency, find a solution, do the work, go home.

I came across @cian riordan discussing becoming a fireman on Conversations, and much of what you said, Cian, is exactly what I get from construction.

I love how for you, though — instead of the firehouse bell calling, it was multiple Grammys!

author: cian riordan
content: On this note, I'll say that I LOVE these drives. My workflow in the past has basically been to buy a new 1GB SSD drive every few projects. When I had my setup on a laptop, this allowed me to always have access to projects I was working on the go (printing stems on the couch while watching TV? Yes please). In addition to using these SSDs, I'd always keep local backups with 'Sync Folders Pro' -- RIP Sync X -- on a cheaper, larger capacity USB drive. Being an anxious data archiver, I also signed up for Backblaze a few years ago as a cloud solution in case my studio burns down. Its a really great service, but the caveat they have with your drives is you *can* back up externals, they just need to be connected to your computer every 30 days. So I bought this monster USB3 hub and just had all of these fucking SSDs connected to my computer whenever it was setup at my studio. It worked fine for a few years, but I ran out of space again a few weeks ago and decided to futureproof mysetup a little bit. I ended up getting a thunderbolt Drobo. That way, I could have redundant storage for archived projects (which also gets uploaded to backblaze) but without having 16 drives on my desktop. Now I just have two of those samsung SSDs -- one work, and one as a backup. They run lightning fast and I get to keep having local backups in case I fuck the dog moving files around after a few glasses of wine. Then, when I run out of space, I just offload onto the Drobo and it's locally redundant, and also backed up on the cloud. Thank you for coming to my TED talk.

author: Deleted User
content:
I don’t think there is a single person that was smartest or wisest. People all have different areas they are smart in, or wise in. The most intuitive, most empathetic, most knowledgeable (in ____), etc

I don’t really know what smart means, but people that appear smart are very nuanced about the things they don’t know or understand. They can articulate what they know, they can put things together with intuition, they can develop ideas and concepts without being fed one.

My observations of people with great wisdom seem to be the people who spend great deal of time processing emotions and self reflection. And they share what they learn from the place of empathy. 

I had a guitar teacher, he never gave me “real answers” to my questions. He always told me at the end of his version of guidance and helpful tools or some joke (again not an answer)“you’ll find the answers to any questions inside you”. Which was a wtf moment to me because I wanted the answer right then and there- but I realized often times a lot of things that are not factual cannot be answered by anyone but me because even if anyone gave their own version of answer it would not be relevant to me or I wouldn’t understand any of it unless I can make sense of things myself. That was one of the greatest and live changing advice I have received in life.

author: Iwan Morgan
content: So, I teach part time at undergraduate level in the UK, and the main complaint most of my students that have come from earlier music tech education is that they have been told things, or lectured at passively but not been able to get their hands on the equipment or be in real or close to real experiences.  In my teaching I get them active early in the process.  Get them excited by the process, find out if there are any players in the group.  Get thme to jam, let the others engineer.  Rotate roles frequently.  Teach them fundamentals while they work.  Some people spend 3 hours teaching them how to coil a cable, and while this is important I always work it into a real environment.  Always, always ask what their favourite songs are and relate the teaching to that.  Got a room full of EDM kids? Get them to engineer a band tracking, then get them to deconstruct and remixit the next week using a DAW.  In doing this they'll learn far more and you can tailor specific elements as you go.

author: LAPhill
content:
The refresh rate on most TVs is slower than on a monitor, so you'll feel more latency. Even ones that do the hyper-real sports setting (motion smoothing) to display 120-240Hz will actually introduce MORE latency for that processing. 

If you can find a TV with a game mode, that's typically low-latency and you'd likely be fine.

author: cy (sigh)
content:
only point I disagree with is music (art) not being essential.  and I think in a lot of ways ppl not seeing it as so is a key problem overall. 

no its not food but we're so used to having access to some form of it (good or bad, to our taste or not) that I think it gets undervalued overall. (obviously outliers exist)

I've literally seen art save lives. mental and emotional health is a necessity and music (even sound in general) I find is a key element. 

a ridiculous amount of cultures (read:indigenous) placed immense value on the art in their culture..often as part of their spiritual beliefs. even colonists co-opted and modified songs to allow conquests though culture more easily.

I think accessibility makes us think art isn't a necessity. it is. a lot of us would probably have lost our minds at this point (and I've seen that happen) if we didn't have it to lean on for various aspects. I'm not saying it should be #1 priority but I do think the inherent value we (the world) give art can directly affect how we value other things 

it's also the source of community and support for a lot of people and we are community based beings at our core  (though we can seperate to some extent).

the mindset things is also v interesting. being from Haiti I see American payment mindsets and European (a lot of both out there) and there's also more traditional ones that are more based in community - usually ones that survived colonialism to some extent. see:taino culture (mostly survived in pr, almost non existent in the other islands now). those are more focused on everyone getting there part fairly. the work is for the community not for yourself. while juxtaposition w the other mindset has flipped some folks' wayof working a lot of them are fine as is.

there's  o clear solution to the value of art thing. diff fields and different positions have to find ways of presenting value but I see that as a Consequence of the mentality we've adopted not a solution

author: BatMeckley
content:
So, statistically this gig is one of the hardest ways to make a living in todays economy. If the kid doesn’t want it bad enough to have an initial “fuck you, I can’t imagine doing anything else this is MY LIFE” response, they’re simply not cut out for today’s realities. Too many people leading too shitty of a life because a family member gave them the “you can do it!” speech because you’re “supposed to be supportive of family even without cause”. It’s like sending them off to war with a tennis racket, and to me that’s ultimately cruel. 

So the next step is on the kid. If they come back 6 months later and are like “hey I know you said not to, but i hit YouTube and figured some stuff out and here’s 30 tracks I got here that someone other than my mom or girlfriend says is pretty cool” THEN I’m all in, and matching their effort, and providing them every opportunity to grow and succeed. But if you need constant validation you’re doing the right thing, and you can’t fight through the first (or tenth) wave of people telling you not to do this, you REALLY don’t belong in this game. It’s way too much work for way too little reward unless the work IS the reward.

author: Rob Domos
content:
I have a scalding hot take that the “indie girl” voice isn’t a fad and came about because it’s the optimal way to sing for the medium. 

Think of how opera doesn’t sound like human speech. That alien sound came about because extremely loose muscles create far less sympathetic intermodulation which sounds cleaner. It’s the same as how a speaker makes your desk vibrate and create out of time interference pattern distortions. Muscle tension creates hard surfaces that do the same when singing and opera singers obsess over undoing this. This is a big reason why so many of your favorite vocalists are opioid and benzo addicts. It’s not just culture. Downers are performance enhancing here. (Please don’t get any ideas artists) 

The modern pop voice is just maintaining that exaggerated opera looseness but with adaptations for the modern medium: English diphthongs instead of Latin ones, way less air in their lungs because the target is a foot from their mouth instead of 50 feet, and softened fricatives because a capsule right in front of the mouth harshly exaggerates fricatives. 

From a physics perspective it’s the perfectly optimized way to sing in 2024. You may not like it, but this is what peak performance sounds like

author: BatMeckley
content:
In all this, i think it’s important to not conflate “new” with “good” or even “better”. Those kind of classifications are best done with a wider lens. 

So often i see an artist shelf the better song for the newer song because it feels fresh to them.

Also important for us to remember that a lot of the classics that we think of as old were the absolute bleeding edge tech of their time (MJ, Hendrix, Dylan, Beatles). Things can be new and exciting and genre pushing and be awesome. But I still think it’s the song underneath that has to work and move people. I have many friends that are absolutely crushing with what I consider TikTok artists that are doing incredibly well with 15 second clips that I have a hard time believing will matter in 6 months let alone 6 years.

author: Zach Hughes
content:
Sure. I pulled this from the article I was reading:

"Building 20 became a strange, chaotic domain, full of groups who had been thrown together by chance and who knew little about one another’s work. And yet, by the time it was finally demolished, in 1998, Building 20 had become a legend of innovation, widely regarded as one of the most creative spaces in the world. In the postwar decades, scientists working there pioneered a stunning list of breakthroughs, from advances in high-speed photography to the development of the physics behind microwaves. Building 20 served as an incubator for the Bose Corporation. It gave rise to the first video game and to Chomskyan linguistics. Stewart Brand, in his study “How Buildings Learn,” cites Building 20 as an example of a “Low Road” structure, a type of space that is unusually creative because it is so unwanted and underdesigned. (Another example is the Silicon Valley garage.) As a result, scientists in Building 20 felt free to remake their rooms, customizing the structure to fit their needs. Walls were torn down without permission; equipment was stored in the courtyards and bolted to the roof. When Jerrold Zacharias was developing the first atomic clock, working in Building 20, he removed two floors in his lab to make room for a three-story metal cylinder."

author: itaylerner
content: Been with my partner for 9 years and ….yes. lol. This resonates a lot and there’s So much to unpack! Here’s my experience- user experience will vary. The biggest unlocks for me have been not seeing her frustration or lack of enthusiasm as an inconvenient issue that I have to deal with, but rather as a valid fear and a hurt that someone I love is asking for support with. When I get busy and she gets mad, it’s because, historically, my business and fun big opportunities have meant she was going to have a lot of domestic labor and an overwhelming amount of loneliness to deal with. So now when I have a busy time coming up, I meal prep beforehand, I clean the house beforehand, I acknowledge that it’s hard for her, I express tons of gratitude, and I always plan to block out some dedicated alone time for us afterwards. Anything to show that I understand the concessions that she’s making and make my own big efforts to foresee what that means from her and minimize the negative consequences it could have. Maybe even make it something we can both look forward to. Not sure if that’s relevant at all for your circumstances but that’s some of the stuff that’s helped my home life become much more peaceful.

author: cian riordan
content: I go back and forth. I finally got a decent turntable setup in the studio… calibrated, aligned, etc… and it was very interesting listening to analog and digital back to back. Most records I prefer the clarity and depth of digital, but there were a few (mostly from the 80s) where the analog pressing surpassed the digital. I still think the medium is a net positive in terms of music enjoyment and the collective industry, but I’ve moved beyond touting it as some sort of superior listening format. It’s just not. I remember mastering several records with Doug Sax and he would always joke with me saying, “you know there’s a better medium, right? Sounds better, is cheaper, etc”. Despite being the master, he understood how it’s evolved and had a sense of humor about it.

author: spectrummasters
content: Coming back on this ,bit corny but this is my testament to the value of rap. I’ve taken the summer to work back on a construction site to get away from screens and endless inside days , get some vitamin d and all that . There’s this kid who is on as a labourer . He’s just pushing dust around all day with a broom and carrying whatever crap the supervisors tell him to move  just to keep him busy . He found out I mix and produce and has been sending me his songs and is waiting for me to give him the nod and set up a tracking session . He’s pretty good and really young . Maybe he could be something . Dunno . But I do know when I walk past him on site looking bored as fuck and wondering why he’s even here …..he’s just writing bars in his head , cause he spits them to me when we are done and all heading home . This sounds corny but it’s so weird being an engineer and having all the skill and gear required to turn someone’s vision into a reality . In the world of music you become their best friend and confidante . Those threesome stories lol , sometimes they get replaced with something deeper …..stories about absent parents and betrayals by friends and lovers . These things are rarely discussed between men here , vulnerability is a weakness …..so it’s crazy how many times I’ve been tracking and thought ……damn this is deep, im a part of a therapeutic process . Or just some made up shit about menages 😂. I will record this kid though . He needs it

author: Slow Hand
content:
12 years ago I acquired two sets of custom-molded earplugs from an audiologist and they've paid for themselves a dozen times over. Easily.

I can't advocate for them enough. They're extremely comfortable, have an even frequency reduction of -15dB, and are easy to clean. I use them at shows, studios, planes, on construction sites, and during noisy sleeping environments. 

They're in my bag at all times. Y'all owe it to yourselves to get a pair. Worth every penny.

author: Jeremy Klein
content:
I moved here 2 years ago with a bunch of savings and making very little money in music. It took me about a year to pull in enough income from mixing and spotify streams where I could stop living off savings and only on music income. 

But, It IS so expensive to live here, and I like to do things. typical night out is like $80 after drinks and ubers. Gas is $80. An egg sandwich is $16 lol. The constant worrying of if i was going to make enough that month got to me, so of a couple months ago, I returned to a freelance software engineering gig 3 days a week. Never been happier. A _lot_ of people in LA are doing the same: _side hustles are your friend_ . 

Another thing i'd add is when you first move here, try to combine your studio and living expenses. Studio spots here start at like $1800 a month and go up from there. I live in a beautiful house in silverlake with roommates where I have a room, my own bathroom, _and my own studio_ in the furnished garage for $1300. Try to get something like that.

@cian riordan shows up. Sporting an outrageous mustache and atrocious accent he completes the interview. Miraculously it works. People love him. The mix requests start coming in. Collectively, the server decides to push our luck a little further than we ought to.

The influx of mix requests are more than Cian can complete himself, so they start getting passed off to server members to mix. The money is flowing. Serban's album credits for 2022 shoot through the roof. The perks start going to everyone's head.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Stereo. I tried out some Atmos headphone mixes at an Apple store kiosk a while ago because I was curious. I can't say that it had much of an effect on me. Maybe I need to live with them for longer and get used to it.

Last week was the first time that I was able to sit in front of an Atmos setup that was meant for music (aka: not in a movie theater) and really get the full musical experience. In fact, I got to sit in front of *three* different Atmos rigs in three different (treated) rooms that evening and two of them were undoubtedly set up as good as they could have possibly been (One was a PMC showroom and the other built and tuned with their input). While the speakers themselves were impressive and very capable, the actual experience felt pretty disjointed. There was a pronounced feeling of phasi-ness that I didn't like.

It was great hearing these records on a rig that probably cost $250k, but my big takeaway was that they felt disjointed and odd. Even when sitting in the sweet spot.

Perhaps my opinion will change with more exposure, but I'm not yet convinced that it's worth the time and effort. I will add, though, that half the mixes we heard were up-mixed from old stereo recordings with minimal track counts and only two of them were modern productions.

author: Rollmottle
content: haha...I'm a UX designer by trade and would have approached this problem differently. i don't know that we actually have a problem where we need a more structured and rigid way of soliciting feedback on music. maybe in certain high volume scenarios, i can see the use case. for mixing and mastering, putting an interface in front of somebody that makes a user think "oh shit, i can comment down to the every last second!" seems ripe for 1. woodshedding and focusing on things that in any other listening context wouldn't matter 2. makes me think I *have* to say something. as my client, i'd much rather you take the music wherever you feel most comfortable in whatever way you want to consume and just listen and then communicate back to me however you'd like without the pressure of a UI that might be unnatural to that workflow in front of you. it's a philosophical thing i suppose...i never want to add friction to your natural way of thinking about something, especially your own music.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Way. It was an outrageously fun period of my life.

The band started as a joke - an Irish colloquialism for “make out with” is “shift”, so we thought it’d be funny to be an Irish KISS cover band called SHIFT.

We realised KISS only have three good songs though, so we added Def Leppard, Van Halen, Motley Crüe… fairly quickly we became a popular wedding band and it financed the endless money suck of trying to “make it” with the original band I was playing with.

Ricky Starship, Van Hammer, Chad Sexington, and Sene Gimmons there are all still my (Rowdy Ronny Smiles) closest friends.

author: Barbara
content:
I have to let you know my first experience with this. Been working on an album that I recorded one year ago. Recording took us 7 days and they still needed to add synths and bass fot some of the songs after that (side note: the production wasn't finished by the time we tracked, so I edited everything I had - 10 songs, none of them with less than 5 minutes. It was the band's first time in the studio, also, and had to edit lots of drums and bass stuff). After doing a first pass, I sent them the multitracks they asked for, to track the rest of their stuff with their producer (a colleague of mine). The next 8 months were spent waiting on their files to start mixing (this was supposed to last 1/2 months, max). When I finally got the files, you have no ideia how messy the project turned out (track names, bounce mistakes, ultrapocessed tracks with artifacts - even the ones we've tracked at the studio before, audible edit points,... all you can imagine going wrong at this point), so it took me a bunch of time to organize everything in a way that I could work with what I've got (going back and forth asking the producer for some files that didn't even get to me or asking if there was the possibility to get some of the tracks dry, without processing or fx - keep this in mind).

Needless to say, when I was ready to start mixing, I was already overwhelmed and tired of it, and I knew I still had a long way to go...

First version took me probably too long to get right (2 months, approx., working on other projects that got scheduled on those 8 months) and I've sent it before I went on a few days vacation.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Came across a stimulating quote recently that I thought was illuminating. The person said the following (paraphrasing):

> "The definition of a nerd is someone who thinks conversation is for peer-reviewing ideas. What do non-nerds think it's for? Negotiating alignment."

Simply based on the way I've framed this question, it's probably pretty clear that I belong to the "peer-reviewing ideas" school of thought (mostly). I love to throw stuff out there, even if I don't believe it. I want to stress test it.

I can certainly appreciate conversation as a tool for aligning people on a belief or course of action, but it's got me wondering about how many of us are playing completely different games when we're having a conversation, and what other games are there? Do y'all think differently?

author: Slow Hand
content:
People who don't win Grammys will never be losers unless their goal was to compete and win a Grammy. Then they're losers by their own competitive standard, and losing is all part of the game.

Everyone else can only stand to gain by being nominated. The act of being nominated is a reward in it's own right. It's a net positive and validating moment for anybody's career. While it may be disappointing not to win, hopefully they'll never feel that they're losers for failing to win something that they didn't ask for.

This is all to say that it's a matter of mindset. If you're not actively trying to win a Grammy, then a loss shouldn't be construed as some demeaning thing and the nomination is still a net positive. I don't think it's on the Grammys to regulate people's emotional state.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I've never considered myself someone who's had substance issues of any kind (thankfully). I'm approaching the end of a self-imposed 3 month break from alcohol and as I near the finish line I don't feel as if I'm in any hurry to return to where I was.

I've been a casual drinker for over 15 years and recently have found that even 1-2 drinks the night before were leaving me feeling like shit in the morning, so I opted to remove them from the equation and see how I felt after my trial period.

No surprise, but it's been a positive one. I'll still drink on occasion, but it feels great not defaulting to that habit. It's probably been the confluence of several factors in my life, but right now I feel as good as I've ever been. I feel present and in-tune with the world around me and I think I'd be far less effective if I hadn't taken this break.

author: Rollmottle
content:
Letting yourself unplug and giving yourself the grace to do it guilt-free takes practice. This is something that has continually dogged me throughout my life. My problem solving brain is always on and it's hard to turn it off. It's really easy to fall into one's work and feel guilty or bad when you're not working even though you should be or have to be. Gotta just accept and walk away and not beat yourself up for needing to be unproductive. The bigger picture frame is a day or 3 or 10 of doing "nothing" is going to be a bigger payoff in the long run than in the short term trying to superhero through it half-in and potentially doing shitty work which could have compounding unintended long-term effects. 

Get high, have a drink, go for a walk, get out of town, watch a show, cook a meal...do nothing.

author: spectrummasters
content: Hi, yes so......within the genres I’m most involved in currently hip/hop , drill and rnb the samples we choose and the patterns we create for these samples are all “trendy “ in a sense that it’s important in our genres to be seeking to present new sounds and patterns that others catch onto . This would be being the new wave . It’s vital in uk street music to be a creator of the wave / up on the new wave .....to garner attention . This dates back to jungle....where the producer/engineers were pioneering completely new sounds and rhythms via sampler technology midi and sampled breakbeats (amen , funky drummer etc ) . When a snare backbeat transitions from the use of a snare to instead a rimshot......or a particular clap sample.....and that track blows up, the wave moves . If you a year later release a track with the old snare on the backbeat instead of the rim .....that’s dated . The same goes for the other percussions, the bass sounds (eg 808 / Moog in intro/bridge combi ) .....and the patterns . So this is why In twelve months most of the productions these artists are dithering over , will be out of date. It’s just silly imo. Music is moving so fast and is ultimately so disposable at the mo holding onto it like some sort of special Tolkien esque ring is really just a vanity. Personally I’d venture this is also the essence of what makes pop music trends discernible . That’s just my opinion tho with respect to these genres. My overall goal is to record and mix work like rumours. Smokey , earthy and nourishing . A bit like @popaganda.  s last work .🙏🏼

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Bear in mind also that the references are UK specific, and this is a work in progress.


- A Minimum Rate Card (a reference for minimum per-hour and per-day rates, according to role and project budget, with additional minimum fees for equipment rental). As an example, see the current BECTU Production Sound rate card https://members.bectu.org.uk/filegrab/bectu-production-sound-rates-nov-2021-final.pdf?ref=2606

- Standardised working hours and breaks

- Minimum time off between working days, with breaches (“overnight infringement”) incurring additional fees for freelancers, or days-off in lieu for contracted workers

- Guaranteed minimum rates of overtime pay

- Special rates of pay for bank holidays

- An enforced system to credit all workers for their contributions – runners, assistants, ops, and engineers (think the credits at the end of a movie)

- Special rates of pay for weekends [Sunday bonus rates (but not Saturdays) are common in theatre. Some other industries pay weekends at time-and-a-half]

- Special rates of pay for planned overnight sessions [This is also common in theatre, film and tv, enforced by BECTU in those instances]

author: spectrummasters
content: It feels like a bit of an honour when someone’s paying me for anything musical i do. I defo dont do it for the money, never have. When i was at uni i used to run the rehearsal rooms attached to a pro recording studio (claim to fame ...wet wet wet’s all around me lol)...so i could just sit in on the studio sessions once I’d booked in the practice bands in the other part of the building. . After uni I’d do stage management/engineer assisting  at local venues in bristol volunterrring just to get experience......i did the wailers, ozomatli, pharcyde.....tons of two tone ska....while volunteering in dj workshops for local kids.....and up to today i always do some free stuff for rappers and singers in my area...because (and this is where i think mainstream often misunderstand rap lyrics).....it helps youngers express themselves and get shit off their chest....and off the streets.....and focuses their minds on ambition and change. In this way i think music is about grace....and as you said @BatMeckley  ...magic. What it brings into peoples lives and how it affects lives. The money i can take it or leave it....but the music i have to have. The most enriching musical experiences i can look back on have nothing to do with how much money was transacted

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Sure! But probably not for the reasons many would think, it’s not just about having a lot of low end, but it’s character and how it sits and feels:

1. Bad For Me by Stacy Ryan (Castelli mix/Becker master) — so much lows to be for this type of vibe, and like .05 db more in 200ish area would be too much. LOVE how it sits on the edge there, but I’m a big Jon fan so no surprise

2. Disco Break 2 by Brasstracks (Castelli Mix/Becker master) — crazy good and deep transients with a wonderfully articulate but big low end. Quite dynamic, maybe slightly on the edge there so great to study translation to streaming. Recommended to me by the wonderful @YianniAP 

3. 30 for 30 - T Shyne. Not quite sure who mixed it, but I actually DON’T like the lows, or really the overall mix that much as an engineer but there is such a wonderful energy to me, this thing played before a sports game or a workout is it. So I have it here to remind myself that not everything has to be amazing sonically to feel great. Actually don’t like the low end on this at all, but the record still hits for me. Told @alexstein this was on the warm up list…he was like “why??” haha. Because I think my job is to love records for what they are and understand why they work, hopefully be more of themselves, not some target curve that’s ideal to me. and this is a great example of something like that

Also just have to mention that “Tattoos” by Georgia Webster is on there…probably my favorite vocal I’ve ever heard. @YianniAP mix Nathan master, I cannot look away from the vocal and the mid density is perfection to me
