author: Slow Hand
content:
Yeah, it rankles. It seems to de-personalize the creative pursuit, strip it of it's vibrancy, and reduce it to a single word for use in conversations about commerce.

However, I wonder what the alternative would be.

I suppose they could adopt some ungainly acronym (ala LGBTQ+) that tries to encapsulate writers, musicians, illustrators, filmmakers, pornographers, podcasters, influencers (ugh), streamers, photographers, and game developers. (WMIFPPISPG?)

Instead of creator, I propose the term *Financially Aspirational Maker* (FAM). 
/s

**Edit:** Actually, I like the sound of Financially Aspirational *Generator* better (more cheeky), but out of respect for human decency I'm going to leave that acronym unspoken 😄.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
As a former (what I would call pretty high level) athlete, I actually think about this thing very intently with regards to working on records and draw from things from the past life. Mine is more focused on how I want to hear (or rather deeply understand how I'm hearing) every day as close to consistent as possible, given we are human of course.

My 2 cents (which of course is just my experience): 

Some sort of routine before you work. Mine is that I wake up almost exactly at the same time every day, will work out at similar times (if possible), literally eat the same thing basically every day before during the work day, coffee at similar times, have  the same routine when I sit down to start work. Not all of that is possible or useful for everyone, but I think we can all find something that would focus us in a way that's useful and ablet to be put into practice for us.

Truly I find it helps a lot. We are physical beings, how our systems and bodies interact can definitely matter, especially in our ability to be available to the music.

That said, sometimes things happen and you gotta go. You will be tired, stressed, whatever. You have to do excellent work under those conditions too, it might be the most important skill if we are being honest about making a career of this. So training specifically for when you feel rough is definitely something I personally find important.  Which is where physically training helps, it's a way to force yourself into (fake) adversity and train response

@Slow Hand I know you know all this, just my experience

author: spectrummasters
content:
I alternate between phases of 7am - 6pm construction work . V rigid schedule with v . Structured reliable pay. This is easy for my family life (good pay , evenings and weekends free ) 
…..and then an extended phase of writing , recording and mixing folks I work with . 
This phase always feels slightly slacker to me , I know it isn’t but hard to shake off . It comes from not being on a firms payroll with no fixed schedule nor income . Have four young children and a music lawyer Mrs so my dependants and my other half do weigh on my mind when I’m doing creative me . 
I will say a couple years ago I lost a hard drive of projects I’d written and produced over a year . During that year I’d spent hours away from my newborn and my other children recording and pouring everything into the work . Once it all disappeared into the digital ether the only thing I really missed was the time I’d not spent with my children , not the lost projects . Defo shaped my perspective moving forwards . I see being creative as essential but not the ultimate priority now and I think that’s good for my fam

author: Slow Hand
content:
This is an issue that the artist and producer should be resolving amongst themselves. It's not yours to mediate.

By telling you to exclude the producer the artist is externalizing the problem to you and pulling you into the disagreement between them.

By sidebar-ing with the producer (as was suggested elsewhere) you're expanding the complexity of the communications between all three parties. Now you're the go-between for everyone. That's messy.

Moreso than that, talking to the producer on the side and updating them on what's going on may feel like a betrayal by you from the artist's perspective, because they clearly don't want the producer to know.

I would seek to steer them both towards some version of "I can't be the one to solve this for either of you, and you need to resolve it amongst yourselves."

author: Deleted User
content: recognizing if my reaction is coming from my taste or objective observation is another thing that guides me when I give feedback to others. I do mention my personal reactions but I try to be clear that it is my personal reaction not a real observation. But it’s very difficult, I’ve read from a book “nonviolent communication” once that the highest form of intelligence is making observations without making judgements. And I confuse these things often too. So I think it is a skill that can be applied to providing feedback. I also find it helpful to offer choices as feedback. For example, if (intention) is what you are going for trying (suggestion) may work well. But if (a different angle) is what you are going for, (a different suggestion) can be another thing you can try. This, I do more often as a producer. As casual feedback, I don’t do this very often other than people I am close to.

author: Zakhiggins
content:
Setting an achievable long term exercise goal and making a plan on how you'll get there is a major key for getting into and keeping you exercising. And doing stuff that isn't boring too.
I've always found doing a little often is way more valuable than doing 1 really intense workout here and there. (this is relevant for progression in any kind of physical activity too, and progression matters because its what will keep you interested long term)
Eating well and sleeping enough is also a major key. I know this is really simple stuff but If you make a habit of these things and stay consistent, you'll notice drastic improvements in physical and mental health, and you won't ever feel like exercise is a chore.

If there's one topic that I actually know a lot about, even down to a deep scientific level, it'd be this sorta stuff, so feel free to hmu with any qs whenever lol

author: chadwahlbrink
content:
> “Some animals, such as toothed whales, can generate sound levels that, if produced in the air, would be equivalent to a large-bore firearm being discharged a few inches from your ear. 
> But, pound for pound, one of the loudest organisms in the animal kingdom is, oddly enough, the inch-and-a-half-long snapping shrimp. Many snorkelers and scuba divers are familiar with this marine sound, since the crustacean appears along most ocean shorelines and reefs, and in estuaries. It has a staticlike sound that permeates the entire underwater region, and it generates a signal with its large claw that can meet or exceed 200 dB underwater—a sound-pressure level equivalent to around 165 dB in air. With every 6 dB change representing a doubling or halving of intensity, we can compare the shrimp output to a symphony orchestra, which may generate loud moments peaking around 110 dBA. Indeed, the lowly, unsophisticated shrimp will not be outdone even by the Grateful Dead, a rock group whose concerts have been measured at levels exceeding 130 dB. Get this, Deadheads: the shrimp is louder by close to a factor of five—all that without a huge stack of stage speakers!”

author: ALXCPH
content:
I Think people lift their noses at shows like these, not to look Down on contestants. But more so the premis of the show.  The over production, the false reactions, the comments from the hosts/judges. The whole over-dramatisation that a lot of us can see right through. Also the fact that it is a contest because of “music ain’t a contest dude, it’s art✌️”. 

I think that the comparison to McDonalds is good, not because it is fast food or “low quality” or whatever, but because it’s not a food business. It’s a real estate business that uses food as a by-product(you know what I mean). These programs are just “reality” shows using music as a by product.

Sure there are some good meals, but I’m sure some chefs would up their nose at people who think McDonald’s defines the culinary experience as a whole. The same way a lot of Music people May feel misinterpreted by people who’s only intake of music is through these programs. 


Sorry rant over, was just a long stream of thought that came as I wrote it 😅 

My fave to come out of one of those programs is probably Harry Styles. He keeps impressing the further he goes in his career! 😇

author: Slow Hand
content:
It's funny how often old aphorisms get turned around and stripped of their original meaning.

The saying "You can't have your cake and eat it too" always frustrated me because it doesn't make any sense. So one day I looked it up and it turns out that the original saying is actually "You can't *eat* your cake and have it too." which is far more coherent.

author: Rollmottle
content: as a fellow recovering Catholic, that music is imprinted in my DNA....Sister Tang was our music teacher and would teach us singing and dancing and would bring in Cure records and other 80s bangers for us to listen to and do dance routines to. the biggest shocker was every year at a single Christmas mass when our quiet little music teacher would do a solo vocal performance of Silent Night accompanied only by an organist and the church's reverb. what came out of her was earth-shatteringly stunning, bigger than life and visceral. you could hear a pin drop when she was through and the priest would just sit in that silence for an extra beat. one of my most vivid musical memories.

author: Bonati12461
content: And sorry to bang on about this, but something that is critical to the audio quality on a record that is way out of most pro-audio people’s view is the state of the cutting lathe being used to do the master cut. Many people working in audio have never even seen such a machine. They are complicated - there are techs who work on consoles who won’t touch cutting lathes. IMO the best lathes were made by Neumann in the 70s/early 80s, and that was a long time ago. You have a TON of electronics and mechanics that need to be refurbished / restored to get the lathe to make some great cuts. Some engineers are cutting on some nicely restored systems and some are using some OLD stuff which should have been pulled for maintenance decades ago. Imagine if 50% of the records today were mastered on 50 year old loudspeakers with blown drivers and mismatched crossovers. We might notice.

author: BatMeckley
content: I very much do actually. We recorded that album at Sacred Heart Church in Duluth, a beautiful decommissioned church. There is a huge difference between dialing in a cathedral reverb and actually putting a mic in the back of a church. HOWEVER, that intro guitar tone, and only that intro guitar tone, was a direct mic on a tweed combo run through Audio Ease’s Speakerphone plugin 😂. Sometimes fake works better than real. I needed the contrast between the intro, where he could bring it down to, and then where he was going by the end. That plug-in gave me the different color that sounded big, but didn’t ruin the surprise of where the song was going to end up

author: spectrummasters
content: @bobby k So way waaaaay back in the uk , when drum and bass and dubstep (and garage ) didn’t exist yet there were a few london based producers scattered about manipulating breakbeats like james browns funky drummer drum break , the amen drum break from the Winston brothers and the apache drum break . England had had breakbeat hardcore for a few years already (eg . Early early prodigy ) and then the British carribean community and others familiar with reggae and particularly the early 90s ragga scene in Jamaica , started fusing ragga acapellas and dub bass line motifs with hardcore ‘s drum breaks . This was pioneering and was referred to as future sounds  , back then the mode was established for U.K. street music producers to value “futuristic “ aka pioneering / unheard of / new sounds and rhythms .

author: Jonathan Jetter
content: I embrace the occasional lack of focus. I don't necessarily have to work a long full day to stay on track. I do have to stay sufficiently attuned to when I'm in the zone to do my best work. And then a few hours of hard work in that zone is often more productive than many hours of my B+ game. I let my mind wander when it wanders. I go for walks, or watch Netflix, or read. author: masteredbyjack
content:
Catching up here, not sure how relevant but my best friend runs a very successful video business he built from scratch, is a mentor in a way (though he knows 0 about music).

One of his most enduring quotes to me is: “What you’re getting paid today is for your work a year ago (or x years, it can work for any duration)”

Essentially, crush everything in front of you and the money/growth will come with time, it takes time to catch up. But you have to fully, and totally, commit in an industry such as this to really do it. And it probably will feel like you’re giving much more than you’re getting in the moment, but in the end it balances

Then again, the age old Ruairi-ism of thinking about the ambition matters too. Mine is almost maximally high, it is how I am. Someone who wants to make a comfortable living and work on records every day would maybe make very different moves or sacrifices based on this (neither is right or wrong)

author: masteredbyjack
content: I really think hope is essential to throwing yourself into something entirely. And that, more than anything, seems like its a huge key to success. Of course the world is so complicated it is impossible to generalize, but I've never seen a human throw themselves 1000% at something with hope and great intentions and not be "successful". It almost never looks like what you think at the outset, perhaps wildy different, but doors almost magically seem to open when the commitment is made to continue, if you are willing to see them

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Love this discussion. All great points — my gut says there is a distinction between the producer/engineer role here and the artist. The learn grammar, be able to adjust and deliver on a vision/etc all lend themselves to being amazing technically and doing the reps to have those skills. Very useful on the service side

But some artists just have it like that. It’s irrelevant, they just crush stuff and have a vision. Pure talent. And probably the rarest ones have both sides and are aware of it. Then you’re truly dangerous

Have seen this with some football guys I’ve played with — I was one of the ones who studied the game deeply and could improve. But other guys showed up on day one, knew absolutely nothing but could just ball. Their knowledge of the game didn’t even matter, they could just ball on instinct. Of course they worked hard, but there was a different level of talent there. And look at them now, cashing checks in the NFL

author: popthetrunk
content: On a Mac Pro 2019 you get 64 pcie lanes, slots 1 and 3 each get their own 16 lanes. These do not count towards pool allocation. Your slot 3 is empty, I’d start there. Assuming graphics card is slot 1, put your afterburner in slot 3. The other slots share 32 lanes, 16 between each pool, the second pool being shared with thunderbolt peripherals. So if you configure manually, you wanna leave some headroom in pool b.

author: sixmissing
content:
Alrighty, here’s a Day 1 update: removed the afterburner card and presto, the usage went down on the pool allocation. 
I experimented with removing the Ultra Studio from Thunderbolt and the usage went down to 75% even with the monitors and 3 Apollos. So it’s seeming like i could help myself by getting a deck link and freeing up the TB. 

As for the OWC drive, I’m going to try popping it into Slot 3 and seeing what happens. On another support group I’m in, a person said they stepped from an 8M2 to a 4M2 and it solved their problems. I suppose there are too many variables there to draw a solid conclusion. 

Forging ahead as planned. Thanks so much for all the help/support/thoughts. Really means a lot.

author: sixmissing
content:
Alright! Back with another update. Moved OWC 8M2 to Slot 3, installed a Blackmagic Decklink card, removed Ultrastudio from Thunderbolt and placed second monitor on its own Thunderbolt bus and wow...it's like it's a new machine. 

Truthfully, I'm feeling the lag within Davinci now that the Afterburner card is gone which is honestly surprising. But it's much preferrable to having PT/Ableton hang/crash.

Can't thank you (and all that contributed) for your help. 

Pool A allocation is 25% when it was previously 100% and Pool B is now 100% (with thunderbolt) when it was previously 200%. 

Yeesh. Thanks again!

author: Slow Hand
content:
Hmm. In that case, I think in terms of cultivating suppleness and flexibility which I feel are best achieved through generalness, classics, and long-term thinking.

Contemporary trends can have a large payoff if you get on board at the right time, but if you're setting out today to start an education in LLMs and AI programming, that ship might have sailed by the time you're ready to contribute. 

Leaning too hard into cutting-edge knowledge without a good foundation of learning is a brittle thing. The winds of demand only have to change a little bit and then all of your specialized knowledge can become useless.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Gosh, it can be so many things that endear me to an artist and it can be none of them. It's a slippery thing to grasp, but here I go:

**1. They have a well-defined vision for their art that I can observe them continually exploring.**
**2. If they present themselves as a public figure, what is the expression of their persona? **
Is it authentic? (I'm a real person)
Is it stylized? (a heightened version)
Is it larger than life? (I'm a God)
Is it mysterious? (Leave me alone)

**3. Their actions as a person**
What do they believe in?
What do they advocate for?
Does their sense of humor manifest in their art?
Do they have interests outside their music? Do they tie them into their art?

**4. How do I observe them confronting challenges?**
Do they swing big in their creative efforts?
Are they resourceful in how they execute?
Are they telling a story about these challenges?

These are all qualities that I like to observe in artists. Some artists will have all of them, some will have none of them, and that's alright.

author: Joel "Roomie" Berghult
content:
Yeah for sure! Sounds like you're on a good path!! Totally understand the hesitation to delegate - especially that first 6 months-a year where you're acutely aware that helping someone else do it is *more work* than just rolling up your sleeves and doing it yourself. 

For building systems, what's worked for me is hiring and training your 'double(s)' first - someone with a similar skillset and sensibilities, very broad skills like me (who also did everything myself for a long time). This comes a lot easier if you have close friends in the same lane looking for jobs, I've seen people have their "double(s)" move in with them for a limited time too, with the intention of them soaking in exactly all you do.

Once my double(s) started doing pretty well, we started hiring more specialized people, and the doubles could then oversee their work, feedback etc - early on I would always be part of this, then slowly phase myself out.

What I wish I would have done earlier would have been to hire a producer/overseer/manager/'my boss' - someone with a bit more skin in the game/responsibility, and who keeps you in line if you start wavering. 

Again, I didn't love the setup of 10 and dissolved it eventually - as a creative it's easy to feel like you built a house/efficiency machine and one day you wake up and it's a prison that's not as flexible as you want. That's another thing I'm trying to keep in mind (I'm putting together a new similar team for this fall) - how do you keep the team agile and ready to shift when priorities shift? It could be as easy as accepting a little bit more churn & letting people go when they don't fit what's going on, but it's hard to let go of people you've trained and know well. I felt a friendship connection with my entire team, in hindsight I think that was a mistake too.

Those are some thoughts haha - what have you found so far? Are you experiences lining up with mine? What kind of roles are you hiring for?

An experience I just had / a Callback to our conversation a few days ago about trying to get work by imposing yourself and saying you could do something better:

I was just at a friends house party when a stranger walked up to me, introduced himself, and told me he does live sound. He told me all about his experience and how impressive he is. Anyway! Be cool, everyone! Play the long game.

author: Pio
content:
I really like an old classical theological meaning for the word mystery, and have found it helpful when thinking about things difficult/impossible to understand: a mystery can be understood as something which of its very nature lies beyond, or above, finite intelligence.

I like some effects of this view on understanding - it’s no so much that we can never hope to understand certain things. It’s not so much a defeatist attitude, that there’s no point in even trying. It’s a little more that I may never be able to fully grasp certain things - being a being of (very, lol) finite intelligence - but that doesn’t mean there’s no merit in seeking to grow my understanding of them all the same.

author: spectrummasters
content:
“I may never be able to grasp certain things “ / mystery . Love this man . This is it right here imho . Since primordial times we ve been staring into the great unknown . My friends and I got really into the beat poets , Ken Kesey ,aldous Huxley, Joseph Campbell  etc in our teens , going to school near Glastonbury and Stonehenge . There’s tons of ancient English mystical stuff down there . I take the view that we are the universe investigating itself . Probably just a “microorganism “ of a much bigger conceptual realm that we can catch glimpses of but not rationalise . I think Donald Hoffman has the closest view to mine I’ve heard articulated thus far . 

I like your fruit bowl analogy because it minds me of Picasso and Dali and how they’d render the bowl . 
When I was a lifeguard we had sessions for autistic children with high support needs , and the children would be reacting to stimuli that I could not “see “ . They’d be speaking to people or getting a scare from something I couldn’t see . I never once thought that they’re seeing things that aren’t there …..imho they are seeing things through a different filter to me .

author: LAPhill
content:
Communication is everything, especially now that I have a kid. There are hours I can always expect to be working, but when things are busy (which they always are), I squeeze in extra time where I can. There are a few sacred points in the day that I do everything to preserve - getting the kid to daycare, making dinner for the family and spending time with them until the kid goes to bed. My wife sees how much I make a point of protecting that, and sacrificing sleep so I can get the work done instead of sacrificing that time. 

She's got a busy job, too, so we both have to be flexible about who needs extra support at a given time, and be understanding when things come up. We're on the same team and we're both making an effort. So far, so good.

author: LAPhill
content:
My 2 cents: I was having dinner with some composers recently and one of mentioned feeding his online presence into Gemini or Chat GPT to get a sort of neutral assessment of how he's coming across. The idea is to make sure when people do look you up, they're getting the right idea (updated credits, good visibility on your biggest work, and the kind of vibe you want to give off).

I'm sure if you reach out to enough people, you'll get a few bites, it's a numbers game and a crapshoot. But these days, our first impression is often from our IG, so even if you don't want to be too active on social media, it's still worth making sure that for the people that do use it a lot, that you're leaving a strong one.

author: cian riordan
content: When I'm having the intro conversation before I start mixing, I usually tell the client that my V1 is almost always my favorite. I've mixed the song this way because its how I hear things, and most changes tend to deviate away from that -- and thats OK! But just know thats where I'm coming from on most heavy-handed revisions. When I send back the revision, i will put my notes in bold/color next to their notes... usually explaining what I did in vague detail. If it was a note like you're referring to above where I don't really agree with it, I'll make the adjustment best I can, say that I don't agree with it, but here it is anyways. If it's something I feel really strongly about -- I'll still execute, but be a little more forceful in my language saying something like 'I really don't think this is a good idea, but hear it anyways'. You want the band to know that you're open to feedback but that you also have skin in the game and care about the end product. This is something that gets easier down the line once you build up a rapport.

author: cian riordan
content: That's super fair given the circumstances of... *gestures to everything around us*. I'm lucky to be a full-time working mixer/engineer. I'm not in the stratosphere in terms of accreditation, but I'm comfortably making a healthy living, am married, have a child, and own a house. If I relied on big breaks, I'd be absolutely nowhere. 99% of my success has come from rubbing shoulders with the right people and finding opportunity that way. A night out drinking with friends leads to meeting other people who you stay in touch with. Pretty soon they'll need help with something and then off you go, that leads to the next. 75% of what I work on is smaller potatoes... most of it will never get heard, but it pays most of my salary. And the 25% of work I have that makes it through the filters has all come through connections I've made through smaller gigs. Networking is really key. And if you're a social person, it's even better as it'll help offset the time spent alone in a soundproof room, pulling your hair out over a stupid kick drum sound.

author: Slow Hand
content: You guys know that phenomenon where you can watch a car on the highway next to you and when you stare at it's hubcaps they look like they're spinning backwards? Did anyone ever realize that that's simply your eyes aliasing? It seems the "sample rate" of our eyes is too slow to catch up with a wheel spinning at highway speeds. We're perceiving the tire after it's already done almost a full revolution and we see it in the position *behind* where it once was. Hence the perception of spinning backwards. It's the same thing with audio. If the sample rate isn't fast enough it reads the super-high frequencies as being lower than they actually are.

author: Slow Hand
content:
This is definitely an interesting period in AI developments. Lots of exciting and novel tools exploding right now that are threatening to replace certain modes of illustration, writing, programming, and audio.

It seems likely that certain roles for creators are going to be diminished. Photography was a huge blow to illustrators when it emerged. Portraiture and photo-realism used to be the domain of painters. But when those skills became trivially easy to replicate the next generation of painters had to pivot into something else that played to the unique strengths of painting. I can't say what the actual causation is for sure, but the entire 20th century was dominated by abstract representation in painting, as one example of what that shift might look like.

Perhaps as creators our domains will need to shift into something else. Something more taste-driven and creative.

These AI tools can emulate pre-existing material well, but they still lack creativity, taste, and informed judgement. So I think the roles that are likely to remain (until another massive development) are matters of taste and curation. Somebody still needs to steer these tools to make something useful or novel.

author: spectrummasters
content:
im defo going through this chapter at the mo, and i like it. Im having some sort of psychological re-alignment with what i do and why. From sheer stupidity i managed to delete 70, 000 files . I've recovered the files but all the directories and filenames are gone. i was faced with the dilemma ....give up months? of my downtime...renaming and filing these files....or hunt back through my time machine disks and re-create these back-ups....or just move on.

Moving on has proven to be a bit weirdly easy and has left me reflecting on this:

If ive given up days and days of spending time with loved ones to work at the computer (which i have ) in my studio .....inside, and not in nature (which re-charges me) for all these digital dalliances that then vanish into the ether ....and iim cool with that......then was it the right thing to have ever done that at all ? Should i have just been sat with my baby boy for that extra 3 hours that day. 

My response so far (as you know ) has been to go laptop-based and mobile and break the chain to my studio set-up . This weekend im mixing for the first time away from my studio and with family. it feels cool. 

I know why i do music, because i have to......the time i give to mixing and serving the whims of the client ....this is something im examining more closely now. And that feels wise. Life moves fast, i dont want to spend a huge chunk of it in a fashion that isnt who i am.....screen-based and inside

author: LAPhill
content:
Jumping in way late to this conversation, but some thoughts:

I'm broadly on board with @Rollmottle 's sentiments that no one is owed anything, especially in this line of work. That said, all music industry professionals, from mastering engineers to songwriters to musicians, increasingly are in a place where they need to prove why they're worth a premium cost. Premium is no longer newbie engineer vs. Serban, it's free plugins (or the artist's friend with a laptop full of cracked software) vs someone with reps at all. Maybe right now, the "premium" cost of engineering is minimum wage, but that is sadly still much more expensive than slapping CLA vocal and Ozone on your track with well-produced Splice loops. So why is your service worth more than that? It's an honest question that we all face.

I believe in the value of educating a client in why what we do costs what it does, but I'm not going to lose sleep over someone that can't see it. I see a ton of up-and-comers over valuing their worth and losing out on gigs because they don't understand how far they have to go. Engineers are often just as guilty at overvaluing themselves as artists are at undervaluing them. 

The one thing that does seem to still hold true in 2023 is that people that are doing consistently good work keep getting hired. And track records of reliability, decent (not even great!) work, and some credits that someone's heard of are all things to point to when talking about price. @Deleted User made a point of someone wanting him, but not seeing his value, and that's a particularly tough spot. Sometimes, you've just got to walk away from those people, as good as it feels to be in demand by someone.

author: shaunobi
content:
@Jeremy Klein some thoughts on home ownership... my wife and I have done pretty well on our house. We've got a large one for our kids (3 kids, my dad also lived with us when we moved into our current house, so 6 people total) and we do plan to downsize if / when they move out. Current rate is 2.65 (I got a good deal, and spent a little to buy the rate down at the time - payoff on that was like 7 years).

We kept the old house, and for about 6 months I considered renting it out. I did not enjoy being a landlord, though, and abandoned mission quickly on that. I'd definitely go the prop manager route if I was to even attempt it. Portland rental scene ain't great though.

Prices in Portland specifically... if you chart them out, the more expensive houses aren't doing great, some zip codes aren't doing great, but in general anything in that "starter home" range that's also near a decent school has done pretty well.

In terms of investing in S&P 500 or total market or whatever, I think you can pretty easily see that they're more correlated than not these days. That was the big thing about the housing crash - RE crashed along with the market crash. In the past those could be decorrelated, so "diversification" worked in your favor. Housing crashing? Rebalance into stocks. Stocks crashing? Rebalance into RE or REITs. Truthfully, though, that's just not the case anymore. Nothing is safe 🙂

I think there's also some psychology here. You can run the numbers, and they do pencil out at times in favor of renting (and I do intend to rent at some point in the future, though I've mostly owned a house). However, being a bit "house poor" sure is a good way to do some forced saving. For years my wife and I paid an extra $1k a month toward our house, and had a very low rate, and we really saw our net value go up quickly. It was nice.

One final thought... you often make money on RE when you buy, not when you sell. Place I'm in (which is in a nice part of Portland up on the Alameda ridge) wasn't selling, and I offered $80k under list, and got it. Put $80k into it in improvements (had an ugly small kitchen) and it's worth a lot more now.

Overall tho? I'm mixed. Bad neighbors suck and you feel stuck with them. Maintenance is a killer (3% a year is about right IME). Sometimes you just don't want to deal with problems. But then... renting sucks too in other ways. Choose your poison! 🙂

author: Joel "Roomie" Berghult

Good question! If I were to list a few reasons:

- The government has invested in free or almost free music education for decades and decades, as well as financial support and grants for musicians
- Collaborative, non-hierarchical culture
- Trailblazers in the field that pay it forward
- A culture that cherishes English-speaking music and tries to understand it from a ESL POV, approaching music making with international export in mind

At this point there's so many institutions and traditions around it, it's embedded in the culture

author: LAPhill
content:
Let's think about this from an activism point of view - are you actually trying to affect change, or is this personal? In the case of MWTM, if you write to them and say "Hey, I disagree with this and will be cancelling my subscription," they might notice. If 500 users do it, they certainly will. If they lose 5000 subscribers, maybe they'd rethink it.

If their user base isn't passionate about the issue, MWTM doesn't have any financial incentive to change what they're doing. Spotify and the other streamers have Chris Brown, and I can't imagine the amount of pushback they would need before pulling his catalog from their services.

As Noah said, everyone can vote with their wallet and decide where to focus their attention on a personal level.

author: Zach Hughes
content:
That's a great question. Does a balance need to be struck? I think it comes down to what we believe about our role in relation to the people we are working with. To someone who doesn't work much with other people to whom success is largely predicated on their lone creative genius maybe the question of balance is neither here nor there.

However, if you are on a team, are a leader, teacher, or coach suddenly you are on the hook with others and the performance of the group matters. The highest achievement, future funding, drawing in more talent, etc... might all come down to the performance of the group. Would it then be wise to be so laissez-faire about undermining the intrinsic motivation / confidence of others? What if an unintended consequence of that attitude is less actual human connection?

Last thought I had is how do we know the truth of someone else's potential? Fwiw I don't know the answers but this is what's kicking around my head.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Everyone’s body responds differently, but I’ve been lucky enough to come out fairly unscathed with my hearing and mobility. 

As I understand it, it’s less about motion than it is repetitive motion. I was also playing guitar professionally so it kinda mixed up the muscles between that and the trackball. I got hurt when I was doing NOTHING but trackball 110+ hours a week for a few months. We were really burning the candle at both ends for a bit. The interesting thing to me is most people burn out their carpal tunnel) which is pointer finger, but mine was medial (I think) tunnel, which was the pinky, from all the chording on the expert trackball. The overuse inflames the tendon which causes it to rub which causes it to get inflamed which causes it to rub which… the steroid shots, some rest, and a lot of ibuprofen over the next few weeks helped.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Quite a bit.

My learning is less music-focused these days, but I budget a lot of time for self-development and continued study.

Sometimes it's  20 min a day in a technical book that I'm reading. I move slowly and make sure I understand before I move on. It may take two months to complete, but I'm steady with it and I do a little bit most days. It's common for me to transcribe notes from high-density talks that I want to learn from and revisit them often over the span of a week. I'm constantly printing out my notes and reading material so that they're easy to revisit throughout the week.

I'm currently taking a project management course through MIT, which has been great. It's uncommon for me to do formal schooling these days, but this is work related and a direct application to my future capabilities that we thought would be beneficial for the company.

When I buy a new plugin (rare) I set aside time to go through it and turn every knob and try each feature to see what it's capable of. Learning a tool on the spot is a good way to kill the creative flow, so I do the exploration up-front when possible.

Often I'll have ideas for novel ways to use a tool (layering distortion, for example) and I'll set aside two hours to explore it and see what I find.

That said, I think my day-to-day may be quite different from a lot of folks here. My eggs aren't all in the business and pressures of record production, and so I rarely find myself buried in such commitments. I tend to keep "normal" business hours these days and keep a hard separation between my commitments and my leisure.

In fact I'd say that I'm actively structuring my life so that I can retain my leisure and don't find myself overwhelmed with commitments. That's a whole other story, though.

author: Zach Hughes
content:
My relationship with things I do not understand is usually conditional on whether those things have antagonized me, wowed me, or are necessary to contend with for my work. One or all are enough to fuel my curiosity and engage the pursuit!

I’m stealing this line from Arcane season 2: “there is no joy in perfection only the end of pursuit”. That stuck with me. From such a great moment in the show. 🤐

At present if I have chosen pursuit I then find the people, organizations, and institutions that have been honored most for their contributions to the thing I don’t understand. Not because they “know” and I don’t but because they are further along in the pursuit. I follow the breadcrumbs they have left, meet other fellow travelers, and maybe catch up enough to some to say hi. 👋 

I am a willing and / or disgruntled object pushed into motion by that which I don’t understand and I am also intentionally searching for what is precious to me.

author: Zach Hughes
content: Personally it saddens me to see the continued disregard of the value of accurate and transparent credits by those in music. There's a reason the issue of credits is so messed up in this industry. I believe it's part systems, part incentives, but is also part cultural. I have hope that we can honor the contributions of our collaborators and build trust based networks. I don't see a solution to credits coming from anywhere outside of our tent. We do a disservice to the next generation of engineers, producers, and artists every time we obfuscate who contributed what to any given project.

author: sinaigimenez
content:
I got really sad when I saw this. It probably hits harder because my dad is around the same age and has Parkinson’s it's not the same but… 
 Dave always seemed like a genuinely good person, and I’m grateful for how he tried to spread knowledge.

I’m with Cian on the interview quality — a lot of them were just awkward (the Justin Meldal-Johnsen one is a perfect example), and the absolute worst part was Herb. In the end, his stupid ego kinda killed the show. It was really annoying how he kept interrupting all the time and talking way more than Dave or the guest, about random shit that had nothing to do with the conversation. Fucking terrible.

BUT I can’t forget that back in the day, Pensado’s Place was one of the very few places where you could actually see your mixing heroes talk about making records. Even when the interviews were pretty bad like 85% of the time, I still had great moments watching Eric Valentine, Tchad Blake, JMJ, Ken Andrews, etc… and I learned some useful stuff too.

I’m from a small village in Northwest Spain (BTW, I heard Pensado has family roots here), and I had zero access to any info about how real records were made. So when I discovered Pensado’s Place, it was huge for me. Big thanks to Dave!! And I wish him nothing but the best in this sad new chapter. Good people and love for this art will always win for me, no matter the flaws. ❤️

author: Will Trotman
content: Not sure if anyone else had this experience, but I had literally never heard of Joshua Slone until the other day when everyone was posting about his album release. First of all, great record / artist. I checked out his Spotify and saw that he had no music out before this album. Correct me if I’m wrong but my understanding is that he got some tik tok traction then went on the road with Zach Bryan before any of his stuff was out? Was so stoked to see the amount of excitement around an artist’s first release (which is so sick that his first release was an album as well). This might be a hot take, but I think I’m a pretty big fan of the way tik tok has impacted music discovery. Obviously it’s not perfect or going to satisfy everyone, but it’s pretty awesome that all the doors are wide open. And I feel like I’ve noticed a bigger interest in songs, writing, lyrics, etc. From what I’ve heard, it sounds like people got to know some of these Joshua Slone songs well enough to be singing along at his live shows, and I would dare to attribute that to the fact that his lyrics are literally on the screen in his videos. Who knows, maybe that’s all bull shit lol, but wanted to throw it out there. Would love to hear y’all’s thoughts.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
@rae this is a great discussion! Totally agree about open communication. It's something Jon and I talk about a lot. Learning how to have difficult discussions (even just learning 10 different ways to communicate "that still isn't good, let's do another take") is such a huge part of what we do. But honest, open communication is almost always the best solution. 

The only other thing I'll add regarding @Zack Hames's initial question is that I find it super valuable to continue to do all kinds of different roles. If I've mostly been programming and finishing productions, I'll take some time to write a song and sing it myself, so I stay "in shape" with writing and recording vocals. If I don't do something myself, how can I empathize with someone? My communication style is always one of "I know how you're feeling and you can trust me because I've done it a ton."

author: spectrummasters
content:
Interesting, yes i follow......this would be the dogs that humans keep to detect the cyborgs in terminator. I agree with your perspective.....I think that we as humans have boundless potential for invention and ingenuity (its just convenient to some that we aren’t educated to see ourselves this way when we are in school).....and its unquestionable IMO that the aesthetic pendulum of “augmented/artificial” processes will swing back hard the other way as soon as it reaches saturation. I was stood on a building site in Kings Cross with an old bricklayer under a bricked archway he was renovating.....and he explained how his trade was dying ...that no-one built brick arches anymore...its all breeze blocks and cladding....and we looked out across london and all the new buildings going up around us and he was right. Not a real brick in sight. One day someone will come up with the idea of using stone and bricks again for hi end projects and stone masonry and bricklaying will be considered art. The yin and yang of our desires i suppose

What turned you off Brett out of interest?

author: spectrummasters
content: Id not heard of him before you both mentioned him and I’ve been listening to Him on  lex fridman , @Nomograph Mastering . He’s a sharp cookie indeed . He’s currently discussing fractals and the nature of our perceptions as being at one order in a fractal , and that colours and sounds don’t exist in the real world , I love this .This gets to the heart of the science and the magic of what we do as musicians and engineers imo . He describes colours and sounds  as oscillations, and perceived harmonics as synchronous oscillations in the brain  . One of the things I geek out on is as engineers  is we get to learn and play with psycho acoustics and physics between  our and other peoples perceptions. ( Buddhism teaches pretty much the same thing Bach is describing here , it describes these things s aggregates . ) . This attention to how we perceive sound is what struck me about you and spiders discussion on lwmr ruari . It’s curious and inspiring imo that somewhere between the maths , the physics and the deception of our perception , we are all capable of communicating something we all seem to be able to share In , a connection in a vast array of unreal oscillations .

author: Will Melones
content:
I used to work for another store in the guitar center corporation, and GC’s turnover was worse than McDonalds’. This was when GC was doing relatively well—only the second bankruptcy or so. Sales reps would start and make great commissions for the first 3 months and then lose their enthusiasm, and commission was ALL they were earning. Sick discount, no paycheck. So I understand the struggle, and it even caused me to appreciate Sweetwater’s dedication to customer relationships in the beginning. Hell, the store I worked for kept a binder of “lead sheets”. Oh, a customer mentioned interest in lessons, or renting a violin? Better take down their info and call them every week when business gets slow.

But like I also don’t want a plumber texting me back to follow up. It just feels lazy and unprofessional, and unlike email or a phone call it strips you of your ability to control the pace of the interaction.

author: ehutton21
content:
I was gonna post about this, it’s a bit sidebar to the discussion at hand, but I’ve just done a very interesting experiment. 

My ADHD is horrid so it took some time to do, but I’ve got a routine where I catalog my “best practices/new ideas/important tidbits” notes from the discord, and I keep two brief shorthand form journals: one for while I work on a project and another for reflection after it’s over. It helps me stop thinking about the work when I want to wind down. 

Its crazy too see how over the last 3-5 months of working, my mental clarity and work flow confidence improved as I had started to build a lot of the consensus tips/habits/ideas from the discord. I’ve also recorded that people seem much more pleased with my work to date.

author: Slow Hand
content: It's a very powerful tool, but it also has a massive learning curve, FYI. I had to set aside an entire weekend to really wrap my head around it. So definitely ask yourself what you hope to get out of it before you go in, because there may be another app that can serve that purpose with only 1/4 of the complexity.

author: jantrit
content:
@austenballard  On a similar thread I try to frame those situations like this. There’s no point worrying about something because if you can’t change it why worry and if you can, change it so you don’t have too. A huge simplification but something I find helpful with dealing with tough times in a studio. 

You can get that weird moment in a session when something goes wrong  usually the best course of action is to be a positive and hopeful force for the band or artist to rely on. 

“Let’s get this sorted as quickly as possible and get back to work”
Deep down I don’t think anyone really thinks you’re responsible for what ever happened, they’re just looking for a solution. Except of course Trevor, Trevor knows you did it and he’s mad. 

Lol but really sessions are emotionally intense situations and places and sometimes that can boil up in interesting ways.

author: Barbara
content:
Loved reading all of this, I didn't catch the convo you had, but I'm glad you posted this @Ross Fortune . Having started as an intern, becoming an assistant after a few sessions and only later into engineering new projects and running my own sessions at the studio I work at nowadays, it's really clear to me that is you succeed at being a good assistant, people will trust you and you will be blessed with an opportunity to learn and evolve in a totally different and better way... I still assist some of the my colleague senior engineers and engineers that come to the studio for their own sessions, and I'm always eager to be on that spot... If you're that good and keep your mouth shut, you can only win - either by knowing the coolest people in the industry, by learning the craft, by learning how different people do their thing, different mindsets... And you REALLY learn what it takes for a session to run smoothly and for people to be comfortable in the studio, which will probably be the best skill you'll ever develop in this career... 

Being an assistant is great, and all the assistants I know are usually the coolest people to hang with (and yes, I'm including myself, of course 😎😂)

author: spectrummasters
content: Wellllll, as the person who asked the opening question , re: marketing and perceived value, it did seem to open up a broad discussion with a lot of varied input . Wherever it got into any perceived sense of entitlement , was off track as the core of the question was about leveraging and better pay/benefits for the successful elite (nothing to do with people striving to get there ) . It wasn’t a question about working hard.....or having talent......or how to share a pie and how much pie there is ......that’s all a given in the original discussion I referenced that was between two Grammy winning engineers.  It was a discussion about marketing and the idea of engineers  leveraging for more as a community looking forwards . One  platform was mentioned here earlier that I have experience with.......and they are definitely driving value down with their marketing.  Through the history of time workers have had to fight for more (pay/benefits/better working conditions / contracts ) and imho that’s a legitimate and beneficial force in society. Noam Chomsky describes a point at which society collapses is when the imbalance of the societal structure is such that the vast majority of the workforce can no longer afford to live . In the uk we are currently experiencing strikes across many services/industries. It’s not really my way to say if they are write or wrong ......but I think the concept of unionising and leveraging for “fairer/better :::::whatever you like “ is legitimate not entitled or moany  . The suffragettes did it ......I digress. I think IME it’s a fair observation that people employed on the business side of the music business in the big music companies in the  uk work with the expectation that this will result in take home regular pay, without fear of non-payment , working with full benefits re’ holiday pay , maternity pay , etc etc.......

author: Edward Rivera
content:
1) to an extent, the doom is real. I understand there are statistics about how this is the best time in the history of human kind to live, but I find that talking point to be pedantic and just plain insensitive. This is a server filled with more successful people than truly struggling people, and the world is the exact opposite. It's hard to hear from the former that things are ok.  


2) it's absolutely ok *not* to want children. There seems to be a one way street of judgement (not just here but socially) where the people who've chosen a life without children are indifferent to those who have / want, but most parents or want-to-be parents instantly throw shade to anyone who chooses not to be...and in most cases even towards people who nature has chosen for them, my partner being one of them. 

It's like all cat people *also* being dog people, but dog people just despising cats, but way less funny. 

3) you don't need, and absolutely shouldn't have, children in order to find some transcendence within your life.

author: cian riordan
content: I used to be good at that. I'd always pencil out what was going to happen each day (mix one song, revise these three, etc). But with things coming in last minute, some things paying double what others pay, people needing things rushed, other people having no deadline; It's just an intricate balance of juggling everything, trying to keep everyone happy while still maintaining a baseline of quality. All of my great opportunites have always come from last minute, 'hey can you do this real quick' kinda things. If I schedule myself into rigidity, I would likely be missing big opportunities.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Without question. And there’s much that can be gained from approaching the music business like a regular biz. Little things like, “deliver on time”, “respect bugdgets” “HAVE budgets” etc. that can really help you make and keep your money.

It’s just also a very specific market with very unique parameters and people, so how a software company is run won’t be a one to one parallel on how you should run a production career. A bit like a pet store owner outlining how to take care of a new puppy to a person that just bought a Canary. Definitely give it food and water, but there are some specifics that require a very different tact.

author: SoundsLikeJoe
content:
Not shit talking BBC, or my own products... but on a BIZ TIP for younger me out there: Don't assume there is no reason to push for players because you have great sequencing skills and $50k worth of sample libraries.  When the production company wants world-class sound, and it's your job to create the budget...   knowing that sample libraries can only take you so far is key to explaining to the client WHY they should allocate budget for humans. "I can create this with just the computer, and it will sound great....  but it won't sound like your example.  There's a real VALUE to humans playing the music and that extra 10% of the quality you're looking for requires a studio session with real players" 

Instant path to budget upgrade.  Suddenly the expense makes sense to them.  Now you get the pleasure of hiring all your friends and deliverying something that sounds top notch...  and you can take the client on a mind-blowing field-trip.  It took me years to learn this trick...   clients don't want to pay mountains of money extra for you to sit in front of your computer and massage CC lanes....  and if they have a mindblowing time in the studio and the track sounds ALIVE?  You win six different ways.

author: tim adamson 🇦🇺
content:
I'm a bit confused by the "bottom up breadth wise" language but I take him to mean that it's good to take on a concrete project that will implicitly define the knowledge/skill set that's necessary for it to be achieved. IE "this is what's needed for x and here's the pathway to actually obtain it"

I've seen a lot of people try and learn x by randomly shooting out a dozen questions with zero methodology. Usually the questions don't follow from, or relate to each other which ends up with the "knowledge" being disembodied surface level data at best and it doesn't seem like it's even relevant to them  that what they're learning is applicable to the real world

This has gotta be one of the worse ways to learn imo, typically you'll see the same person asking the same question a week later with no memory of what they'd learnt or why it's even relevant, there's zero chance of this kind of approach getting you "knowledge" that you can actually implement which should be the goal

I like Andrejs post a lot, esp when it seems like the bulk of the world is loosing their value in doing the more difficult and meaningful things in life, along with their attention spans

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Everything tells a story. For me, I love that before the digital age people were working toward precise time keeping. Entire towns in Switzerland were dedicated to it, like when the railway was built and bypassed this little town of Waldenburg. They ended up making the first chronographs for the Swiss Airforce in 1916! 

The care for the artistry and precision and aesthetics and how they all marry… I want that to be part of my story ya know?

Like Eric & his Japanese denim, or David & his coffee, those things help tell stories about who they are as people and how they move about the world. For lack of a better term, it’s a part of their brand. 

For you… well it seems like watches are very much a part of your history, but does it need to be a part of the story you’re trying to tell right now? Only you know that, and you shouldn’t feel bad for not giving a shit about it.

author: EliHeathMusic
content: I have a M.M. (jazz performance) and when I was living in New York and teaching part time, the degree may have helped me land the jobs I had but never got me an increase in pay. This is going off of a fairly small sample size though (a charter public high school and a private music school) and I stopped teaching in schools after about a year. I definitely got a lot of other things out of my Master's program (skills, network, artistic development, my Protools perpetual license, etc) and the degree would qualify me for certain academic jobs if I were to ever go that direction in the future. My main recommendation for grad school would be to do it for more reasons than just the certification and potential pay increase, and ideally find a program where the costs are mostly or entirely covered.

author: itaylerner
content:
Thank you guys for all the answers! 🙏🙏  Sounds like the general consensus is that  "music production"  programs really aren't worth the money. 

To be clear - She's a music educator and her career goal is to modernize music education in public schools by helping shift education practices from teaching theory and how to read sheet music to teaching modern music-making / production techniques (along with the fundamentals of listening skills, music history, etc.) 

A masters degree in music produciton would be a strong stamp of legitimacy to help advocate for that shift but I figured there weren't really any modern music production programs that were worth the money. Maybe there's something in the "popular music education" lane. We'll keep digging!

Again, really appreciate all the feedback y'all!

author: itaylerner
content:
Hey, y'all! It's the aforementioned girlfriend, Annie, here! Thanks for all the tips and opinions, I really appreciate it. 
I'm trying to kill several birds with one stone with this degree; I'm looking to attain my masters, partially for the significant salary bump (which will continue to be the case for teachers in the US, that is how our salary schedules work across the board), but I'm hoping to study something that will enable me to continue building the popular music curriculum I have been informally researching, writing, and teaching the past 7 years. I'm looking at several avenues for doing this, including an education degree, a research based music education degree, or a popular music degree. 

Itay and I both know there are a ton of popular music programs out there that aren't worth it but just thought we'd ask if there are any that are! Doesn't look like it haha 

Thanks again for all the tips 🙂

author: Spencer Broschard
content: My wife and I have been making duet cover videos on YouTube for 10 years and we’ve always been pretty adamant about doing them live and not correcting anything. It is so much harder and more stressful to get a great take especially with two singers lol but IMO it’s worth it and our audience really appreciates it…other than a few trolls who confuse using reverb with autotune. Could we have a bigger audience by now if we just decided to produce the best most clickable content? Probably. Maybe I’m turning into a crotchety middle aged man but I do think there’s something to be said for musicians actually being able to play and singers actually being able to sing without help from computers. I think it’s a huge reason why legacy acts are still being discovered and connected with by gen z.

author: bobby k
content: Ahh i missed plant talk but have to chime in. AVOID anthuriums and calatheas. we have 50+ plants in our home (my lady works with plants for her job) and we've never been able to keep either one alive, even from Easy Plant (so sorry @kylem we love you and appreciated it though). I've also heard Orchids are on this difficult list. The company cool though and offered to replace it free of charge, so now we have a money tree and it's fantastic. Looks really cool and is thriving. We're fairly organized with our plant collection so I have a long list I can share, but I'd suggest a syngonium, fiddle leaf, philodendron, or monstera. Favorites are philodendron billitiae or monstera thai constelation. both are kind of rare and eye catching, but not wildly difficult to maintain.

I just got a haircut that made think about communication with things like mix notes. 

I walked in with shoulder length hair and wanted a maintenance trim of about two inches off.  

Now it just so happens that my stylist had a mullet going down to exactly the length I wanted, so when describing it to him, I said “basically your length, but not a mullet, like not short on the sides”

Homeboy proceeded to cut my hair down to a 1940s business man short but with poofy sides. He thought I meant the length of his front, because I had said “your length but not a mullet”. 

I thought I’d been very clear and still got the complete opposite of what I wanted. 

My question is: Do we know if/when we are doing this with mix notes? 

Ie. Someone says they want something “clearer”, so we boost top end - but really the issue they were having was the hashy aliasing masking the diction and our boost just made it worse. 

When engaging with artist requests, are we knee jerk reacting to the literal words in the notes email, or are we truly grasping *why* the artist is asking for something? Do we feel what is underneath their request?

author: Gabriel Tyranny
content:
Phase 3 | Final Mix
- 🔑 Be Brave!
- A track will have a life and will and will of its own by now. That life is to be respected and only changed with respect and in context with absolutely everything else that plays within the same section of the track.
- There’s no method for this stage, as it’s more of a flow state of decision making that revolves around self trust.
- Sometimes, the gut will give me that painful realization that the snare is still wrong. It’ll be a process of juggling EQs, messing with routers, and questioning if I’m meant to do this lol, but I make sure more than ever that I back up the previous version of the track and push through no matter how I feel.
- For the sake of the tracks life that I should respect more than my desire to finish, I face this intimidating hurdle from a thoughtless place, letting go of any thoughts regarding the approaching finish line, commercial viability, etc etc. Literally any thoughts other than that self trust to know when to put it down, which developed as a macro skill across multiple projects for me.


But yeah - Also what @Juliette said 😂

author: Juliette
content:
— Approach your goals with realism, always full send it and don’t be afraid to fail. 

— We’re inherently always trying to be as intimate with our craft as possible (mainly music, but also movies, chess, tech, etc.) Separate yourself from it sometimes for the sake of your love for it. Do something you hate or you’re afraid of just once and it’ll reinvigorate your existing love or gift you a feeling you’ve never had before for something new. 

— Talk to people you’ve never talked to before. Expand your community and let them be apart of your bubble. If they’re weird, you’ve got just as much right to remove them from your bubble.

author: Slow Hand
content:
That fracturing is also why you can watch a movie on HBO one month and then it leaves HBO and becomes exclusive to Netflix a few months later. 

If you're the license holder you can generate more value for your properties by limiting the licensing window and then re-licensing to another streaming provider for a more favorable rate. It would be frustrating to sign up for Spotify cause you love Led Zeppelin only to find that they've re-licensed with Tidal a few months later.

author: Zack Hames
content: I think the fact that you’re reflecting on it is meaningful. The reality is, for a lot of artists, we may be their first recording experience, their first record, etc and they’ll grow a LOT during and move on and grow. I think this was mentioned In the Conversations podcast. So for me sometimes it’s letting certain things go that aren’t going to change in someones performance and trying to make it work. I did a pretty emo influenced record recently, and the vocalist isn’t the best. I tried to give him tons of vocal tips and train him the best I could, and it ultimately made it so much harder to record him because it sounded so unnatural and unemotional. We ended up using a lot of earlier scratch takes for certain songs (and they feel super good/relatable/captivating even though it’s maybe nasally) and then using particularly emotional driven takes at the very end. I think there’s a balance of being honest/giving feedback and being delicate/not destructive in your response. Also, @oaklandmatt , your point about learning 10 different ways to say something needs to be better, is spot on.

author: Adam Thein
content:
Just got this same spec also last weekend.  About a week in, it's definitely a little crowded for finishing work in my opinion but I'm use to working on a 1440p 24" monitor.  I can always HDMI I figure if I need the extra real estate.

The only acustica plug I run regularly is Ruby 2 - seems to cause pretty drastic spikes on the CPU short term in Ableton (running rosetta mode and VST3 by the way) but then it levels out.  In general I've been super impressed with the performance vs my desktop.  I'd say for my mixes it runs maybe 80% as well on large projects (75+ tracks, lots of processing) which was more than I was expecting.  Smaller projects and productions and softsynths it absolutely chews through compared to my desktop.

Was just trying out a little mix in Studio One just on the 14" and it felt very cramped to me.  I think it'd be hard to completely mix at this resolution but again it probably has more to do with what I'm used to.  Would definitely recommend a separate display if you are going to be doing all your work on it.

author: jantrit
content: I worked in kitchens for a long time, it allowed me to make some cash and live but also have flexibility to take music and studio jobs when they would come around. After moving to the states I found more restaurant work but kept it to only fri/sat/sun and tried to focus the rest of the week to build contacts and do studio stuff. I got super lucky with my boss who was also in the music thing and very understanding about calling out. It eventually got to the stage where I had to call out like 3 weekends in a row so I made the jump to doing the studio stuff full time. So far it’s been working out and I’ve been lucky to keep a good basis of projects, supplementing quiet periods with studio build stuff. It can be super stressful relying 100 percent on the music thing and it’s ultimately different strokes for diff folks. I’ve seen some people who get really burnt out taking music stuff that they don’t like to pay the bills and conversely I’ve seen people getting burnt out doing other stuff that’s not music getting effected in the same way. Ultimately whatever keeps ya happy and works for you is awesome, burn out is real.

author: ehutton21
content:
If you’re confident enough to hit various scales spanning 2+ octaves in each hand (in sync and delayed/one at a time) and you have a decently strong level of piano sight reading ability, then I’d say a piano teacher might be worth lessons every so often if it’s affordable because I’d say you’re starting to max the limits of your ability to assess your execution of technique (you’ll want someone to actually watch how you move, see where you should go, and give you specific cues on what you can shore up from there). 

But honestly when I was training classical piano regularly as a kid (good god I feel old saying that but I know I’m not lol), majority of upper level technique mishaps stemmed from struggles with proper wrist & elbow position where students would let their form slide (the more advanced the composition you were playing, the harder it became to remember your technique) and so they’d lack the actual strength and muscle twitch to hit harder moves.   That along with finger strength & dexterity would often result in stumbles or slips, which also vary based on how you strike the key. Most common error you’ll see that slows down technique is wrists dipping below the fingers a la traditional keyboard typing at any point in the playing process, and you’re never gonna swing an arpeggio or move fast enough to trill because your physical relation to the keys is what dictates proficiency. The physical aspect is why pianists are brought in so young (I started at supervised playing at 4 and I started instruction when I could get through the alphabet), because you can shape them into technique machines. 

So if you’re looking for max utility, finger drills, wrist position, and scales as much as possible is going to keep you sharp as hell.

author: ehutton21
content:
I feel like budgeting expenses to see what you’re actually looking at and what you actually need down to the last dollar and cent (as crazy as it sounds, it can be done fairly accurately, and some banks/creditors even provider a CVS file for excel usage of spending logs) and figuring out how to get to your breakeven point every single month eliminates a lot of angst, and often times it’s not as crazy as you think. I’m not quite in LA, my move there is next month end of September, but CoL in San Diego is nearly identical to LA in most ways. Once I put my shit into an excel spreadsheet and did the math on “this is break even; this is what it looks like if I go out every once and a while; this is what it looks like if I’m off my rocker with my credit card” I could put rather definitive numbers on things and it gave me peace of mind.

As for more of the how: I think gaming the roommate system is your best bet. I’m moving into a two bedroom place with my roommate/collaborator as well as my long time girlfriend. If you can find a way to split a bedroom, that’s gonna help. 2 bed room houses for rent aren’t that bad if you’re willing to sit down with a drink or two on Zillow for a few nights and really figure out your living area. I’ve found places for the $2300 in East LA and Pasadena. Splitting that and other key living expenses (we plan to have a few nights where we eat together and we’ll sorta rotate meal ideas, that way everyone’s not shelling out super ridiculous individual grocery charges) among 3 people each month is fairly easy so long as we hustle well.

Schools not important. Education is.

author: austenballard
content:
> There was a noticeable number of US clients (artists + their entourages, certain producers, and especially writers - usually in pop or hip hop) who treated assistants like “the help” / waiting staff / taxi drivers / some menial worker they felt was beneath them. The first few times it happened, it was kind of shocking, and very off-putting.

I want to add to what Ruairí and Matt B said with another perspective. I've had the privilege of working in some very professional settings, where everyone needs to fade into the background to do their jobs properly, and that's absolutely the case at higher levels. And it makes things work. And everyone's cool about it.

But much of my work has been as producer, assistant producer or project manager/fixer for people working at decidedly lower levels. 

And idk how it is in other countries, but we have a glut of people here in the US who have a certificate from a for-profit recording school that says they know what they're doing, who think they're *the shit* for being in the room with some viral star off YouTube/Instagram/TikTok. But don't know how to use a damn patch bay. 

And when you're on the come up, especially as a writer or producer, you interact with a lot of these people, and you get REALLY sick of them REALLY fast. So that might be the source of some of the condescension you see. It's hard not to get jaded when you have to wade through so much incompetence. I feel like a bitter old man just typing this paragraph tbh but I hope I'm not the only one with this experience.

author: cian riordan
content: When I first got hired by Eric as his assistant, I had already built a multi room studio complex and was making a living producing and engineering records. When I landed in LA for the first session, my mindset was “I can’t wait to show off all the knowledge and experience I had.” I very quickly ran up against the “nobody-gives-an-absolute-fuck-what-I-have-to-say-about-anything” wall. It was very clear that I was there to sit in the back of the room until I was asked to do something… order food, help with a mic setup, shuffle cars in the parking lot, etc. Not to mention working for someone like Eric who is extremely self sufficient… he was terrible at asking me to do things. It was always just quicker for him to do it… even if it meant getting up from the seat and walking all the way across the studio to adjust something. I made the absolute mistake in my second or third week of suggesting something to the drummer in the band after a performance. Eric overheard and pulled me aside. Basically said something along the lines of “yo, you really can’t do that. If you have an idea, run it through me. Absolutely inappropriate, however well intentioned it was. This was really deflating to me. I went from running the show at my own place to spending 14 hrs a day waiting for something to do.

author: austenballard
content:
I need to amend what I said earlier. Forget about **protecting your personal information** - it's out there. That's not the point. If someone wants to dox you, they will.  

What you do have to do is make it as difficult as possible for someone with your information to act on it kinetically. Have a gate. Or live in a building with a doorman. Private mailbox rental, and use that address for everything you legally can. Delay your social posts if they're in an obvious location until after you've left. No license plates in photos. The list goes on but I'm too tired to write it rn

author: ehutton21
content:
Piggy backing on a lot of the great thoughts in here and recalling my own musical education, I would say dividing the curriculum into a “listening” component and a “creating” component would be critical. In hindsight, it was incredibly formative for me that ear training practice and actual theoretical/sheet music knowledge always came alongside the practical element of sitting at keys and performing the pieces I was assigned that week.

I like the idea of breaking down modern pop structure, I like the idea of covering signal flow a lot. I think you can teach and test signal flow in theory while allowing someone to practice their recording technique by mimicking the song structure of their favorite pop song. I’m not proposing that as an actual coursework suggestion (I doubt most would be ready for that week one) but just as a thought for course organization

author: Slow Hand
content:
Observing others' conversations on the matter, it seems that Chat GPT still has lots of limitations when it comes to coding. Currently it lacks certain contextual awareness about how a part fits into a larger design/ecosystem, and so it's guidance on how to code or design something may be limited to low level coding at the moment.

I've got some friends experimenting with using it to generate content for their Dungeons and Dragons game and while it's been good about generating serviceable scenarios and providing responses to player choices, another limitation that they've encountered is that it doesn't remember things like player state (what was their health when we started, what is their location, etc). That is to say it lacks certain kinds of long-term memory that allow it to maintain continuity.

author: David Fuller
content:
So sound is captured as electrical signals by disturbing a magnetic field (or in the case of condenser mics, changing the voltage potential across a specially tuned capacitor), which generates an AC voltage corresponding to the compressions and rarefactions in the air. This is a whole topic on its own but tl;dr for dynamics you're moving a magnet back and forth inside a coil of wire, with ribbons you're moving the wire back and forth inside a magnetic field, guitar and bass pickup you're disturbing a magnetic field with vibrating ferromagnetic strings... anyway. 

Linear voltage amplifiers (ie class A, and AB for us audio guys) - which we use for mic preamps, line amps, differential amps, power amps, pretty much anything you can think of - work by using an AC voltage to vary DC current flow. In its most basic form, it works like this: That AC signal from the mic or guitar pickup hits either the grid of a vacuum tube or the gate of a FET, and changes the amount of current that flows from one end to the other (usually cathode to plate in a tube, and usually source to drain in FETs). Stick a resistor between the DC power supply rail and the amplifying element and you get a voltage variance because of ohm's law - current goes down, voltage goes up, and vice versa. So, you end up with a bigger version of the input signal, with its polarity inverted. 

Distortion is a *way* more complex topic and not one I'm equipped to explain, as I don't understand it very well myself.

content: They discuss purpose in depth and gladwells ideas that we have three levels at which we need to feel connected and satisfied . Firstly , immediately with ourselves . I’d tend to agree
