author: Josh
content:
I’m very late to the convo but this is facts. My brother one day called me during his lunch break at Walmart and he was almost crying because he was so frustrated he couldn’t get enough sales to not work there and he said something along the lines of “I can’t believe people are fine with working here”. And I literally said “Bro, you should be JEALOUS. Imagine how much easier your life would be if you were perfectly content with putting the Mayo in the bag.” 

He hung up on me. 

The next day he goes “Hey man. You’re right. I’m jealous of the people who can Mayo in the bag”. 

And that’s just facts. 

I knew a dude who worked at a really great restaurant as a chef. Not the big chef but one of the chefs. During covid he said “eh I have this crazy passion for cooking but never cook for myself. Why don’t I go sell cars?” And he fucking did it and ended up being the only dude I knew who could make $20k a month selling Toyotas without ever having stimulant dependency in his life. This man was leagues happier after the change mostly because he could finally have Sundays off to watch football.

author: Zack Hames
content: I do make my living making music. But my salary comes from making music and mixing post production audio in advertising. It keeps me in pro tools and being creative and paid so I can dedicate creative energy and time to record making. (I also freelance at a recording studio in town)

author: Zack Hames
content:
This is a lovely idea. No one’s gonna risk their bacon in at least the USA economy. Educating our clients and learning the industry so that they can find viable ways to be more financially viable is a good way to get a return on our end. (Providing value, being an expert)

We as engineers get money from artists and labels. Understanding how they can make money may help us, help them, help us, etc. 

most small bands make an album, don’t want to spend any money because they have 0 idea how to make money off of it after it’s done. Whether that’s ignorance, the albums not that great, or lack of effort, depends on the artist and project. 

It does bum me out. But I have 0 idea how to address this on a large level. I think just understanding this career is the long game and if you do good work long enough it’ll eventually pay off.

Sometimes you do a record and you lose money or make almost nothing and spend months on it. Another time you’ll spend an hour or two and make a ton of money. It balances out.

author: Josh
content: Oh man I had this happen to me except they didn't come back and apologize. They were never available to work, I did two songs for the price of one, paid for 4 days of studio time because they all of a sudden couldn't cut the vocal in the session, wrote the whole thing, produced the whole, and the vocalist was *almost* tone deaf. They came back after the songs were done and said I ripped them off because they bought 4 beats for less than half of what I charged them lol. We're talking 15 hours on just tuning. I still think about that whole thing right before I fall asleep at night.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Some anlalogies I've found helpful when navigating this whole mindset and fending it off:

1. Piano (or any instrument) -- would upgrading your instrument make you a better player? Maybe marginally, if you are already at the extremes of being very very good. This isn't to say it doesn't matter, ala gear, it's just that it's way better to become an AMAZING player than worry about whatever your current instrument is.

2. Sports -- as close as to a meritocracy as anything, literally everyone has to play on the same field with (generally) the same gear, or close to it (especially at higher levels). A lot of the time if I'm feeling like I'm a "piece of gear away", I think...would upgrading my cleats make me better? Almost certainly not in any way that would matter. Go practice, that may help, and if you are Lionel Messi or Patrick Mahomes then maybe the gear could give you a tiny advantage you could use

Not so simple, great gear does do a thing, but recentering on yourself is worth a lot I think too

author: spectrummasters
content: I was in my hometown brighton on the weekend and was chuffed to see the old collectors and dj record stores from my teens still open and now …..a brand new thriving alll vinyl store with classic re releases but also new stuff …..and most people in there were under 30 . I also just spent a couple hundred pounds on three new release n-hypen cds for my daughter as a gift the other day (which she told me about )  . Beautifully boxed , artwork pamphlets , high quality print gatefold posters , unlock web codes , stickers , loads of stuff . She cherishes them bless her It’s a touch I still have an older imac with the cd/dvd drive because she is definitely about the cds……..and it’s mad to think there’s no way to play anything physical on contemporary computers . The loss of the physical format is a huge loss for music imo .fwiw im not a vinyl lover (even though I’ve tons of it and releases of my own on it ) but I do love 💿 I bought up tons of second hand cds  a few years back at 99p a time for sampling purposes (the highest quality format available at that point  compared to vinyl and streams ) . Now my cd collection let’s me listen to all the great pre - 2000s music without needing to suffer the horrific streaming remasters )

author: Slow Hand
content:
I'm particularly keen on this idea of humor as lateral thought. I've got a motto that I say to myself as a matter of process: "Always invert."

Whatever the subject facing me: a problem, a reply in a conversation, an object, a principle I'm adopting, a rule, or an idea, always start by inverting it's properties and seeing what you get. Turn it upside-down and see what that extreme reveals to you, then make a choice.

Often, with an inversion of perspective you get something hilarious, and that can be valuable in it's own right, but just as often you get newfound empathy, or something unexpected, or catch yourself from stumbling into a foolish move. Although, quite often the inversion itself *is* the foolish move because it flies in the face of common sense. 😄

Here’s what I remember - I got a notification about MacOS Sonoma that I hit the little X on while in a meeting midday yesterday, maybe 1p.  At 430p I got a “updates have been installed and a restart is required”

The boss of my first label (a U.K. garage label ) was busy getting hold of exclusive U.K. licenses to release all this stuff in the U.K. including the absolute smash robin s show me love. My label boss and his pals got busy trying to produce their own versions of New York garage and so U.K. garage was born

author: Deleted User
content:
I don’t think the boxes are necessarily bad; I think they can simplify the process of search of self. However, that in and of itself is the danger too. I grew up trying out different boxes myself in the process of searching for who I am; I believe I still am and that it will keep on going. I always felt like I didn’t belong in any of those boxes. I’ve sat with this feeling of discontent for a long time and realized that the boxes are mirages of idealization, and that NO ONE truly fits into ANY boxes. Part of themselves might be scattered in different boxes- but not all of themselves

‘since I’m in this box, I should be this way’

but this really hindered me from finding my true self. And I see a lot of people go through this. It’s not projection; I see people actively steering themselves away from who they really are because of this idea that there is one box they should fit in.

author: Slow Hand
content:
So the producer of *Abstract* is (was?) the editor of *Wired* magazine and he and David Chang were doing a SXSW talk on their upcoming joint venture.

I'd been intrigued by a 2016 feature that David published in *Wired* called *David Chang's Unified Theory of Deliciousness*. Silly name, but a stimulating read.

In the article David describes his epiphany about how popular flavor profiles in recipes re-occur across cultural boundaries. How a Chinese spicy pork sausage and rice cake has the same fundamental flavor profile as an Italian ceci e pepe and they share underlying structures that are expressed differently in their respective cultural incarnations. In math this would be called an isomorphism.

Well this immediately rang to true to me because I'd observed the same thing in music. I thought about this article for a year. Finally I saw that they were giving a talk in a hotel showroom with 500 people in attendance and made it a point to attend.

When the open mic was passed around I asked my prepared question, expressing my admiration for their insight and how it was applicable to other domains beyond food. I asked them if they'd had any additional insights on this phenomena since publishing the article.

They both looked to each other, didn't say a word, and then proceeded to ask for the next question 😕.

To this day I have no idea what happened.

author: Matthew The Cooke🎄🎅🏻
content:
**-) **Offline experiences might be a song or an artist being tied to a memory I cherish - that song played at that party when I kissed a beautiful girl, that song played when I was walking out of the bar piss drunk at 6 am with my best friends, that song I heard when I was at a music festival 10 years ago and the world was a better place etc, that song makes me laugh my ass off everytime I hear it (shoutout Frank Zappa lol)

**-) **It could also simply be a piece that moved me when I first heard it and it made me feel something - take for instance** LCD Soundsystem's** *"All My Friends"*, which is to me still the most poignant anthem about getting older, and it never fails to illicit and emotional reaction in me, even though I've never seen them live or have a specific memory attached to them. 

**-) **What makes me become a fan of an artist is - at least these days -  mostly determined by how consistently the artist's work can get an emotional reaction out of me. Take **Bleachers** for example - I had been aware of them for years, but only with this year's album and after discovering "Hey, their songs are actually ALL that good" I became a fan. 

**-)** There are a only a handful of bands/artists I consider myself a hardcore fan of., where I truly explored their entire catalogue over and over again, and it was almost always because they just continued to impress or move me

author: Rollmottle
content:
Going to rep Tailscale here.

Been investing in some infrastructure and future planning over here. The problem I was trying to solve was making my working drive available to me for when I’m away from my studio so I can continue to be responsive to clients at all times. 

Tailscale allows you to create a secure, private VPN without having to have a networking PHD and compromising your network. Basically install the client on a device, 2-factor auth into the client and any other client you have installed on any device signed in with those same credentials are available to you as if you’re on the same local network, even if you’re on another network anywhere else in the world. It’s an actual game changer.

For a variety of reasons including keeping my mastering rig lean and clean and because the rig is not always on because I don’t want to run my HVAC 24/7, I sync a clone of my working drive from my mastering rig to a drive attached to an always-on Mac in my home network that has the Tailscale client authenticated. I’ve got screen share enabled on that Mac and now from any other device, I can sign into it and grab whatever I need from that clone drive. You can install the client on virtually any device including NAS’s and mobile phones so it opens up whole new avenues in how to think about availability of your data, traveling, 3rd party cloud vs. rolling your own, etc. Tons of possibilities. Really big fan. Love the future.

https://tailscale.com/

author: cy (sigh)
content:
1st thing I'd recommend is listening to the Tape Notes podcast. they interview the artists and producers to break down the processes and stories behind the tracks. 

I got quite a bit of confidence in that respect from listening to those . especially ppl  that come back multiple times. I don't even necessarily listen to everyone's music, I'm often more intwrested in their personal approaches - especially since lost are folk who we'd consider "established"  and what I found to be true for most of them is they split into 2 main camps with most of us dancing between them. 

a) have 0 clue wtf they're going for a lot of the time. kind of going with the flow of whatever is happening /they're feeling in the moment. very similarly to people starting out or me. the approach can vary wildly and a whole concept can be born of something seemingly unimportant at any given moment. 

b) there's an outline that comes to mind early and might give some direction. whether that's thematically or sonically. how tightly they stick to this can vary a lot depending on the artist. 

I think there are many factors that come into play - how good and ready the team they have is might be one of the most important imo. that's both for the creative side and admin side. 

as far answering  your questions as a producer, it depends. 
some artist I work with will literally dream up the whole production and I'm kind of facilitating and bringing it into the real world. others will come with loose ideas and others will show up with absolutely nothing and go off the feeling in the moment. some are more involved than others in the production

your relationship with them is probably the biggest factor in knowing how far you can push their creatively bounderies. 
same artist that dreams up their production usually gives me free range to try whatever I want when the session is over and I've overhauled whole songs.  recently a post-punk ish artist picked up a video game ost /jazz fusion prod I was sketching

author: Gabriel Tyranny
content:
I’ve officially competed in many different activities and learned the art of optimizing for first place. I got a thrill in ‘seeing the Matrix’ and coming up with my own ways to do things, but ONLY if it had results tied to it. 

I have a 6th place finish I got over 10 years ago that I’ll never forget, because I was so obsessed with getting top 5 (preferably #1 but I’d always lie to myself that the next threshold would be enough, but it never was) I was destroying my mind and body and my health was affected. I had to stop focusing on competing and find the deeper layers behind what I was really running from by attaching my self worth to competing like a parasite scared of losing its host.

Music was actually such a perfect remedy because I can always improve my ability to translate my ideas into reality, but there is no optimal result. No truly perfect song or finish line. Hunting world records was a life of quick-sand, always trying to keep up with the past while showing you can still do it in the present. 

Those days of competing taught me that entering the ring, doing my best, and letting go of any care of result is where true joy lies. Any connection to an activity and my self worth, or my complicated authentic identity, has nothing to do with the outcome of how my time was spent, but instead the win of having the ratio of the time I spend in life doing what fulfills me.

-

I made music at that time too, but ever since these breakthroughs my music has become far more authentic, which makes me feel like it’s better. It jumped the quality of my work way more than any technique, because now I sit down to express exactly who I am in that moment, and everything else is a subconscious implementation of everything I’ve learned thus far.

author: chrissorem
content: This is an important balance you brought up, we have to constantly find ways of keeping the session flowing but also make sure we take time to get things right.  No one wants to watch someone get drum sounds for hours or any sounds for hours yet we expect the results to sound as if we did.  We have to stay out of the way but always be prepared to catch someone falling.  This job is hard, there are many details that go into making  a session go well.  Id suggest thinking about the things you feel need to go further. Are there ways you can be ahead of the curve ?  Are there ways that you can surprise the room and you can say “I  actually just took care of that, we can move on to the next thing”? We have to be steps ahead of everyone else in the room. Some things do in fact take time and you can decide if doing certain things are disruptive to the flow and you might need to bust it while everyone is getting a coffee or telling the room  “ hey gang I need 15 mins to take care of …..”

author: spectrummasters
content:
Fun . Can dig it . I’ve got a 90s midi style production setup alongside my contemporary one . Akai s3000 slaves to the MPC 2000 . Into mixer . 
Only major difference to writing in the daw is timing of the mpc. Be aware if you’re tracking it into your daw it won’t line up on the grid as its timing drifts . So if you like easy grid based edits of overdubs etc it gets a little more complicated than usual . I wasted a bit of time trying to work out the problem then slaving the mpc to daw MTC which then just removes the mpc swing which is counterproductive . So yeah , if at any point it’s gonna be tracked into the daw familiarise and strategise for that asap in the process .

That was me in like 2019, I said yes to *everything* before that and eventually for my own mental health I had to make a decision about what my priorities were. I ended up choosing to value self care and family availability higher and it turned out that my clients understood.

This industry has a lot of double edged swords though, I think if I had made that decision earlier in my career I wouldn't have had as many opportunities so everything is tradeoffs

author: spectrummasters
content: I guess it depends what floats one’s boat ⛴️. Part of my process to transition into band mixing is constant listening to indie bands who crossed over to majors in the main scenes in the UK/US since the 70s . Really listening deeply to the recordings and performances . I’m currently discovering kyuss …..and at this point I’m totally addicted to everything about these recordings that sounds completely human . The buzz of it sounding like a bunch of people in a room making a racket ….and some engineer managing to capture and articulate it . Im totally addicted to the humanity of it . The concept of us being archivers of moments , creating a catalogue of human expression is what motivates me . I saw timbos latest AI release and it struck me how exquisitely banal it was . Quite impressive in fact

author: Zack Hames
content: That’s a super thoughtful response, totally helpful! I think you hit on two huge things, performing in the moment and the bigger picture creatively. For context, a band I’m currently working with worked with someone who, locally, is quite popular which is why they hired them but they did not have a good experience/didn’t like the end result (maybe similar to your experience). they complained that engineer they hired had 0 input good or bad and was not super flexible when it came to sounds (drummer likes open toms as opposed to dead, the engineer basically shrugged and said that it was going to cause problems or something to that effect) So I made it a point to communicate my thoughts on takes as much as possible and make suggestions and guide them when needed. author: Zakhiggins
content:
I had another job up until the pandemic actually, was working 20+ hours a week, and doing college while working on music, then the pandemic hit and the place I worked at shut down, the business is fully closed now but that's another story. Right now with the government restrictions in Ireland, sooo many businesses are closing and it's near impossible to get a job. 
So my college then went remote, meaning I had alot more free time on my hands, and no steady income.. This kinda forced me to go all in on production. College finished last May for summer, and I worked hard as fuck on being a better mixer and producer (with the virtual help of Matt and Jon) and also tried to figure ways of making money from it.. Apart from working with local artists (there aint too many here in Dublin) most of the work I got and still get was through soundbetter.com, after a while of grinding I got to a stage where I was and still am, only making a little bit less than the job I was in before, so I can at least survive lol.

Basically long story short, I'm actually kinda full time music right now while finishing off my college degree. Then I've to make a decision of whether I remain fulltime music here, go part time and get a job from my degree, or move to the US or London to pursue music there. It'll prob be one of the latter 2 options cos the scene here is very much in it's early days and not sure if a sustainable career could be had.
Also as I said here before I'm very fortunate to live in a country where you can get free education, so debt isn't a worry for me. 

That's my long ass story anyways, since you asked 🤣

author: Zakhiggins
content:
I don't wanna talk bad about anyone but I've been following kneesovertoesguy for a good few years, even though I agree with alot of what he says I'd be careful with him for sure, he used to have a really good system with ATG and good coaches around him, but they've since left him and he's become alot more of a business man than a coach I feel, I know his training works for him and some others but it definitely isn't 1 size fits all, I know personally people that  have signed up to his programmes and have gotten much worse knees than they went in with, and when they asked him about it they were blocked on everything by him.. There's a lot of people out there with similar unconventional principles to him (like putting load thru knees over toes and back flexion etc) but are definitely much more educated on the topics they're speaking on, and won't block you when you confront them..

Id personally reccomend the likes of Jeffery Wolfe (@theflexibull), moses Bernard (@mosesbernard), Dan van zandt (@flexibility.research), Nicholas Simpson (@nicholassimpson_)

I've reached out to them before and they're always very helpful, nice people, I know they often do live videos themselves, maybe it could be worth asking one of them to do a podcast with you..
I definitely don't consider myself an expert on this stuff, but I feel I have a very good base knowledge on health and fitness, I've been heavily involved in track and feild most my life, competed internationally too, so keeping strong, flexible and pain free is definitely something I've experience in lol

author: David Fuller
content:
Anyway: uncompressed PCM audio (.wav and .aiff) is made up of digital words generally 16 or 24 bits long recorded however many times a second for a given sample rate, for fixed point (integer) values. Each bit represents ~6dB of dynamic range. Every time you go up in level 6dB from that particular sample point, another bit flips from 0 (off) to 1 (on). The least significant bit defines your noise floor, so 16 bit audio has 96dB of dynamic range at maximum from noise floor to full scale (every bit turned on). Seems simple enough, right? And it isn't super complicated. But it has one problem: you run out of dynamic range real quick if you're changing levels with (virtual) faders at 24 bits. There are two ways around that:
1, make the mixer engine run on a much higher integer word length (like old Pro Tools HD systems, which use 48 bit integer), and the mixer automatically converts the audio (if anything is done to it, including fader moves) to 48 bit. Think of this as adding more digits to the fractions side of a decimal point. 
2, make the mixer engine run on a floating point system (almost every other DAW, including more modern versions of Pro Tools) - that is, you move *where the decimal point is* . 32 bit float effectively works as 24 bits that can be moved around more or less with impunity, up or down.

content: I had the same life growing up. Thankfully BJJ is good for all ages, you can start at any age and still improve a ton for the entire life without a need for above-average physical strength. One thing I’d say is to find a good place with healthy community. Where everyone trains with everyone regardless of skill level (when covid is not a thing) and where people aren’t training to feed their egos. author: skinnybreakfast
content:
Sorry for the book incoming. But this is plaguing my mind. Has there been an in-depth discussion on live or in discord yet about musicians on tiktok? 

It's a crazy scene of selling your creative soul for 1 minute of attempting to go viral. and then if you do get a popular video, whatever that one was - that is now your thing... singing into a trash can doing RHCP covers... ok, now do another 100 of those.  I see so much talent on there, genuine talent and artists who have worked hard on their craft getting 10 views due to the algo... once the algo has tried your vid on a few people and it didn't stick the vid is dead... so it's totally hit and miss based on your first small sample of viewers.

I see this having a huge impact in many ways. On the plus - you are getting exposure to incredible new ideas, skills, trends, methods for being creative... on the negative it's demotivating to the nth degree, and cheapening the creative process, in my opinion.

Matt and Jon recently talked about track lengths getting shorter and shorter, now 2 minutes is the normal. Partly due to the attention span of people... well what is this going to do... 1 minute pop tracks incoming? Just gimme the hook in 30 seconds and let's move on please. :p. How can we get young people to lay on the floor and listen to 10 minute vinyl tracks again? In my opinion humanity NEEDS this :)) 

I also swear I've heard the influence of trending memes from tiktok coming through in music in the charts, but cannot really back this up.

What's everyone else's thoughts? I have a friend in LA who says everyone has gone crazy there for tiktok fame? 😛

author: Slow Hand
content: I think you're also right that the music of memes and Tik-Tok edits are starting to creep into popular music. I think that's exciting. It's layered and fun. As long as the core material is compelling it's all fine to me. My one reservation might be if you need to have full cultural context to appreciate the "meme-ness" of the song. If the record doesn't hold up on it's own outside of that cultural context then it's probably weak songwriting. It's window of relevance is limited.

author: skinnybreakfast
content: You said you're fine with 1 minute tracks right, which is fine and I get it. I have made a few myself that I like and found I expressed the feeling and emotion in that time and it didn't need more... but.... what if you are confined to 1 minute for every track all the time... your form of expression is going to change no? Can everything be truly expressed in 1 minute snaps. What about songs that keep you in the vibe and space by having space and time to unfold.... my concern is everything is getting shorter and shorter with tiktok being a big influence. instant gratification, move on, "i need to find the next hit for my brain", swipe swipe. this speed, this haste... how is there any chance for music to settle, sit and unfold in the listeners mind? --- and even if you manage that, it's gone almost instantly as they continue swiping for the next "hit".

author: Zack Hames
content:
I’m pretty sure Spotify main normalization is set to -14 LUFS. 

In my experience with Broadcast, streaming, Advertisement audio, the LUFS standards have proven incredibly useful and quite reliable. Every project to do for “web” is mastered to -14LUFS, North American broadcast is -24, and Euro -23. Hulu, Roku, YouTube, etc all have their own little specifications for loudness. 

LUFS takes into account perceived loudness whereas RMS does not. It also does not measure or add to the loudness for passages of audio that fall below a certain level of loudness. So if something is far quieter, it doesn’t get factored into the average loudness.

author: peterlabberton
content:
Partly in light of recent Facebook… developments:

I would *very* happily leave Instagram—or make a private account and unfollow everyone except my actual friends—if I wasn’t worried that it would impact my work. I feel like I have anecdotal experience that, when I post more on Instagram, I work more. And so I keep at it even though Facebook/Instagram just generally bum me out—and are ruining society.*

I am a freelance engineer/mixer/etc. and rely almost completely on work for hire gigs, i.e. I’ve got basically no passive royalties coming in. I’ve gradually, recently gotten my name on a few bigger projects but by no means do I have random people hitting me up to work—the vast majority of my income comes from friends/acquaintances hiring me for their self-funded projects.

Has anyone else in a similar situation tried fully cutting the cord?

*BTW, this community is so rad, and I’m well aware it sprung out of Instagram. Life is complicated. 🤷🏻‍♂️

author: jantrit
content: With isolation you’re only as good as the weakest part of your system, that is to say, is the door opening the place where you notice most sound leaking? By the sounds of it yes! First things first can you change it out to a solid core door and add weather stripping and some beefed up stops all the way around? You can get special door seal kits with a droppable bottom seal that seals tight to the floor when the door shuts, although these are like 200 bucks a pop and you can get similar if not better results making something yourself. You want to start by figuring out a rough mass per square foot for your wall assembly (include drywall, stud work, insulation etc) and then bring your door up to the same mass per square foot. Solid core door, good seals all the way around and then you can even add more mass to the door with drywall or plywood. Once your door is at least the same mass per square foot as your wall assembly you’ll have to look elsewhere to gain more isolation

author: cian riordan
content: I juggled side-gigs for years while getting going -- but made a point for all of them to be temporary & extremely flexible. So many of my opportunities came last minute and having the ability to pivot and make things happen for people was extremely important. For example, I was living in the Bay Area working out of a studio when I reached out to Eric about assisting. He asked if I could come down to LA that weekend to interview/hang-out -- so I got on a plane. At the end of the weekend he hired me and basically said, "record starts in two weeks -- can you get down here?". I had to move out of my studio, pack up my life, find a place to live, and get down to make it happen. Obviously that was a great opportunity and most folks in my position would trip over themselves to make it happen -- but I always wondered had I had a day-job with real obligations and financial leverage over my life, would I have been able to make the timeline work... probably not!

author: BatMeckley
content: Like with a certain band i love that I work with, much of their income is derived from licensing. I didn’t take publishing per se, but in the case of that record not only did I make a fair cut of the normal revenue off the album reflective not only of my normal deal and the discount they got, but we also agreed to splits if something got used in movies and or in a jeep commercial or what not. I’m not listed as a writer, I don’t want to legally have them have to clear things with me, they just make sure I get a cut when it happens.

author: ehutton21
content:
Just additional food for though, re: dollar today vs dollar tomorrow!

I think a more wholistic way to think about deals, economically speaking, in the music world is to treat it more like an Net Present Value scenario that happens for M&A, where you’re asked to think about the value of everything the deal brings to you now and down the road in present year context, and then go from there. That includes those opportunity/non empirical costs, too.

author: Slow Hand
content:
This looks pretty great. Seems like it's got all of the features I want and then some fancy ones that I probably don't. Except the *Pro* version is a $5/month subscription 🙄. I'd rather just pay once for a license, rather than be dependent on their subscription for the rest of my life (SaaS strikes again).

I downloaded the (free) standard version to see if that'll do the trick and they want me to create a login account using FB/Google/email, etc. I bypassed that step and it turns out I can't even use the *Library view* feature without a user account. Perhaps this is because they also have fancy cloud sync and radio options, but that's way too elaborate for my needs. I just need a localized application that allows me to browse and play my files on my laptop.

🎺*sad trombone*

Anywho, it probably sounds like I'm moving the goalposts on you, but I really didn't think things would be this elaborate 😄. Thanks for a good suggestion. I just have an aversion to needless complexity, SaaS, and data collection practices as of late.

content:
My wife brought this up in her physics class (she’s a professor)  and some people who didn’t have one responded with “you hear voices??? That’s so weird” but she had one student who doesn’t have one but looked into it and it helped them understand why they have a hard time communicating ideas. Super interesting topic. Seems a majority of people have one especially If they’re creatively inclined

author: frankieharper
content:
Agreed on all fronts, we have seen work rewarded for its incongruousness countless times,  those are works that push a genre forwards, right  - the Billie example is great -  it’s the swathes of new music that is released in its wake that is telling, like when Billie went dark and soft spoken, pop when dark and soft spoken (another aggressively swooping generalisation there 👍) Someone comes along and shuffles the deck the rest of us try to follow suit 🃏 

Anyway If everyone was pushing boundaries all the time the marketplace (better term pending…indeed) would be an incoherent cacophony … and probably no one wants that. 

Personally, I do wish the scales were tilted somewhat more in favour of the obscure though. Matt paraphrased someone on a live ages ago (can’t remember who, sorry) saying “miss left” - if you didn’t catch that one the general gist was that you’d do better to derail the thing because it all got too weird as opposed to derailing it into the middle of the road. That stuck with me. 

Think I’ll get that tattooed on back of my eyelids… Miss Left… and on the rear of my neck for the back sofa dwellers to observe.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I think a good example of someone who represents that shift is the painter Mark Tansey. 

His paintings, while photo-realistic, don't derive their value from their resemblance to the real world. Instead their interest lies in their allegorical representation of people and places. Their unique value lies in the curation of ideas and the story, concept, or idea that they convey. They're telling a pretty sophisticated story under the surface.

Look at these paintings. There's no individual element of either of these that I couldn't render right now with Dall-E and photoshop my own remake together. But right now AI is nowhere close to creating such a cohesive visual composition with it's unspoken message. For now great art still requires a human operator with intention.

author: LAPhill
content:
Given the exponential levels in advancements we're already seeing in AI, I think anyone who thinks what we do can't be replicated in a few short years might be fooling themselves. But the thing that can't be replicated is the audience's connection, right? 

Growing up, when there was music I liked, I latched onto everything I could about the artist. I digested as much as I could about who these people were, what they looked like, what they wore, what guitar they played, etc. etc.. Audiences are still going to seek a connection with other people, it's human nature. I don't think we can ever replace that connection with an AI. Until falling in love with robots becomes normalized, and then we have bigger problems.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
**Keyboard players (and songwriters) of LWMR:** I need to seriously up my keyboard chops this year. 

I’ve been keyboard catting my way through life up to now - mashing out left hand root notes and RH triad shapes to get the rhythm and feel down, then fixing the notes / adding removing midi.  Fine by myself, but infuriating for anyone else in the room. 
 
I’m going to be in some (mostly writing) situations where that’s not going to cut it - I need to be much more fluent.

What are some efficient ways to get there? I’ve tried putting myself through the school of YouTube, but I haven’t found a course prescriptive enough to keep me focused and on track - just loads of disparate technique tutorials, and I don’t know what order to take them in. Also took some lessons, but cost and scheduling were unsustainable.

If it helps, my theory and reading were at one point strong and can probably be dredged back up if needed.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
But what about that oNe WeIrD tRiCk?? 

This is great, thank you, and describes exactly how I learned guitar, drums, and bass as a teenager. I do everything by ear, so I’m very comfortable with it.

My only hesitation with an exclusively ear learning approach is that I picked up all sorts of nasty habits and muscle memory on guitar that I’d need to check into a Chinese reeducation camp to unlearn.

I’m thinking it might be good to balance my natural inclinations with a bit of technique. Eat my vegetables, so to speak.

author: ALXCPH
content: Learn the basics really well, and learn how to communicate that. Let the YouTubers worry about the Lydian dominant flat 2 scale that will change your life, while you play and make music 🥳

content: One other random piece of advice - when we closed, we had a year of a home warranty included, which we thought was kind of silly at the time. Ended up being really useful. author: Slow Hand
content:
It's crazy to revisit all of the things that you've forgotten. Every once in a while I'll randomly pick a journal entry from fifteen years ago and discover that I had some *raw* feelings about an old girlfriend or someone who I might look back on fondly now. I was *super* pissed at them, or I was very immature in my thinking, or I was full of so much joy. Old emotional layers that have long-since been painted over and forgotten. You really get to see how far you've come. 

I don't dwell on those feelings, but observing the changes can be illuminating or humbling.

author: austenballard
content:
Which brings me to one of the biggest problems here. Healthcare. Even with good insurance, you will still be paying fairly substantial amounts of money for mediocre service. Your insurance network determines which doctors and hospitals you can go to. God forbid you get sick in the wrong state and need to go to the hospital - even if you have insurance, you might end up paying out of pocket if you're not covered at your point of care. Just don't get sick, and DEFINITELY don't have any chronic illnesses.This dysfunction applies to social services in general. Where things can be privatised, they have been, and where they haven't, they don't really work.

Then there are socio-cultural factors. Politics is a spectator sport, and Americans LOVE sports. Red team and blue team *hate* each other with a passion that is unmatched by political parties pretty much anywhere there isn't an active civil war on. Related but slightly different, race-based animosity is becoming more and more of a problem again the last few years after half a century of social progress. You will be able to avoid getting dragged into this by being an expat/resident alien/what have you, but you need to be aware that it's there. Another related issue to this is education. The vast majority of people in the US did not receive anything close to an adequate education to function in the modern globalised world, even if they went to college. This leads to a lot of parochialism and narrow-mindedness that spreads bad ideas fast.

content: Do big artists get additional payouts for landing a Grammy from their label? Like when a sports team wins the Super Bowl or World Series, they get bonuses...I gotta imagine something like this exists in the music realm.

author: Slow Hand
content:
In this instance it seems like the label's employees and artist would be aligned on voting in a way that wins their artist a Grammy, and that seems to be your point. But I don't think it matters quite so much.

If you want to get all game theory about it, there are other competing labels with voting members and artists of their own who are *also* pushing to attain a Grammy, come voting season. So I think your thesis that a label might try to increase their odds of winning by directing their employees to vote for *their* artist is counter-balanced somewhat by their label competitors probably doing the same.

The net result in this scenario would be that the gap between major-labels winning and indie artists winning is widened.

author: austenballard
content:
Maybe not 'universally useful', but even just in this present conversation, you, Cían, Beckley, and LAPhill, have all spoken to something that is *so* important. Even if your particular way of expressing it doesn't hit home for some people, the beauty of this server is that there are several of you speaking to similar values. 

As Cían just noted, his generation was one of the last waves to get that education. I got a little bit of it early on, but by the time I was working in this full time, it was attitude over aptitude everywhere I looked except for a few people who were lucky to get into the remnants of the previous system.

I guess this is partially me trying to express gratitude and appreciation, and also begging y'all not to hedge what you're saying, for the sake of the people coming up now, coming up through the mess.

author: ALXCPH
content:
Let the man sing if he wants to! 🤠 I’d argue that having some musical experience/intuition is 10/10 times not a bad thing. No matter what your job is in the music making process. 

Sure it’s not the engineers job to give advice. But if an artist asks when they are stuck with something being able to communicate at the same language is never a vibe breaker. I’d even argue it could enhance “vibes” or confidence, as long as what is being said makes contextual sense. 

It might be different where you are or at your level. But where I am (lower level 😂) who ever is in the room is involved. And if the process is being respected. I’ve been in so many sessions where I’ve recorded an artist and they ask for a harmony advice, or even if we are vocal producing, being able to quickly sing a line to quickly reference a point in the song is so much. Faster then having to look for it.

author: austenballard
content:
re: AI, but also other things
I was presented with an interesting query/opportunity today.

A prospective client would like to train an AI model on a deceased relative's vocal tracks and fill in the gaps on some demos so they can be released. They cited the Jay-Z Navy Seal copypasta and those excellent voice deepfakes that have been circulating on Twitter lately.

I said I'd have to look into exactly how to do it, but I'm also wondering about the quality of the final product and the ethical implications of it.

author: austenballard
content:
I feel like for me personally, actually executing this is a little too far outside my wheelhouse and maybe still a year ahead of where technology is right now. So to answer your earlier questions

1. I do care, I'm very interested in how this would play out technically and also about the broad implications of being able to essentially fake any singer

2. I'm in a position to turn down work where the compensation would not be worth the effort. This might be one of those cases.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: This has already happened in film, and the cultural (and contractual) implications are broad. For music I predict it is a 100% “solved problem” consumer product like face swapping in a year or two

author: Zach Hughes
content: I found it works really well as a tool to bounce ideas and approaches off of. Seems a far way off from doing the work for you for more complicated programs, but chat gpt + some critical thinking skills seems pretty powerful. The conversation threads are very meandering and I would have to rephrase instructions up to a half dozen times sometimes before it understood what I was trying to do. It would provide a suggestion, I'd do it and get an error, share the error, and it would correct itself. Several of those loops in a row. A buddy of mine who is a computer programmer was telling me about a peer of his who created a program that prompts chat gpt to write code then automatically feeds any errors back into chat gpt and it keeps looping and looping and looping until the code works. Pretty cool stuff

author: andrew_yv
content:
An interesting side note re: the psychoacoustic HRTF binaural sound localization discussion from yesterday’s live with @Nomograph Mastering :

I can’t find my source right now but if/when I do I will link it, anyways… A study was conducted wherein moulds were cast of several people’s pinnae (outer ears), these were placed on dummy heads with microphones inside the ‘ear canals’ and recordings were made through each of sound coming from a variety of locations. Some of the subjects were audio professionals and some were lay people.
When the subjects listened back to these recordings, there was significant variance in their ability to localize the sound sources. If I remember correctly, they were generally better at listening through their own pinnae than others were, and audio professionals were a bit better at sound localization in general, particularly in the traditional stereo field. However, the really interesting finding was that there were some pinnae that were universally better or worse. People actually had improved localization through someone else’s pinnae than their own, implying that although we are adapted to our own pinnae, there are material differences that make some better than others for localization of sound.
This is all from memory of reading something a few months ago, so I apologize if there are details that aren’t 100% accurate, but I assure you that the surprising bit is correct!

HRTF-based binaural mixes are not exactly the same thing as dummy head recordings, but I wonder if, in the creation of the aforementioned “baller individual HRTF’s” there might be a place for some optimization beyond the exact copying of an individual’s unique acoustic properties.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I can't stop thinking about this idea of "Why don't you play something that people actually like?"

I personally wrestle a lot with the idea of making music *for* other people. It's simply not very high on my list of priorities. I'd say I'm self-centered in how I approach making music. I'm out to make stuff that *I* want to hear. Things that aren't being represented elsewhere. Flavors I've never heard. I'm not aiming for a broad appeal, but I'm also not shying away from it. I'm just not much of a people pleaser in that regard. I'm in it for the discovery and the exploration and the pleasure of making something that excites me.

I think often about that Steve Jobs sentiment of "People don't know what they want until they see it." I think about that a lot. I trust that if I follow what feels good to *me* then I'll get something valuable out of it, and maybe it'll connect with others. If not, that's alright too. I'll know that I've made something that feels great.

I sometimes worry about this because I've always felt that it puts me at odds with a lot of people out here trying to make excellent records. Sometimes our goals will align, but I just don't feel motivated by the need to appeal to a lot of people and that can also make us diverge.

I guess what I'm trying to say is that there's a different kind of taste that I'm trying to cultivate. It's one that runs parallel to the kind of taste that is good at appealing to a large number of people. I feel as if I'm aiming at an entirely different goalpost from people playing the other game. I want to tickle people in a way that they didn't know they were capable of. That's what's thrilling to me.

author: Will Melones
content:
I get the impression that *your* taste is both incredibly diverse and highly refined, and while it may not align with the general public, it’s far from “bad taste”. I also don’t feel like someone who only likes to listen to the top of the charts has better taste, although you could say it’s empirically true that they do.

The fact that you’ve deliberately chosen to create something that’s not for everyone brings me back to the Conversations episode about the Service-Artisan Continuum. There’s no need to plant your flag on the service end of the spectrum if it doesn’t bring you joy and there’s food on your table. And there’s nothing that says you can’t serve clients by day and let creativity run wild by night.

If you’ve got something profound to say, it would be a damn shame to water it down for the public’s taste. I don’t think Radiohead would have had the impact that they did if they’d written another “Creep”.

author: peterlabberton
content: Trying to add to things and make a broader point without stepping in shit… I think I probably often come off as a Luddite, but I am truly not at all. I’ve always been a tech geek at heart. But I do deeply feel a resistance to tech that feels foisted on us, the general public, as it so often is just money making wrapped in the veneer of “progress” (or connection or whatever). Not said in this context with a political motivation, but, in capitalism we just have these things popping up all the time with no regard to whether we *want* them or whether they will make our lives *actually better*. And no, I don’t think an app that streamlines you getting your dog groomed or whatever is actually a substantive improvement in human life. So much stuff we have now actually makes us *less* happy and fulfilled, and so I always want to push back on the next new thing having had the hindsight of how these products have played out over the last two decades. (Thus ends a half-baked tech screed—sorry y’all.)

author: LAPhill
content:
I'm similar. My projects (active work drive) gets backed up hourly on an incremental scheme to a second internal drive. My system drive gets cloned nightly to another internal drive. If either were to fail, I can immediately swap over. The incremental projects drive has saved me countless times when I need to revert some changes or accidentally write-over a cue when I forget to save-as. 

When projects are done, they get backed up to two duplicate hard drives plus an NAS which has copies of all those hard drives but in one place. 

I haven't done the Backblaze thing yet, so I'm still at risk in the event of fire/flood/zombie attack.

author: Deleted User
content:
I think the bigger question is the lack of money in recording business. 

No tangible way of making real money off of it for most people except those who are landing sync placements, which can really be anyone. The way I see it is sync placement is fulfilling more of the utility aspect of art, while making records for people to listen to is a more artistic endeavor in service of the people that listen to the records. But the reality is that everyone’s streaming and that doesn’t pay. Even with the biggest success- it won’t make money correspondent to the level of success. 

Budget for record production is now more of a PR for their shows or tours. (As far as what I can tell)

So why in a sane mind would anyone spend money on making it other than for their own satisfaction? It’d be insane to see making records as business investment unless you’re really aiming for sync in mind. But then, what most of us fell in love with are the amazing records that we grew up listening to. Maybe a song from a movie occasionally, but probably not quite a track from sports spot nor a jingle. 

At this point, is there really a way to monetize real money from records other than sync? If there can be, what would that be?

author: Deleted User
content:
For sure- but within the “value you provide” there’s few different categories of it. and the main thing people consider first is “can I make that money back” 

I wish I was competent enough to make that money back for them, but at the same time my service is still service for them. The value I can actually guarantee to provide for them

The tough thing is I wouldn’t hire me for the money I charge from a clients’ POV because of the lack of ROI. I’d go DIY. But the thing is people are still wanting to hire me to do that work. It is a weird in between to be in. I don’t think I should be hungry enough to cut down on my price, but I also don’t think I have enough track record for people to justify spending the face value of my “labor” itself.

author: Deleted User
content:
Definitely something I’ve considered over and over. I mean, if I am too expensive then it really is the reason. I’m hearing this from those whom I’ve worked with before. 

But as you mentioned, you work in an industry that is more profitable as far as my knowledge (games). There isn’t much reason for them to question ROI. I don’t say this to invalidate your point, I think we’re just in a different playing field with different rules. 

If I lowered my price to $300 a song, I’d have no problem getting work. But I’d be making less. And of course maybe that’s what I need to do to get to the point I want to be, but I’d rather do it for no money and have more freedom in controlling my portfolio and having more potential long term returns. 

All of your points are valid points though

author: peterlabberton
content:
Alright frens, seeking… wisdom? Advice? A gig? (Lol.)

I’ve wanted to live in nyc my entire adult life and never have—it’s never made sense to do it career-wise and probably never really will. But every time I’m there I feel totally at home and happy and excited in a way I don’t anywhere else. I spent a summer there several years ago and always linger as long as I can whenever I can, have close friends there (not in music), end up there usually a couple times a year and relish it every time. I feel like I know it as well as is possible for never having been a resident.

I know the music biz there is pretty much defunct (at least compared to LA), and I really *really* don’t want to repeat the emotional and financial ruin that I experienced moving to LA and restarting everything 6 yrs ago… but from a non-career perspective it’s where I want to be.

All that said, I’m in it to fucking win it in LA for my career—though with an eye for sure on getting to a point where I can relatively comfortably make that move.

Any wisdom/experience on making a mid-career move like this from folks here? I’m 35 yrs old, some decent credits but not major traction yet, in a basically married but not actually married relationship with a school principal who is into the idea of a move there as well (though our finances are totally separate and I for sure need to earn!), no kids or desire/plan to have kids.

Any benchmarks/goals that might be reasonable to aim for before seriously starting to make moves on this? I’d do it tomorrow if I could, but would also stay in LA for 5+ more years no prob to set things up properly. Even open to things like a podcast (/radio?/other audio prod) gig to help smooth the transition if that’s reasonable to find and lucrative enough—but what I’m really looking for is how to think of this as a full time freelance record maker. Or if someone on here secretly is hiring for staff gigs at Electric Lady, plz lmk 😉

author: AJ
content: Further proof that identifying what unlocks a transcendent experience is... a very high burden of proof. One that's impossible to quantify.  One of my friends who wants kids said it was "an entirely emotional decision, not a logical one."  The justifications throughout this thread seem to align with that phrasing. I don't mean it in a disparaging way. More so to potentially show why there is such a discrepancy.

author: cian riordan
content: Wouldn’t push back against that experience in Burma, but I would push back by emphasizing the broader implications of parenthood through out the history and fabric of human existence. I don’t find the two comparable. Same with pet ownership. And I’ve had some amazing pets.

author: AJ
content: That's an oversimplification though. Just because at one point civilization needed to reproduce to survive.... the negative experience of modern day parents is invalid/outnumbered?

author: cian riordan
content: I can go to a three Michelin star restaurant and have the meal of my life but there will always be a few that catch a bad night

author: cian riordan
content: I’m not judging anyone for their decisions, mostly just digging into the justifications and to give insight from a place of experience.

author: AJ
content:
In my life and circles, I've seen more of the folks who have had a rough go. Which just turns the conversation into anecdote vs anecdote... and it's why anecdotes tend to be viewed as a questionable source of evidence.

I get your point though. There's no doubt that parenthood can be a truly enriching and unparalleled  experience. I'm truly glad that it has been like that for you, and sincerely wish that there was a guarantee (or evenhigh likelihood) of that bring replicated for every person. My issue has to do with saying that experience is the norm. Since we've established there's no clear way to quantify something like this, it's still a gamble at the end of the day. One that I can't fault anyone for taking one way or the other.

author: bobby k
content: I really think i struggle with conceptualizing time. I'm horribly optimistic, lol. (it's the ADHD) but this month is almost entirely attended sessions, shared with recorded sessions. in some cases people are flying in. i know i can balance it on my own, but what makes it uniquely difficult is that I have a mixing/coproducing project right now with a new client who insists that every second spent working on the project is attended. makes the calendar really difficult, since i was planning to squeeze it in between other work lol. that's definitely on me.

author: bobby k
content: facts man. needed to hear all of this. I think the problem happens when i try to squeeze in discounted clients around the full paying clients. I'm not missing deadlines for anybody paying the full rate. I think communication is key here -- don't do discounts & don't miss deadlines. Or continue to offer discounts to people with the clarity that deadlines need to be flexible, or not exist at all. also, part of what's pushing things around is personal stuff (house projects) that I didn't take into account when i booked my month.

author: shaunobi
content: Interesting convo. I think approaching music with more structure works for me, but I’m doing this part time and the dynamic is different. Most of the above sounds like project management issues, boring as that is. Not having a process to get paid? I mean - I’ve not gotten paid too. Have $250k we’re about to write off (and we’re not big enough for that not to hurt bad). Commit to something you end up not being able to deliver on? Having to tell clients “sorry” a lot? All sound like PM issues. And no, you can’t “solve” them, but with clear process and communication you can nudge a project towards more repeatability. I try to be up front and just very clearly and kindly lay out what I have seen before and consider “normal” (I mean, for me, I’m Portland of course). I find people like it when I bring the PM structure to the project… all depends on framing but I have good luck. And even some basic checklists I follow in initial meetings.

author: spectrummasters
content: So , I don’t really watch tv or anything just music related or science related docs . So (and I know it catches shade ) MWTM is my Netflix bro . Whether it’s downtime or I have a mix to do …..there’s so many great mixers on there , Shawn Everett , andy Wallace , tchad Blake , etc etc etc ….just hours of conversations I love to listen to about a song and what brought it to completion . Over the last year or two they’ve really stepped up the frequency of new content and the deals they have made with plug in companies and firms like samply and others , it nearly pays for itself to be fair . There’s a lot going for it imo , not least to mention …..it being a good consistent source from people who know their onions . Shawn Everett’s tape / match eq technique ….that jacquire king kick/bass vu meter balance thing , the andy Wallace ambient drum triggers ….schepps and his dual mono 1176 back bus 🚎 ….even al Schmitt in capitol mixing with no eq …..these have all been really inspirational ideas and convos I’ve seen from there . At this point they’ve got so much content on there bro ….and even the JJP don’t send me 48 kHz files convo 😂. What’s not to love

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Yeah the taylor thing might be the most interesting because it shows that having a strong fanbase can circumvent the usual cycles of promotion and release for an artist.

There are always outsider viral songs that catch fire (the oliver song) and song that get renewed life from a license or a viral trend (Kate Bush "Running Up That Hill"), but this seems generated by a groundswell of fanbase support. Obviously she's one of the biggest artists in the world and has a GIANT fanbase that can move culture, but it's fascinating to see.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
That’s what we get paid for. ¯\_(ツ)_/¯ Find the winning version of that idea, a way to make it work.

The other thing for me is setting expectations. Going into a project agreeing with the artist that “if we’re all happy, then we know it’s right.” Sometimes that’s just the 2 of us, sometimes more…. Obviously the more involved the more complicated the calculus. 

I’ve also made an artist happy, and then made myself happy and pitched that idea. Ultimately? We can’t win ‘em all.  And the more records I make the harder it is to fight for every idea I have. Honestly I’m wrong enough that it tempers that need anyway

author: Josh
content: Working on a track like that right now. Artist is in self discovery mode. Wants to throw away their entire fan base in rock music to do pop (which is pretty damn bold considering they have 2m followers on tiktok lol) and they told me they really want do the blinding lights thing. Which IMO is not a great idea as I think new artists making top 40 sounding tracks is kinda hard to pull off. And then you also have the fact that the whole 80s thing is feeling dated already. I think they need to go more indie since their voice suits the genre and their image won’t have to be tweaked too much and there should be a solid crossover of current fans, but I ain’t the artist here. So I just talked to them about it and told them I’m gonna take a few extra days and make sure this feels right for the above reasons and if they hate it that’s fine we’ll try again until it’s right. So I guess I’ll post his response today when he writes back. I think just being honest and being like “yo your idea is fire but BOTH of us can do a lot better” is the mindset needed for these sorts of scenarios.

author: Deleted User
content:
Late to the discussion, but I do think the word ‘talent’ is reductive and oversimplification of one’s complex combinations of innate character/traits. A lot of little things coming together is what makes up the ‘innate talent’. Things that give certain people a head start on different crafts can probably be analyzed into different components. While “either you have it or you don’t” can lead to defeatist thinking, I believe seeing them as a make up of different components can really bring out individuals’ best self. 

we all have our fortes, but not everyone is able to break them down and integrate the different strengths to create synergy. And the “talented” individuals are the ones who has integrated the different strengths, whether it was through deliberate discoveries or something that was given to them circumstantially. I believe rephrasing ‘innate talent’ to something like ‘natural qualities/traits’ can lead to more freedom and more useful perspective than “I could never be like X” - because of course you can’t, you are not X. 

Which brings back to what you were saying about the value of  journey over the prize

author: Slow Hand
content:
Does anyone here host their personal music collection in the cloud? I've got a massive collection that could get more love, so I figure I should look into a solution for engaging with it more often.

What I'm seeking is:
1) My entire 500gb collection hosted in the cloud
2) The ability to organize and catalog everything meticulously.
3) A desktop and phone app that will allow me to stream any of it at will. Like using Spotify on your phone.
4) Requires very little in the way of ongoing subscription costs.
5) (Edit) Ideally it would be open-sourced or robust enough that if the developer closes the tools will still function.

Does anyone know of any options that satisfy most of those needs?

author: Rollmottle
content: I think in this case, your best bet isn't necessarily hosting it in the cloud, it's hosting it locally somewhere in your house and exposing that server to outside access for yourself. Should be relatively easy to setup with a small dedicated Windows box or an old Mac Mini. the bottleneck will be the bandwidth of your home's internet and your mobile device connectivity.

author: f.ern___
content:
Can you all help me figure out the best solution here?

I have copied ALL (about 2.5tb) my files to my new LaCie external drive. I still keep all files on the old external drive in case I found anything has been damaged or broken during the move to LaCie.

The plan is to set up LaCie with Dropbox. I wiped my dropbox (that used to be a clone of the old drive) completely from the browser in order to set it up with LaCie.

Now, setting it up with LaCie it says that the file format (Exfat) isn't compatible and I need to change the format of the drive to HFS+ or APFS. I know that while changing the format the drive will be completely wiped. So before doing this I need to transfer all the files again to another location. I have two external drives, a macbook and an iMac. None of them have enough storage to store my 2.5tb folder.

Anyone have any idea of a good option other than to get ANOTHER external drive just to perform the move?

Is my best option to make a back up of the old drive to Dropbox backup, then wipe the drive, move all files from Lacie back to it, reformat Lacie, move all files back to Lacie, wipe the old drive and download the backup from dropboc back to it?

author: Josh Bowman
content: Biggest thing for any post audio mix- find out the delivery specs before you mix it (ie broadcast or web only, surround or stereo or both) and setup your mix so your music, dialog, and sfx masters are doing any buss processing and leave your master/mix buss clean aside from final limiter. You wanna make sure the stems add up to the final mix exactly if possible to avoid future shenanigans. Label things very clearly. Otherwise just make it sound good! A lot of ad/agency people like the dialog pretty hot I find.  I’m actually not sure what OMV means. But I’ve been out of the ad mixing game for a few years so maybe I’m blanking. Did it full time briefly tho and delivered a bunch of network stuff so 🤷‍♂️

author: Josh Bowman
content: I still have a toe in- but don’t go looking actively for post gigs. I’d say 85% of my work is music mixing, and the rest is tv/ad stuff when it comes up. but doing it full time as a staff engineer wasnt for me. Lots of “dog and pony shows”  for clients… annoying agency people, plus I was getting fat from all the catering 😂 If I ever pursue it actively again it will be on my own and not working for a studio. I mainly just don’t love working for other people I guess might actually be the take away

author: sixmissing
content:
Well, the issue that sparked this all is definitely the "hangs" I'm getting in Ableton and the "CPU overloads" in PT which on a machine this powerful made me really question what's up. 

So far I'm thinking the plan will be to remove the Afterburner and seeing what the performance is like and what the Pool Allocation is looking to be. Second thought would be to reposition the OWC card. And the third thought may be to step down the OWC 8M2 to a 4M2 in an eight-lane slot. It could be that the 8M2 is just pulling too damn much.

author: Zach Hughes
content:
Question for the group: 
I have a few artist friends who have both been told by different music industry folks to consider starting fresh under new names. Their rationale seems to be that labels and other potential team members (booking agents, managers, etc...) want to hop on the fresh new promising HOT artist stonk :stonks:  rather than work with an artist who has been consistently releasing music for years but whose catalogue on streaming platforms is dominated or overrepresented by older works. That they are turned off by middling success after many attempts over time.

Would a truly amazing *undeniable* record have a better shot at commercial success under a new artist name with no previous middling successful tracks or nah? At what point, if ever, would it be beneficial for an artist to kill an artist project and start fresh under a new name with new music?

author: Zack Hames
content:
But i get the worry from the artist. But unless it’s something really being repeated by tons of trusted people…focus on the new music and move forward. 

Trying to articulate it…if you have an artist name that REALLY sucks, and almost no one reacts positively to it, you’re getting nowhere, etc etc…maybe there’s something there. Having your name be “DJ Dog Shit” may not land even if it’s your truth

author: SoundsLikeJoe
content:
Catalog buyouts are a trend.  My outlook on this is that the hedgefund managers are in over their head.  A few puchases may break even or profit, but...   MANY are bad buys.  Rod Stewart for $100 Million? Terrible investment. 

https://www.musicbusinessworldwide.com/iconic-artists-group-raises-1bn-acquires-rod-stewart-catalog/

author: Matthew The Cooke🎄🎅🏻
content: Then again, you never know when a past hit might become reintroduced to the new generations. Rod already had minor moments like this with „Young Turks“ being similar to Blinding Lights and also featuring prominently in GTA: San Andreas, which is still popular amongst gamers to this day

author: BatMeckley
content: What is your basis for this thinking? Are you aware of the average income of Rod Stewart’s catalog over the last 5 years? Do you think they used too high a multiple?

author: Matthew The Cooke🎄🎅🏻
content: Ngl there‘s a least a handful of rod stewarts songs that I‘d put in the „timeless“ category without blinking an eye

author: SoundsLikeJoe
content:
The value in ALL pop culture is, in general, front loaded.  Across his entire career Rod is reported as earning $300 Million from all recordings, tours, and etc. He squeezed the best out of it then. Being "featured" in GTA or any other modern revival is worth something, but it's not going to net anything near original hit earnings. Especially with royalties still dwindling, in general (aka smaller pie than pre-2004 and more content dividing it up). 

Rod played the game well and is loving this.  I don't think they will roupe.

author: sethearnest
content: What'd be your guess on high-side multiple for an artist like Rod Stewart? 20x? The multiple-vs-timeline math is so interesting to me on these legacy catalog deals.

author: SoundsLikeJoe
content:
That's the thing...  I think the earnings of 20th century recordings are going to diminish as the generations die.  Currently catalogs from popular music of the 1940s and 50s...  this peer group is almost extinct.  In 20yrs those catalogs will not have a multiple value, but it will be a diminished return (less than 1x) ....  not a growth (greater than 1x multiple).  

If Rod Stewarts catalog generated $300 Million during the height of his popularity (including tours)...   The value of his catalog over the decades would be a fraction of that.  To recoup $100 Million would require $10 Million x 10yrs in ROYALTY alone to break even. He (reportedly) earned $7 Million from his music in 2013.  So the ROI couldn't profit until 2037 (without touring income).  His fanbase will be effectively extinct by 2040 and it's going to be hard to break 1980s trends on future generations.  You'll get some novelty bumps but I don't know how many Kate Bush moments investors can bank on.  Seems more lottery and less solid investment

author: BatMeckley
content:
I mean, im not 100% speculating because I’ve gone through this with my friends (current) and with my pop (legacy). Basically they look at an average of the last 5 or so years, and then do a multiple of 10-15. Certain huge legacy names (Dylan, etc) they’ll go higher because it’s a loss leader to attract other artists to the fold. Numbers were bigger a before the last year or two before interests rates went up, because the catalogs were basically being bought by borrowed money.

As matt said, Irving has a long track record of making really smart business decisions both for himself and his artists, so I was curious if @SoundsLikeJoe had specific information regarding the financials of Rod’s catalog or if he was speculating.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
Not sure where to put this so we’ll start here and maybe we can migrate it if it lands in any way

Had a great call last week with @Josh. We talked about a bunch of stuff but one of the themes we explored was the idea that one needs a “portfolio” of slick & great sounding work to get hired

Once you’ve decided that then it becomes the focus, and changes the way things feel and the way decisions about time, who you work with etc get made. Concepts like “I’ll suck it up and work for free but *then* I will have a singular “good track” for my portfolio”. Of course there are exceptions but it feels to me that there’s something very constricting and materialist about this way of being in the world. There can be a tension between what the artist wants or what the song wants to be and what makes you look “good” in your portfolio - they want mono and grimy but you want wide/lush/impressive

In our jam I proposed a kind of thought experiment, an end of the line or extreme of the “need portfolio” way of thinking…

So let’s say you are here, a young writer, producer, mixer. You’ve been doing it 3 or 4 years. You feel that one of the reasons you are not getting hired, getting shots or getting paid well is that there isn’t a body of work for a potential client to judge you by. Ok, here’s comes the magic trick. I’m going to grant you a genie wish portfolio! 5 killer tracks with  great collaborators. Not hot 100 #1 but the kind of work that you really feel would represent you best in the world. Boom. There it is…

So now what? You get some DMs and sessions start happening. But you’re not ready. You’re not fit for game day. You’re in over your head, and don’t have the fluency, the experience, the reps and the humblings that build a great music business pro. In short you’re not ready for the opportunities the genie wish portfolio granted you

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: You can have zero work history, zero expertise, zero relationships and have a loving dedication to the craft
