author: Deleted User
content:
I love this angle. 

another thing people say often, “remember you exist”. especially when you live in your mind a lot, we start disconnecting with our physical beings. Forgets to eat, drink water, sleep, and breathe

author: Deleted User
content:
when we think of how language and words get created out of necessity, we can also use that to work our way back and analyze why certain words become popular or lost its use over time. especially with internet, language started driving a good part of pop culture. we don’t want the words to limit our expressions, we want words to enable more articulate expressions and thinking -> both are happening from what I see. 

Why does the new generation feel the need to minimize and maximize everything? Why can’t we spend our effort into exploring everything in between? 

Do everything in between come with labels or do they become lengthy sentences and paragraphs? 

I think the answer to all of this is complexity of life that us humans brought onto ourselves. That is the cycle of “why older generation can’t understand newer generations”

older generations make the world “better” - (technologies and advancement of civilization & cultural understanding ) for the new generation. But what this “better” comes with many times though, is complicated soup of mess. This causes overload in young people’s minds trying to make sense of this world. Many or most don’t have the patience to keep on trying to explore the nuances in between. Or can’t afford to take the time / invest the energy to do so. I believe the lack of dimensions in the new generation’s language is a product of this. 

@NoahNeedleman said older, less nuanced in opinion & younger, less nuanced in language. I believe both are true for both younger and older people *if they ended up giving up trying to dig deeper to explore and ponder on “everything in between”*. I don’t think age has anything to do with it. It’s just that the disparities between those who had the patience for nuance vs those who gave up trying become more apparent as people get older.

author: Josh
content: I think it’s as simple as two groups of people who think they’re communicating effectively. Some people bust out the thesaurus to say exactly what they mean, some people find that exhausting so they use common language to make sure they’re understood.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I would suggest that it’s not that simple at all. There are people who speak with less resolution because of limited IQ or education, others who choose language to meet a target audience, others still who use language to signal in group/out group or status. There are those who wish to confuse and distort facts, to manipulate etc etc. all of this rides on top of trends, culture, generational differences etc

author: Deleted User
content:
I also want to mention something I learned about recently, and that is borderline intellectual functioning. People with IQ between 71-84 are not categorized as disabled and you won’t notice them in everyday life, but it can be as common as 1 out of 7 people. They won’t be able to get a disability check, but will have harder time living than others with average or higher intelligence. 

It gave me a new perspective on why I can’t seem to communicate with or understand certain people, and that it needs to be approached with empathy whenever possible. 

+ poverty can affect people’s brain development. not only from the lack of education but the stress that goes on in the household due to poverty can affect children’s brain development. Truly unfortunate viscous cycle…

author: spectrummasters
content: I really enjoyed reading this . Another aspect of language I find fascinating that has been highlighted to me by friends of mine who think of themselves as shamanic but others might call kooks …..the meaning / reason  of why certain words were “invented “ . If we can agree that thoughts become things by the use of words ( I have an idea 💡, I communicate this by the use of words ) the idea is received and expanded on in the listeners mind . They add to the idea . We communicate these ideas in dialogue with bankers and engineers and this idea is manifested in the physical world . A thought becomes a thing . Imho this can be described as magic . 🪄 so words are indeed powerful , they are in fact magical . No surprise then that ….in school we are taught that the process of creating words from letters is called ???? Spelling . My favourite understanding of words and numbers is the 5per cent nation and their supreme alphabet and mathematics . If I meet someone who knows the supreme mathematics it’s like meeting a lost member of your tribe

author: SoundsLikeJoe
content: Nah.  It's a core function of capitalist economics.  Without counter-weights,  the theoritical end game of all markets is a single provider of all services. That's what the board game tries to illustrate.  Specialization is only valuable for individuals.  Corporations (especially those with shareholders) must continuously grow and expand profit centers.  It's why Amazon doesn't just sell books anymore...  and grocery stores start pushing their private label brands...  or fast food chains earn more from real estate than from selling food.

author: Matthew The Cooke🎄🎅🏻
content:
I find it really interesting that for instance in music streaming there are various streaming platforms that pretty much do exactly the same thing (provide all, or most of recorded music at a cost). There might be slight discrepancies (spotify not having Joni Mitchell/Neil Young catalogue until recently) but they offer essentially exactly the same product so they have to convince consumers from a different perspective („we pay artists more, we sound better, we have spatial audio etc.“) 
And on the other end of the spectrum you have the complete shitshow that is streaming movies/series on demand where you have to have like 5 different subscriptions bankrupting you just so you can watch your favourite movies. It‘s interesting how those two offer basically the same thing (access to entertainment on demand) but have developed drastically different

author: Deleted User
content:
I loved the analysis, I had thoughts about a few points he mentioned. 

1. Paradox of climbing up to the highest level
Could Michael Jordan have become Michael Jordan if it wasn’t for the feeling of someone chasing behind him to become one of the greatest of all time? There is only one Michael Jordan, and can anyone else be that one and only without going through what he has put himself through? 

2. Acceptance vs Dissatisfaction
I think the dilemma here is between satisfaction and acceptance vs beating. I don’t think one or the other is necessarily the answer, but I think a good place to be is finding acceptance in where I am right now while still beating on myself to keep on improving to the highest level I could be. 

3. Potential
This is a crazy concept to me. Who is anyone to evaluate someone’s ceiling of improvement? Spider defined the meaning of ‘potential’ perfectly in my opinion. Not his exact works but; one’s capable/willing range of adaptation. Did the professor in Whiplash really expand his students’ potential in this sense? 

4. Abusive Internal voice 
I love how he saw the professor as our internal voice. And it made perfect sense to why I was so obsessed with this movie and the character. He was myself to me all along. I went back and forth over and over on whether this relationship was worth it to either of them. I think perhaps limited to this particular two people, because they had common goals/interests and made it happen. 

5. Joy?
I feel that this is the most simple and complex out of all things here. Can anyone NOT experience any frustration while trying to get better at something? If the answer is no, is there a way to better manage the frustration? 

Pursuit vs Result, our brain works the most consistently when we look towards pursuit. Result feels good but not for long, but what if the result meant more than just the goal being achieved? What if the “result” portion leads to another pursuit after another?

author: Matt Huber
content:
So, first of all, thanks to the buds here who appreciate what I’ve posted in the past.

Second of all, my thoughts on this:
 
I have a personal rule that I will NOT post anything that feels like EFFORT or out of a motivation to game the algo. If I’m “making content” and notice that I’m doing so out of a place that is less than genuine, I will just delete and move on. 

For me, the “mix tips” thing came out of a sincere place of excitement and passion. I would, as a growing mix engineer, stumble upon something that excited me, and I would find myself wanting to turn around to the people in the room to share…well, there’s almost never anyone in the room with me. So, I channeled that passion and excitement in a genuine way to share with the small community of mixers, mastering engineers and producers that I knew on IG. 

At the beginning of my career on to the middle of my career, that became a very fruitful source of business for me - people who followed me on IG, who enjoyed my posts, and began to view me as someone who MIGHT know a thing or two about mixing. 

As my career has developed and my clientele has growing, that has become less important, but it was absolutely pivotal in helping me build a deep bench of great clients, both indie and signed. 

But…I NEVER did it for that reason. It was always (and continues to be) a genuine result of my passion for what I do.

author: Joel "Roomie" Berghult
content:
The photo example showed that catering to a bad metric is bad, not that catering to robust metrics is bad.

A truism is a statement that is obviously true, while Goodhart’s law is deeply nuanced and context dependent, and was not intended to be broad ranging in its inception.

author: cian riordan
content: Figure out what you want out of the project and work towards that. If you're doing it for money, do what it takes to be a pro and get it over the line. You want them coming out the other end realizing they might have been unreasonable and that you were doing everything in your power to accomodate. If you're doing the project for fun -- and it isn't fun -- then find a way to communicate that kindly and bow out.

author: Zach Hughes
content:
This video brought to mind a highlight from a recent read: "When you’re invested in a goal, being doubted by experts is a threat. They may be credible, but since they don’t recognize your potential, they’re not coaches who will help you improve. Their disbelief quickly becomes your insecurity. It shatters your confidence and stifles your growth. That’s a self-fulfilling prophecy. But the research suggests that when they come from an uninformed audience, low expectations can become a self-negating prophecy. You’re motivated to shatter their confidence that you won’t succeed. Samir calls it the underdog effect." - Adam Grant, *Hidden Potential*

Also related are the concepts of the Pygmalion and the Golem effect in social psychology. Where low / high expectations for students / beginners can become self fulfilling prophecies. Begs the question how do you find the balance between being honest / truthful with folks just starting out without significantly undermining their intrinsic motivation and confidence?

author: Dereck Blackburn
content: Without telling the story about two years ago I had my first “bad” client. They were in the middle of building a house (unknown to me) and decided this would be a great time to manage that project but also make a record with me. Because I was under the impression that studios were financially out of reach for this person, I worked at half my usual rate and allowed them to give me a small deposit to start working together. MY MISTAKE.  Every time they came to the studio they were stressed out and unfocused. I did my best to make their home recordings sound great but there was very little good communication and it ended up that when I sent a mix over, I got a 8 paragraph dump about how nothing is working out, the mix was nothing they would ever release, then proceeded to call me a bunch of names - just taking out all their frustration on me. I zipped up all the work I had done so far and sent it over saying I think it’s best if we went our separate ways, you can do what you like with what we’ve done so far - I don’t want any credits at all. Since then it’s motivated me to make sure that I am following my process and OVERcommunicating every step of the way to be sure there’s no confusion about the work I do with clients. I learned that this former client bad mouthed me to a few artists and I lost some work because of it. Eventually work got back to normal and it’s been steady rocking ever since. The memory of how I felt motivated me everyday to be better than the day before, no joke - I know there’s going to be bad days here and there but I’ll be damned if I ever let someone take advantage of me like that again.

author: itaylerner
content:
Education question for you all!

My partner is looking to get a masters degree in something music-related (mostly just to get a salary bump), she’s a music teacher and an amazing singer/songwriter/producer.

Wondering if anyone has insight on particularly solid programs for music production or something related? 

We live in the Pacific Northwest but she would totally travel elsewhere in the country or international if it was a good fit

I know a lot of music production programs are really not worth it so she’s super open-minded as to what the focus of the program could be

Open to any insight / advice!! 🙏

author: Slow Hand
content:
Interesting question. As someone with a diploma from a music program I don't know that it was the best investment in the long run. 

Don't get me wrong, I learned a *lot* and got a great education, but it was a lot of money to spend for learning to make records, and I'm not sure - with hindsight - that I'd do it the same way. There are other programs/paths that could give great results, so I would advise others to heavily consider if it's the best use of their money.

That said, it sounds like the formal qualification (the diploma) is a big motivator here. Is that correct?

author: itaylerner
content: Yeah that's correct - she's also looking into research-based music education programs. Her primary motivator is the diploma but it would be ideal to study popular music education in an environment where she could also hone skills and knowledge in modern music making and exist in a community of people with similar interests.

author: itaylerner
content: It's a public school so they pay more for any additional level of education.

author: peterlabberton
content:
I wonder if it’s worth looking at degrees more in the education field than in music?

I have a degree in the humanities and most of my family is in academia. I despair the ROI-centric approach to education these days—there’s value far beyond money in getting to dive deep on a subject. But I think if she’s mostly looking to get to the next column over on their pay schedule, there are perhaps other options that may even be better for her career.

author: itaylerner

author: Slow Hand

If someone asked me today about how to get experience making records I'd probably recommend a combination of paid private study/tutorship from someone with first-hand experience, hands-on learning, and a resource like this server to fill in the cracks and shine a light on the real-world application.

author: bookchild
content: I was at an event in an Irish University lately and I let someone try to talk me into doing a Masters online (not music-related - actually not anything in particular). She was selling microcreds.ie but I’m sure every college in every country is doing similar. Within limits, you can build your own course. Basically 60-120 ECTS (standard European college credits) equals a Masters and apart from that all you have to do is get someone in a university to agree that the modules you choose make sense together. People in Universities are in the business of selling qualifications to you, so they will probably want to help. If the piece of paper is the most important thing, it might be an option.

author: Rukie
content:
the word “emotion” needs a better definition sometimes in the space we are in. 

Emotion isn’t necessarily something that you are always aware of “feeling”. Some reactions are merely state of mind, until it is given a name. Some reactions are visceral because of what the chemicals do to our body. 
sometimes, it’s neither visceral nor label-able. Which makes us assume that it’s not a feeling or emotion. But can we really differentiate emotions and thoughts? What exactly would differentiate them? 

On the other hand, there is music that pushes more, versus music that pulls more. 

Just like how audio is bipolar, we can’t have connections just be a one way communication. Tame Impala is a type of music that pulls. You don’t know why, but you just want to know “what was that song? I GOTS TO FIND OUT”. 

Push is more like… “I can’t unhear it” a lot of Pop hits are push with some pull factor. 

the ones that make you bummed out that you couldn’t shazam are ones that pull you in. it’s a slight push that gets you listening, and the rest of it is just pulling you in. (my own reaction when I first heard tame impala and couldn’t find out whose song it was)

Culturally, I think the love for (dreamy sound) can be explained with a desire to escape reality. 

So really, the emotional reaction is that “it transports me into a different space”. My theory on “why do people like that feeling?” is that many people aren’t happy with the reality of our lives because of economy and what not. And the idea of “escape from reality” became more and more a viable thing for us to want after experiencing digital devices and internet.

author: EliHeathMusic
content:
With credits, is there a general consensus or definition on the distinction between  "producer" and "additional production" or is it always a case by case thing? Had a song I worked on (finished the production and did the mix) come out today. At the beginning of the project I had asked to be listed as a producer and mixer but realized when it came out, that the artist had listed himself as the producer and me as additional production/instrumentation, and mixer. The artist is a really good and longtime friend and I am going to just talk to him and ask that he fixes the credits (and will start making written agreements before all of my projects) but I am curious if there is any broader context that could help how I approach the conversation? 

Not super critical to the main question but here are some specifics of my situation: Artist wrote the song, and recorded some basic tracks (drums, vox, guitar). We then worked on it in my studio and I played more instruments (bass, guitars, keys, lap, steel, percussion). We then finished it remotely a few months later. Sent the Ableton production session back and forth a few times times and then I prepped and exported the files myself and mixed it in Protools. And I had to do what I would consider a fair amount of heavy lifting in the mix: song was pretty complicated and recorded at home so I ended up do doing a lot of clean up, some tuning, and a lot of sound shaping and effects. All that to say, this case feels pretty cut and dried but I am curious to know what types of work would appropriately fall under “additional production” and what is standard in the industry. Thanks!

author: EliHeathMusic
content: The main reason I was planning on bringing this up with the artist is because we had initially agreed on roles and credits before I started working on the song (just not in writing because he's a close friend and it didn't seem necessary at the time).  And I agreed to do the project and set my rate (offered a pretty significant friend discount) under the premise that I would be credited in a certain way. I totally understand that some artists want to be the only producer on their projects and if I was ghost producing a song for someone I would have probably charged a lot more. Either way, that doesn't seem like something that an artist gets to decide on their own after the song has already been completed. In my case I think it was just an honest mistake or he forgot or we had a miscommunication and its an easy thing to check in about and resolve. But it just made me wonder going forward if there is a clearer distinction between the two roles.

author: Zakhiggins
content:
I was recently inspired after going to the cinema to see *A Complete Unkown*, the movie memoir about Bob Dylan; partially by Bob's story, but also by Timothy Chalomee's performance as Bob. All of the shots of him performing in the movie were fully live - which is an impressive feat by itself - but even more impressive that he apparently wasn't much of a musician before making the movie. I didnt know much about Timothy before this, so I watched his interview with Zane Lowe on Apple Music's YouTube channel. One thing I found really interesting was how available he made himself to learning the role. For example, he didn't turn his phone on for 3 months straight. Got me thinking about how much I can get distracted during the day, and how these distractions can get in the way of me actually giving 100% to the art that I'm working on. I'm sure you all can imagine how the distractions in your own life can effect your work. Might be TikTok videos, might be discord, might be lusting over getting new converters or monitors or guitars, etc, you get the idea. So I guess what I'm saying here is that if I want to compete with the best, maybe I have to understand how to impliment systems in my life that allows me to be more available to the things that I am working on. I want it to be like lifiting a heavy weight at the gym - at the bottom of a heavy squat, you've no choice but to focus on pushing the bar back up with good form, cos that think will break you otherwise. There's a certain thing that happens in your brain when you're forced to only think about one thing for a prolonged, or even short period. It's something akin to meditating. 

I guess what I'm asking is if anyone has ever given this subject any thought before, and if anyone has ever done anything to get better at these things? I'm still not sure if all this only makes sense inside my own head.

author: Zach Hughes
content:
Oh man ngl I'm fascinated by this topic. I have been diving deep into this subject and what it means to me over the past couple of years. It started with books. These contributed to a paradigm shift in my world:

*Slow Productivity* by Cal Newport
And subsequently researching the *Slow Food* movement out of Italy which largely inspired Newport's book

author: Zach Hughes
content:
___
"The first layer of your attention, he said, is your spotlight. This is when you focus on “immediate actions,” like, “I’m going to walk into the kitchen and make a coffee.” You want to find your glasses. You want to see what’s in the fridge. You want to finish reading this chapter of my book. It’s called the spotlight because—as I explained earlier—it involves narrowing down your focus. If your spotlight gets distracted or disrupted, you are prevented from carrying out near-term actions like these.

author: kieronmenzies
content: Me personally, Yeezus was the last album that I was super moved by and I've never really had much of a desire to revisit any of his stuff, as brilliant as it is (though I might try after this convo). But on this topic, I find it hard/impossible to completely 100% enjoy a piece of work after the artist has done something disagreeable, taken a public downfall or occasionally if I had a negative personal experience with them. Even though I might intellectually appreciate the beauty of the work, my heart just feels a slight bit of ick -- akin to that feeling of trying to enjoy a meal that you know is super delish but you burned your tongue on a hot cup of coffee the day before. So I’ll just end up choosing to listen to something else instead. This also makes me intensely appreciate my past experiences with the art. I don’t think I’ll ever enjoy it the same way again but I’m so glad I was able to completely enjoy Puff Daddy productions, R. Kelly songs, Woody Allen’s movies, Bill Cosby’s comedy, and Kanye West’s early albums when they were coming out and having their day. I’m resolved that it was a time in my life and in the universe and that time might be over now. Kinda like the ex-girl that you remember fondly but would never ever ever go back to.

author: BatMeckley
content:
I think there’s a danger in assuming those that are successful didn’t have it hard.
2 quick stories that have shaped my career:

very early on when I was recruited to play in a band in Australia. Sold my car, got rid of my apartment, and flew out to Melbourne. Band had a moment but I got tossed out just as the song was going number 1. Had no money to get home, no where to stay, and was literally 23 living on our producers couch in a country about as far from home as possible. And I called my pop, basically telling him how bummed/scared/fucked I was. And he goes “you know, I just got off the phone with **** (a very famous actor friend of ours). If there’s anyone that had it all, you’d think it was him. Big career, wife on the cover of sports illustrated swimsuit edition, fans everywhere. But it turns out his Dad just passed, his wife is cheating on him, and if this new show doesn’t get picked up they might lose the house they just bought. EVERYONE has their share of crap they have to deal with, give or take, no matter how easy it looks from the outside. Life isn’t about what happens to you, it’s about how you deal with what happens to you. Figure out a way to make the most of what’s going on”. For some reason, knowing that EVERYONE’s life sucks to some degree, was immensely helpful in getting me back on my feet.

The other was a year or two later, when I started tuning vocals for Rob Cavallo. One of his wrecking crew of session musicians had been in a band with a huge hero of mine, who had sadly took his own life mid way through making his second record. I asked the guy if there was anything he could tell me about working with said hero, and he said “he was the best musician I’ve ever met. Whatever instrument you played he was better at it than you were within 10 minutes of picking it up. But he seemed to think he was the only guy that ever got a raw deal from the music industry”.

author: Chad Rodgers
content:
I like the idea of agency as practice. A really talented artist I've been working with recently is young and very new to the industry. They don't know much about being a recording artist, how publishing works, how the business side of things goes down, or what kind of a team they need to build around themselves etc. So I suggested some further reading, shared some of my experience and gave them some tips (as I always try to do with younger artists, to do what you say @spectrummasters and support them). Their response was 'Honestly my manager can do all of this for me, I just want to focus on the music, it's all too complicated and goes over my head'.

So what can you do 🤷‍♂️ 

This, I guess, is one example of someone who could really do with some personal agency. If their manager walks, they're a bit fucked. There are thousands of other young artists out there who will be actively educating themselves on the business, joining Discord groups like this for furthering their networks and education, and proactively looking at how the arc of their career can be navigated 'by them', not 'to them'. This kind of proactive attitude would immediately gift the artist I'm working with a leg-up, giving them an advantage over peers, with a higher chance of success. The more they do this, the more control they have over their career. It's a win-win.

So back to a more definition-based view of the term 'agency', or like I said before 'nous', a lot of folks could do with more of it and I totally see both sides of this conversation. It's good to explore the cultural and societal effects on something like this as nothing exists in a vacuum, but on a general, everyday level, it's SUPER useful and important to try and exercise control over outcomes. Is the opposite of agency apathy?

author: Brian Reynolds
content: I just want to make music that resonates. At different stages of my life. But especially around 15. Music was an escape. I would find songs that encapsulated exactly as I was feeling, and made me feel less alone. Or gave me words for feelings I couldn't properly express myself yet. The idea of playing that role for someone is intoxicating. I HAVE to do it. And yes making money of my music is a goal. But right now making 30k a year of my music would be life changing. I could have holidays and the middle of my days during the week back. And not running my body physically at the edges constantly

author: spectrummasters
content:
…yeah the independent producer community backlash has been growing for the last few years against him already . 

There’s a discussion in my wheelhouse culture at the moment (london street music creators ) about whether the real value  of a project is about numbers / popularity or moving the culture . The further the “industry “ progresses into AI , for the sake of numbers , imho the more the value moves into cultural / underground art . 
Street music stories are about a common or represented experience . We want to hear the street poetry

If you take timbos hiphop midlife crisis and combine it with soulless number based work , I don’t think it’s likely to resonate with the culture .   This is why I think he’s likely to catch an L . 

Even the new clips release is being met with , okay you’re 50 and still rapping about coke ? 

….there an element of corny creeping in as the genre ages 

On the flip side, I think a whole new genre is gonna happen soon . Where’s there’s yin there will be yang

author: spectrummasters
content: I feel that the more the business of music devalues the price of labour of the human musician , it will have a counterintuitive impact. The real musician becomes the rarity . I see AI and social media driving out fair weather “musical creators “ and leaving behind only those who do it cause they have to , not because they “can “ . So the less people can make a living out of making music the more I see music returning to the hands of true , passionate artists . When you can’t afford to do it …..but you can’t stop . That’s the art that’s important . I think we are moving there

author: andrew_yv
content:
Sony set me up with it for Mike’s BH room in both stereo and atmos. It’s the first spatialization tech that has impressed me. Not sure how quickly I would reach for it in stereo, but I can confidently pre-mix things in atmos with it, and with some loss of detail, it really does sound like *those speakers in that room through my ears*

Process is pretty cool and elegant. They put electret mics in your ears, record IR sweeps of each speaker in your room through them, then put headphones on, record IR sweeps of those, then have some sort of sum/difference algo that translates it all.

When you get measured, go for relatively high SPL sweeps. We tried it at a few different levels and at lower levels, the result was pretty unimpressive. You can also go too high and distort, but worth trying a couple times if they’re game, which I’m 100% sure they will be for you

Tons of great channels for tangible action items, which is fantastic cus that’s what one really needs to move forward, but I also feel a need to connect with others that are where I’m at and giving it our all in this ‘trenches’ stage of building a career in music/audio.

or, is that just a general topic and this is the place, cus all musicians can relate? 
: P

author: Gabriel Tyranny
content:
Yeah that makes sense. Thanks for the advice. The question is never ‘should I persist’ - Which is almost why I’m afraid. I feel like no matter what her and I are both locked in, and when someone else trusts me like that I want to be sure I can do my part in giving back in that dynamic.

It’s hard to weigh short term wins/losses vs long term wins/losses at this time cus I’m in the thick of it.

When reflecting, I know I always did my best to communicate as honestly as I could in every moment, and was transparent about every decision and my thought processes along the way. I’ve had many wins, but going a long period without financial wins has made me question the judgement I have when navigating everything.

“Winning” to me is a culmination of things that can be summed up as living authentically while positively contributing to the world and lives of others. It helps fight of the tendrils of negativity I feel coming from so many angles of the outside world, especially in the last decade.

I don’t exactly know what I’m asking. Or want. I’m looking to process these feelings and synthesize them into a new level of awareness as I move forward with what I’ve learned being integrated into my subconscious.

Sometimes being around others, or hearing their experiences and takes, helps me get angles of things in a way that I can piece together for a rough draft of what will become the lesson that I carry with me moving forward, regarding this topic at this time.

author: spectrummasters
content:
For sure , I completely agree with you that weight should be given to the apparent findings of rigorous work . Absolutely. I also think it is a disservice to all of us if people are discouraged to approach unpopular ideas and ask questions about them for fear of mockery . Or that newcomers simply accept dogma of the day . That is anti science . Our greatest scientific discoveries usually shatter the pre existing concencus view (for the benefit of all ) Newtonian physics gives way to relativity, classic physics to quantum etc . 
As you will know Cian , science is not about proving  things with absolute certainty it deals in probabilities . 
Science works to bring us to a place where we can say p< 0.05 . So imho we shouldn’t loosely  present science as absolute and unchanging truths in service of quietening and/ or deriding people and/or their ideas . 
Imho what is being missed in so doing is that it is those who dare to challenge dogma,  who challenge and constantly review empirical evidence that bring us the new discoveries . My point is less about discrediting null tests and more about celebrating people who dare to challenge dogma . And that science is also in support of those people . If young people / newcomers are to chase a few rabbit holes and cul de sacs for the will of exploration and finding things out for themselves , who would deny them that ? Those who probably did much the same thing themselves at the start of their journey into audio ? It certainly appears to be true that under observation and current technology the daws sum. Yet we are also at a moment in science where mathematicians are suggesting our reality may only be an avatar and time as a concept is outdated . In mind of these leading edges of scientific thought someone as clever as Jon challenging a consensus on nulling may or may not be genius . But laughing at or dismissing his and Aaron’s and many others sense on it …..doesn’t serve any of us imho .

author: Slow Hand
content:
If you zoom in on the yellow suit, every one of those images are composed of hand-sewn beads. And that's not even the most intricate example. If you zoom in on the purple suit that is an entire three-dimensional castle that hangs from the front. If you were able to peer inside the windows you would see curtains on the interior, and at the drawbridge, a small horse emerging. The attention to detail is off the charts.

The splendor is overpowering. It took me 90 minutes to make my way through everything. The deeper you look, the better it gets. It's awe inspiring stuff.

content:
They’re so good. I used one earlier this year when I wanted to lock in on some writing work for a bit and go fairly heftily cold turkey offline, for a few weeks - I let my brother come and visit me and hide the Brick somewhere in my house where I couldn’t find it. 

I would have had to call him, and ask him to come visit me, if I wanted to unlock it… and… it worked 😂

Of course most of the time I use it a bit more reasonably 😅 but it’s amazing the difference it makes doing something simple like putting it in another room so you’ll have to go all the way over there to get back online

Definitely been a game changer

author: thegreatcarsoni
content: Hey guys, so I wear a lot of different hats in my day to day, as I'm sure a lot of you do. Does anyone else experience a kind of uncertainty/mild anxiety about their work that might derive from the fact that you're not really specialized in a certain area? I feel like I'm not always as excited or confident about getting into a certain task not only because I know i'm not very good at it yet (which i know is all relative, I could still be exactly what someone else needs for something), but also because I know others are out there, sometimes in my personal circle, who are much better? For a little added detail, my fulltime career is as a voice actor, but I love mixing, and sometimes I produce some baby artists, engineer ADR and video game/commercial voiceover. This week i was asked to dialog edit an animated film, I have to comp vocals for someone's song, and there's always a litany of othere stuff, none of which I ever feel prepared to do so the work usually takes longer than I know it should. Maybe the answer is simply to stop trying to be everything to everyone, but honestly I'm terrified to put all my eggs into the voiceover basket even though it's what I've got the most momentum with.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Does anyone use Apple's mail app to manage their email accounts? I'm considering switching to an email manager like *Mail* or *Thunderbird* because I have multiple Gmail accounts (personal, work, creative work, etc) and I want to access them all in one window.

**But here's the thing I can't solve:** All of my incoming emails (useful, updates, promotions, notifications, etc) get dumped straight into my inbox. Suddenly my inbox goes from being empty to having 8000+ unread emails.

I've become accustomed to Gmail's *categories*, which automatically files promotions, updates, social notifications, etc to their own tabs. This keeps my inbox tidy and focused. However it seems to be a proprietary feature that doesn't exist in all other email managers.

**So. My question:** Has anyone found a way to make their email manager sort incoming mail into categories like this? Yes, I could manually create rules and filters to sort into folders. But the initial setup labor and ongoing upkeep is not something I am interested in doing at this time.

author: Kian
content:
I've been using apple mail for about 6 months now (switched to apple after getting a mac and going apple brained), and I had the same issue at first but quickly got used to things.

Apple mail has the categories at the top, but they act like filters and not separate inboxes. "Primary, Transactions, Promotions, Updates", and then filters for unread/read.

author: Kian
content:
as for managing seperate emails in apple mail, its a bit more cumbersome. Initially I was really annoyed by the delay that it took to bounce emails from my @gmail domain to apple mail, but i slowly got used to it. Sometimes emails that get sent to my alternate email show up in apple mail as read which is annoying too. 

Other than that things are okay. Even though you can look at each account's inbox individually, it does put every accounts messages into the main inbox too. If you're just annoyed by having 8000+ unread emails on an account that you generally don't want to receive notifications for, set up a rule to mark any emails in that account as read.

author: Slow Hand
content:
What's the strategy with aliases and forwarding?

On the whole I'm very happy with Gmail. In fact, the phone app works great. I'm very happy with it. However, I have so many accounts that it's cumbersome in a browser to open a window to check for updates on each account. I wish there was a consolidated viewer, or some sort of global indicator to show me my total number of new messages across all accounts.

Ideally, Google would just make their own desktop app. Unfortunately desktop software is against their strategy these days. So we're unlikely to see that.

author: Will Trotman
content:
Interesting, that’s good to hear it’s gotten better, I was assuming it had gone the other way. 

I just wonder what kind of disruption could be large enough to cause a shift away from Spotify, since they’re pretty firmly on top. It seems like streaming is about as easy as it’s going to get, and I don’t really hear any Spotify users with qualms about their experience.

I do wonder if artists will become less partial to Spotify over time though. It seems like there are so many different metrics of success now (Spotify streams, instagram followers, tik tok followers are the main ones I think of) that aren’t always mutually inclusive of each other. And I wonder if that takes a little weight off of streaming numbers being the only metric that legitimizes an artist. And I hear people like Ryan Tedder talk about the importance of “world building” for artists now - I wonder if fans of artists will care more about being part of that artist’s ecosystem than the artist’s music being a part of their music library. I think of how K Pop bands sell crazy numbers of physical copies as an example. They can still stream the music but it seems like there are more variables now.

Thinking out loud a little bit, I might have just said absolutely nothing with a lot of words lol.

author: Will Trotman
content:
Has anyone here ever experienced a significant loss of fidelity (like more than normal) with tracks after they’re distributed? Been listening back to a project I did that came out end of last year and, after A/Bing the songs with the master files, I’m pretty positive something is going on. The artist double checked the files and they’re all the right ones. Only thing I can think of is they switched from distrokid to a different company mid project rollout. Not sure how that would affect things.

The sound is just kinda phasey, almost “bubbly.” Kinda like if someone threw a bunch of waves NS1 all over the session (which I didn’t lol). Kinda driving me a little crazy.

Edit: Got confirmation from the artist and ME that it’s weird. It’s only on the singles she uploaded to distrokid before switching to the smaller distro, so she’s reaching out to them. Beware the distro switch.

author: Will Trotman
content: Yeah it’s definitely more than that. I literally got my mom to listen and she could hear it, which says something lol. I never noticed the issues before the distro swap mid rollout, so my hunch is that there was some sort of weird file conversion when they got handed off to the new company. Definitely a little embarrassing tho because they just sound kinda bad
